(2)  If the consideration is between $1,500.00 and $7,500.00, at least three quotations shall be solicited by mail or telephone request from three prospective vendors, from which the lowest quotation with the proper qualifications shall be accepted. A record of the quotations shall be maintained. 
(3)  All supplies and contractual services estimated to cost in excess of $7,500.00 shall be purchased by formal, written contract from the lowest responsible bidder, after due "notice" inviting proposals. Whenever possible, at least three bids should be obtained from prospective, qualified vendors. The board of aldermen shall award the contract or purchase. 
(4)  Individual contracts, purchases, or sales, be they for goods, supplies, commodities, or services, shall not be excluded from the requirement of competitive bidding hereinabove described. 
(5)  Individual contracts or purchases shall not be subdivided for the purpose of evading the requirement of competitive bidding. 
(Ord. No. 1783, § 1(5), 1-19-2015) 
Sec. 2-394. - Method of giving notice. 
    The notice shall consist of the following: 
(1)  Notice inviting bids shall be published once in at least one official newspaper of the city at least five days preceding the last day set for the receipt of proposals. The newspaper notice required herein shall include a general description of the articles to be purchased or sold, shall state where bid blanks and specifications may be secured, and the time and place for opening bids. 
(2)  The purchasing agent shall also solicit sealed bids by direct mail, e-mail or telephone request to prospective vendors as may seem to him to be in the best interest of the city. 
(Ord. No. 1783, § 1(6), 1-19-2015) 
Sec. 2-395. - Bid opening procedure. 
    Bids shall be submitted sealed to the purchasing agent or his designee and shall be identified as bids on the envelope. They shall be opened in public at the time and place stated in the public notices. A tabulation of all bids received shall be posted for public inspection. 
(Ord. No. 1783, § 1(7), 1-19-2015) 
Sec. 2-396. - Lowest qualified bidder. 
    The city reserves the right to reject any or all bids. Contracts shall be awarded to the lowest qualified bidder. Bids shall not be accepted from, nor contract awarded to, a contractor who is in default on the payment of taxes, licenses or other moneys needed elsewhere due the city. In determining "lowest qualified bidder," in addition to price, the following shall be considered: 
(1)  The ability, capacity and skill of the bidder to perform the contract or provide the service required; 
(2)  Whether the bidder can perform the contract or provide the service promptly, or within the time specified, without delay or interference; 
(3)  The character, integrity, reputation, judgment, experience and efficiency of the bidder; 
(4)  The quality of performance of previous contracts or services; 
(5)  The previous and existing compliance by the bidder with laws and ordinances relating to the contract or service; 
(6)  The sufficiency of the financial resources and ability of the bidder to perform the contract or provide the service; 
(7)  The quality, availability and adaptability of the supplies, or contractual services to the particular use required; 
(8)  The ability of the bidder to provide future maintenance and service for the use of the subject of the contract; 
(9)  The number and scope of conditions attached to the bid. 
(Ord. No. 1783, § 1(8), 1-19-2015) 
Sec. 2-397. - Justification of award. 
(a)  All bids in excess of $7,500.00 shall be accepted or rejected by the board of aldermen. When the award is not given to the lowest bidder, a full and complete statement of the reasons for placing the order elsewhere shall be entered upon the minutes of the board of aldermen. 
(b)  If all bids received or the lowest bids received are for the same total amount or unit price, or the local bid is within five percent of the lowest bid, quality and service being equal, the contract shall be awarded to a local bidder who maintains an office/residence within the city or to a bidder who maintains an office/residence within the county if no local bid has been received. 
(c)  The contract shall be awarded by the board of aldermen, at their discretion. 
(Ord. No. 1783, § 1(9), 1-19-2015) 
Sec. 2-398. - State bids, cooperative procurement plans. 
    The purchasing agent shall have the authority to join with other units of government in cooperative procurement plans when the best interests of the city would be served thereby. Competitive sealed bids or sealed proposals received by any other governmental department shall be the equivalent of bids or proposals received by the city and may be the basis for any procurement by the city. 
(Ord. No. 1783, § 1(10), 1-19-2015) 
Sec. 2-399. - Emergency purchases. 
(a)  In case of an apparent emergency which requires immediate purchase of supplies or contractual services, the purchasing agent or his designee may authorize the purchases at the lowest obtainable price. Emergency procurement of supplies, materials, services, professional services and construction items is allowed when there exists a threat to the public health, welfare, or safety, provided that such emergency procurement shall be made with such competition as is practicable under the circumstances. A written determination of the basis for the emergency and for the selection of the particular contractor shall be made and shall set forth the contractor's name, the amount and type of the contract, and a listing of the items procured under the contract. 
(b)  In no event shall the contract price exceed commercially reasonable prices. A full explanation of the circumstances of an emergency purchase shall be made in writing and presented to the board of aldermen at the next regularly scheduled meeting. 
(Ord. No. 1783, § 1(11), 1-19-2015) 
Sec. 2-400. - Sole source procurement. 
    A contract may be awarded without competition when the purchasing agent determines in writing, after conducting a good faith review of available sources, that there is only one source for the required supply, service or construction item. The purchasing agent shall conduct negotiations, as appropriate, as to price, delivery and terms. The board of aldermen shall make such an award when the proposed expenditure is in excess of the amount set forth in section 2-393(3). The purchasing agent shall make the award when the proposed expenditure is less than or equal to the amount set forth in section 2-393(3). 
(Ord. No. 1783, § 1(12), 1-19-2015) 
Sec. 2-401. - Debarment or suspension. 
(a)  Authority to debar or suspend. After reasonable notice to the person involved and reasonable opportunity for that person to be heard, the board of aldermen, after consulting with the city attorney, may debar a company for cause from consideration for award of contracts. The debarment shall be for a period of not more than two years. The board of aldermen may suspend a company from consideration for award of contracts if there is probable cause to believe that the company has engaged in any activity which might lead to debarment. The causes for debarment include: 
(1)  Conviction for commission of a criminal offense as an incident to obtaining or attempting to obtain a public or private contract or subcontract or in the performance of such contract or subcontract. 
(2)  Conviction under state or federal statutes of embezzlement, theft, forgery, bribery, falsification or destruction of records, receiving stolen property or any other offense indicating a lack of business integrity or business honesty which currently, seriously and directly affects responsibility as a city contractor. 
(3)  Conviction under state and federal anti-trust statutes arising out of the submission of bids or proposals. 
(4)  Violation of contract provisions, as set forth below, of a character which is regarded to be so serious as to justify debarment action: 
a.  Deliberate failure without good cause to perform in accordance with the specifications or within the time limit provided in the contract; or 
b.  A recent record of failure to perform or of unsatisfactory performance in accordance with the terms of one or more contracts, provided that failure to perform or unsatisfactory performance caused by acts beyond the control of the contractor shall not be considered to be a basis for debarment. 
(5)  Any other cause the board of aldermen determines to be so serious and compelling as to affect responsibility as a city contractor, including debarment by another governmental entity for any cause listed in this policy. 
(b)  Decision to debar or suspend. The board of aldermen shall issue a written decision to debar or suspend. The decision shall state the reasons for the action taken. 
(Ord. No. 1783, § 1(14), 1-19-2015) 
Sec. 2-402. - Exemptions. 
(a)  Generally. Although the appropriate authority shall endeavor to obtain the highest quality professional services at the least expense, the provisions of this division shall not apply to the procurement of professional services, including, but not limited to, that of professional engineers, consultants, certified public accountants, auditors, attorneys and judges. 
(b)  Miscellaneous exemptions. A contract for materials, professional services or services may be awarded without competition if the board of aldermen determines that one or more of the following conditions exists: 
(1)  There exists only one responsible source; 
(2)  Although there exists more than one responsible source, a competitive process cannot reasonably be used or, if used, will result in a substantially higher cost to the city, will otherwise injure the city's financial interests or will substantially impede the city's administrative functions or the delivery of services to the public; 
(3)  A particular material or service is required to maintain interchangeability or compatibility as a part of an existing integrated system; 
(4)  A particular material, professional service or service is required in order to standardize or maintain standardization for the purpose of reducing financial investment or simplifying administration; 
(5)  The material is perishable; 
(6)  The material qualifies as an object of fine art; 
(7)  A particular material is required to match materials in use so as to produce visual harmony; 
(8)  A professional advisor or consultant prescribes a particular material; 
(9)  A particular material is required to enable use by a specific individual; and 
(10)  The material, professional service, or service is the subject of a change order. 
(c)  Construction change orders. 
(1)  One or more change orders to an existing construction contract which do not exceed a cumulative cost of 15 percent of the original contract awarded pursuant to an invitation for bids or request for proposals may be executed as long as funds are available. 
(2)  Any construction change order which authorizes a new improvement under a construction contract may be executed when: 
a.  The new improvement is required for the completion of an improvement which is currently under construction pursuant to a competitive bidding or competitive proposal process; 
b.  The new improvement results from the discovery of differing or unforeseen physical conditions at the site of the improvement under construction and is required for the completion of the improvement under construction; and 
c.  An administrative finding has been made by the purchasing agent that it would be in the city's best interest to negotiate with the on-site contractor for the construction of the new improvements after recommendation of the engineer or architect. 
(3)  Every contract modification, change order or contract price adjustment in excess of 15 percent of the original contract amount under a construction contract with the city shall be subject to prior approval by the board of aldermen after receiving a report from the city administrator as to the effect of the contract modification, change order or contract price adjustment on the total project budget or the total contract budget. 
(Ord. No. 1783, § 1(15), 1-19-2015) 
Sec. 2-403. - Bid, performance and payment bonds. 
    When deemed necessary by the purchasing agent, bid bonds, performance bonds or payment bonds, cash or other equivalent security shall be required to protect the city's interests. Any such requirements shall be set forth in the solicitation. A surety company or recognized lending agency shall provide the surety in a form satisfactory to the city. Unless a specific extension is granted in writing, a successful bidder or offer or shall forfeit any bond or equivalent security required by the purchasing agent or this section upon its failure to enter into a contract within 15 days after the award. 
(Ord. No. 1783, § 1(16), 1-19-2015) 
Sec. 2-404. - Disposal of city equipment. 
    City equipment that is deemed no longer operable or is obsolete may be disposed of through a competitive bid process with notice as outlined earlier in this policy, by public auction, trade-in on newer equipment or in any other way as approved by the board of aldermen. 
(Ord. No. 1783, § 1(17), 1-19-2015) 
Secs. 2-405-2-422. - Reserved. 
Subdivision II. - Specifications 

Sec. 2-423. - Intent. 
    All specifications, including, but not limited to, design, performance, combination and brand name specifications, shall be drafted so as to provide a clear and concise description of the material, service or construction desired. 
(Ord. No. 1783, § 1(13.1), 1-19-2015) 
Sec. 2-424. - Preparation. 
    Before any procurement requiring bids, written specifications shall be prepared detailing the city's requirements for the materials, service or construction. The purchasing agent may request other departments or agencies of the city to prepare specifications for procurement to be made primarily for such department or agency. 
(Ord. No. 1783, § 1(13.2), 1-19-2015) 
Sec. 2-425. - Approval. 
    Specifications prepared primarily for a procurement for a specific department or activity of the city shall be approved by both the purchasing agent and the head of the using department before being submitted for bid. 
(Ord. No. 1783, § 1(13.3), 1-19-2015) 
Sec. 2-426. - Maximum practicable competition. 
    All specifications shall be drafted so as to promote overall economy for the purposes intended and encourage competition in satisfying the city's needs and shall not be unduly restrictive. The policy enunciated in this section applies to all specifications, including, but not limited to, those prepared for the city by architects, engineers, designers and draftsmen. 
(Ord. No. 1783, § 1(13.4), 1-19-2015) 
Sec. 2-427. - Brand name or equal specification. 
(a)  Use. Brand name or equal specifications may be used when the purchasing agent determines that: 
(1)  No other design or performance specification or qualified products list is available; 
(2)  Time does not permit the preparation of another form of purchase description, not including a brand name specification; 
(3)  The nature of the product and the nature of the city's requirements make use of a brand name or equal specification suitable for the procurement; or 
(4)  Use of a brand name or equal specification is in the city's best interests. 
(b)  Designation of several brand names. Brand name or equal specifications shall seek to designate three or as many different brands as are practicable, as "or equal" references and shall further state that substantially equivalent products to those designated will be considered for award. 
(c)  Required characteristics. Unless the purchasing agent determines that the essential characteristics of the brand names included in the specifications are commonly known in the industry or trade, brand name or equal specifications shall include a description of the particular design, functional or performance characteristics. 
(d)  Non-restrictive use of brand name or equal specifications. Where a brand name or equal specification is used in a solicitation, the solicitation shall contain explanatory language that the use of a brand name is for the purpose of describing the standard of quality performance and characteristics desired and are not intended to limit or restrict completion. 
(Ord. No. 1783, § 1(13.5), 1-19-2015) 
Sec. 2-428. - Brand name specification. 
(a)  Use. Since use of a brand name specification is restrictive of product competition, it may be used only when the purchasing agent makes a determination that only the identified brand name item or items will satisfy the city's needs. 
(b)  Competition. The purchasing agent shall seek to identify sources from which the designated brand name item or items can be obtained and shall solicit such sources to achieve whatever degree of price competition is practicable. If only one source can supply the requirement, the procurement shall be made under section 2-400. 
(Ord. No. 1783, § 1(13.6), 1-19-2015) 
Sec. 2-429. - Construction safety training. 
(a)  Required. Any person signing a contract to work on the construction of public works for the city shall provide a ten-hour Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) construction safety program for their on-site employees which includes a course in construction safety and health approved by OSHA or a similar program approved by the state department of labor and industrial relations which is at least as stringent as an approved OSHA program. All employees are required to complete the program within 60 days of beginning work on such construction project. 
(b)  Workers to maintain documentation of completion of training. Any employee found on a work site subject to this section without documentation of the successful completion of the course shall be afforded 20 days to produce such documentation before being subject to removal from the project. 
(c)  Violations and penalties. Noncompliance with this section will be investigated and adjudicated by the department of labor and industrial relations pursuant to RSMo 292.675. 
(Ord. No. 1783, § 1(13.7), 1-19-2015) 
Chapter 4 - ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Public intoxication, RSMo 67.305 et seq.; Liquor Control Law, RSMo 311.010 et seq.; local licensing of malt liquor sales, RSMo 311.200; drunkenness or drinking in certain places, RSMo 574.075. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 4-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Intoxicating liquor means and includes alcohol for beverage purposes, alcoholic, spirituous, vinous, fermented, malt or other liquors, or combination of liquors, a part of which is spirituous, vinous or fermented, and all preparations or mixtures for beverage purposes, containing in excess of one-half of one percent by volume. 
    Malt liquor means and includes any beer manufactured from pure hops or pure extract of hops, and pure barley malt or other wholesome creams or cereals and wholesome yeasts and pure water, and free from all harmful substances, preservatives and adulterants, and having an alcoholic content in excess of 3.2 percent by weight and not in excess of five percent by weight. 
    Wholesaler means and includes any person who maintains, or is in charge of, any place of business or depot in the city where intoxicating liquor is kept or stored for sale to any other licensed dealer. 
(Code 1971, § 3-1; Code 1991, § 3-1; Ord. No. 1488, § 1, 2-12-1996; Ord. No. 1646, § 1, 1-17-2005) 
State Law reference- "Intoxicating liquor" defined, RSMo 311.020. 
Sec. 4-2. - Possession restricted. 
    No person shall possess intoxicating liquor within the city unless the same has been acquired from some person holding a license or unless the intoxicating liquor is kept with the written permission of the state supervisor of liquor control, and the package in which intoxicating liquor is contained has been labeled and sealed with the official seal prescribed under state law; provided, however, that nothing in this chapter shall be construed as to prevent the natural fermentation of fruit juices in any home for the exclusive use of the occupants of the home and their guests. 
(Code 1971, § 3-31; Code 1991, § 3-47) 
Sec. 4-3. - Transportation in open containers. 
(a)  No person shall transport an open beer or liquor container in a motor vehicle in the city. 
(b)  A person commits the offense of transporting an open beer or liquor container if a container of malt liquor or intoxicating liquor is found to be open (that is available for ready consumption) within a vehicle which that person has under his control or in which that person is a passenger. 
(c)  Any person violating the provisions of this section, upon conviction, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be fined not less than $10.00 nor more than $300.00 for any such conviction. 
(Code 1991, § 3-3; Ord. No. 1293, §§ 1-3, 8-2-1982) 
State Law reference- Unfinished bottles of wine as exception to local open container regulations, RSMo 311.101. 
Sec. 4-4. - Drinking in public. 
    No person within the city shall drink any intoxicating liquor on any street or sidewalk, or in any theater or public vehicle, or in any public place or building. 
(Code 1971, § 3-40; Code 1991, § 3-56) 
Sec. 4-5. - Permitting unlawful activity. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to own, operate, lease, occupy or control any building, car, shed, room, basement, structure, tent or booth and knowingly permit intoxicating liquor to be unlawfully manufactured, sold, stored, kept or consumed therein or thereon. 
(Code 1971, § 3-41; Code 1991, § 3-57) 
Sec. 4-6. - Sales to drunkards, intoxicated persons prohibited. 
    No person shall sell or supply intoxicating liquor, or permit the same to be sold or supplied, to a habitual drunkard or to any person who is intoxicated or appearing to be in a state of intoxication. 
(Code 1971, § 3-37; Code 1991, § 3-53) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 311.310. 
Sec. 4-7. - Druggists, physicians. 
    Any druggist may have in his possession intoxicating liquor purchased from a person holding a license issued pursuant to this chapter, or lawfully acquired at the place of acquisition and legally transported into this state and lawfully inspected, gauged and labeled as provided for in the Liquor Control Law, RSMo 311.010 et seq., to be used in compounding medicines or as a solvent or preservant in his business; provided, however, that nothing in this chapter shall prevent a regularly licensed druggist, after he procures a license in compliance with this chapter, from selling intoxicating liquor in the original packages, but not to be drunk or the packages opened on the premises where sold; provided, further, that nothing in this chapter shall be construed as limiting the right of a physician to prescribe intoxicating liquor in accordance with his professional judgment for any patient at any time, or prevent a druggist from selling intoxicating liquor to a person on prescription from a regularly licensed physician. 
(Code 1971, § 3-36; Code 1991, § 3-52) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions under Liquor Control Law, RSMo 311.470. 
Sec. 4-8. - Certification of convictions. 
    Upon conviction of any person for violating any provision of this chapter, it shall be the duty of the judge to certify such conviction to the board of aldermen. 
(Code 1971, § 3-44; Code 1991, § 3-60) 
Secs. 4-9-4-34. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - LICENSES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Authority of city to regulate and control sale of intoxicating liquors, RSMo 311.220. 

Sec. 4-35. - License required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to manufacture, distill, blend, sell or offer for sale, either at wholesale or retail, within the city, any intoxicating liquor without first having obtained a license therefor from the city. 
(Code 1971, § 3-16; Code 1991, § 3-32) 
State Law reference- Authority of city to require liquor licenses, RSMo 311.220. 
Sec. 4-36. - Qualifications for license. 
(a)  No person shall be granted a license under this article unless he is of good moral character, a native born or naturalized citizen of the United States, and possesses all of the qualifications required for an application for a similar license from this state. 
(b)  No person shall be granted a license under this article whose license as such dealer has been revoked, or who has been convicted, since the ratification of the 21st amendment to the Constitution of the United States, of a violation of the provisions of any law applicable to the manufacture or sale of intoxicating liquor, or who employs in his business as such dealer, any person whose license has been revoked or who has been convicted of violating the provisions of any such law since the date aforesaid. 
(Code 1971, § 3-17; Code 1991, § 3-33) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions under Liquor Control Law, RSMo 311.060. 
Sec. 4-37. - Application for license. 
(a)  All applications for licenses within the scope of this article shall be made in writing to the board of aldermen. 
(b)  All applications required by this article, except for the sale of malt liquor, shall be accompanied by an inventory and an appraisal of the stock of goods, other than intoxicating liquor, at the proposed place of business. Such inventory and appraisal shall be made under oath and shall be the value according to the invoices at the time of the making of the application for such license. 
(c)  No license within the scope of this article shall be granted at the same meeting of the board of aldermen at which the application therefor is presented except by unanimous vote of the board; provided, however, that such application may be considered by the board of aldermen at the first meeting of the board at which the application is presented if the applicant has first served written notice upon each member of the board, at least five days before the meeting of the board at which such application is to be presented, of his intention to present such application. 
(d)  In addition to the above requirements, an application for a license to sell intoxicating liquor by the drink at retail for consumption on the premises shall be accompanied by a copy of the organization's certificate of exemption from the payment of federal income taxes, issued by the United States Internal Revenue Service under section 501(c)(3), 501(c)(4), 501(c)(5), 501(c)(7), 501(c)(8), 501(c)(10), 501(c)(19), or 501(d) of the United States Internal Revenue Code, as amended. The city clerk shall immediately reject any such application which is not accompanied by a copy of such certificate. 
(Code 1971, § 3-18; Code 1991, § 3-34; Ord. No. 1575, § 1, 10-16-2000) 
State Law reference- Application for license under Liquor Control Law, RSMo 311.210, 311.230. 
Sec. 4-38. - Issuance of license generally. 
    The city clerk shall issue a license within the scope of this article to any person who complies with all of the requirements of this article to the satisfaction of the board of aldermen, including payment of all license fees prescribed by this article. 
(Code 1971, § 3-19; Code 1991, § 3-35; Ord. No. 1766, § 1, 9-24-2012) 
Sec. 4-39. - Issuance of license prohibited near schools, churches. 
    No license shall be issued to any person for the sale of intoxicating liquor within 100 feet of any church building or school building within the city. 
(Code 1971, § 3-20; Code 1991, § 3-36) 
State Law reference- Authority of city to prohibit sale near schools and churches, RSMo 311.080(2). 
Sec. 4-40. - License fees designated. 
(a)  Annual license fees are provided in the city fee schedule for the following classes of licenses: 
(1)  For manufacturing, distilling or blending intoxicating liquor of all kinds, and to sell to, and solicit orders from, duly licensed wholesalers of the same. 
(2)  For manufacturing intoxicating liquor containing not more than 22 percent of alcohol by weight, and to sell to, and solicit orders from, duly licensed wholesalers of the same. 
(3)  For manufacturing and brewing malt liquor not in excess of five percent of alcohol by weight, and to sell to, and solicit orders from, duly licensed wholesalers of the same. 
(4)  For the sale of, and soliciting orders for the sale of, intoxicating liquor of all kinds to, by or through a duly licensed wholesaler within the state. 
(5)  For the sale of, and soliciting orders for the sale of, intoxicating liquor containing not more than 22 percent of alcohol by weight to, by or through a duly licensed wholesaler within the state. 
(6)  For the sale of, and soliciting orders for the sale of, malt liquor containing not more than five percent of alcohol by weight to, by or through a duly licensed wholesaler within the state. 
(7)  For the sale of intoxicating liquor of all kinds by a wholesaler to a duly licensed retailer. 
(8)  For the sale of intoxicating liquor containing not more than 22 percent of alcohol by weight by a wholesaler to a duly licensed retailer. 
(9)  For the sale of malt liquor containing not more than five percent of alcohol by weight by a wholesaler to a duly licensed retailer. 
(10)  For the sale of intoxicating liquor in the original package at retail. 
(11)  For the sale of intoxicating liquor in the original package at retail on Sundays between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 12:00 midnight, by any person licensed pursuant to subsection (a)(10) of this section, in addition to the license fee prescribed by said subsection (a)(10). 
(12)  For the sale of malt liquor containing alcohol in excess of 3.2 percent by weight and not in excess of five percent by weight in the original package. Any person licensed pursuant to this subsection may also sell malt liquor at retail between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 12:00 midnight on Sunday. 
(13)  For the sale of malt liquor at retail by the drink for consumption on the premises where sold. Notwithstanding the provisions of section 4-100, any person licensed pursuant to this subsection may also sell malt liquor at retail between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 12:00 midnight on Sunday. 
(14)  For the sale of malt liquor and light wines containing not in excess of 14 percent of alcohol by weight made exclusively from grapes, berries and other fruits and vegetables, at retail by the drink for consumption on the premises where sold. 
(15)  For the sale of intoxicating liquor at retail by the drink for consumption on the premises where sold by a charitable, fraternal, religious, service or veterans' organization exempt from the payment of federal income taxes under section 501(c)(3), 501(c)(4), 501(c)(5), 501(c)(7), 501(c)(8), 501(c)(10), 501(c)(19), or 501(d) of the United States Internal Revenue Code, as amended, which includes the license described in subsection (a)(10) of this section, provided the organization shall have qualified in all ways for a state liquor license under RSMo 311.090. 
(16)  For the consumption of intoxicating liquor on premises where food, beverage or entertainment are sold or provided for compensation, where the person operating said premises does not have a license to sell intoxicating liquor. 
(17)  For a temporary permit for sale of malt liquor and light wines at retail by the drink for consumption on the premises where sold by a church, school, civic, service, fraternal, veteran, political or charitable club or organization at a picnic, bazaar, fair, festival or similar gathering or event held to commemorate the annual anniversary of the signing of the Declaration of Independence of the United States, pursuant to RSMo 311.218. 
(18)  For the sale of intoxicating liquor by the drink at retail for consumption on the premises of any resort, as defined in RSMo 311.095, which includes the license described in subsection (a)(10) of this section. 
(b)  The fees for the other licenses and permits required under this article shall be as follows: 
(1)  For a special permit to conduct tastings of malt beverages, wines or intoxicating liquors, as provided in section 4-50. 
(2)  For a temporary permit for sale of intoxicating liquor at retail by the drink for consumption on the premises where sold by a church, school, civic, service, fraternal, veteran, political or charitable club or organization at a picnic, bazaar, fair or similar gathering, pursuant to RSMo 311.482. 
(3)  For a temporary permit for the sale of intoxicating liquor by the drink at retail for consumption on the premises of any resort, as provided in RSMo 311.095(4). 
(4)  For a temporary permit to caterers and other persons holding licenses to sell intoxicating liquor by the drink at retail for consumption on the premises who furnish provisions and service for use at a particular function, occasion or event at a particular location other than the licensed premises, as provided in RSMo 311.485(1), for each calendar day, or fraction thereof, for which the permit is issued. 
(5)  For a special license to caterers and other persons holding licenses to sell intoxicating liquor by the drink at retail for consumption on the premises who furnish provisions and service for use at a particular function, occasion or event at a particular location other than the licensed premises, effective for a maximum of 50 days during any year, as provided in RSMo 311.486(1). 
(6)  For a special license to caterers and other persons holding licenses to sell intoxicating liquor by the drink at retail for consumption on the premises who furnish provisions and service for use at a particular function, occasion or event at a particular location other than the licensed premises, effective for an unlimited number of functions during the year, as provided in RSMo 311.486(2). 
(Code 1971, § 3-21; Code 1991, § 3-37; Ord. No. 1445, § 1, 6-21-1993; Ord. No. 1575, § 2, 10-16-2000; Ord. No. 1625, § 1, 2-16-2004; Ord. No. 1646, § 2, 1-17-2005; Ord. No. 1720, § 1, 8-17-2009; Ord. No. 1766, § 2, 9-24-2012; Ord. No. 1774, § 1, 8-19-2013) 
State Law reference- Authority of city to prescribe license fee, RSMo 311.220(2). 
Sec. 4-41. - Issuance of receipt upon payment of license fee. 
    The city clerk shall issue a receipt to any person who has paid the license fees prescribed by this article. 
(Code 1971, § 3-22; Code 1991, § 3-38; Ord. No. 1766, § 3, 9-24-2012) 
Sec. 4-42. - Forfeiture of license fee. 
    In the event any license issued pursuant to this article is revoked or forfeited, for cause or otherwise, the city shall not return any part of the license fee paid for such license. 
(Code 1971, § 3-23; Code 1991, § 3-39) 
Sec. 4-43. - Duration of license. 
    The licenses provided for by section 4-40(a) shall be for a period of one year commencing July 1 and ending June 30 each year. No refunds shall be made of any part of the license fees because of discontinuance of business prior to expiration of the licensing period. License fees for persons first commencing business for which a license is required hereunder after July 31 shall be prorated by the month, and such persons shall pay for only those months to elapse before the next succeeding June 30. 
(Code 1971, § 3-24; Code 1991, § 3-40; Ord. No. 1766, § 4, 9-24-2012) 
State Law reference- Period of license under Liquor Control Law, RSMo 311.240. 
Sec. 4-44. - Limit on number of licenses. 
    The number of licenses issued by the city to sell intoxicating liquor in excess of five percent of alcohol by weight, in the original package, within the city is hereby limited to one such license for each 400 population of the city, as shown by the last preceding federal census, and one license for any major fraction remaining in excess of each 400 population in the city as shown by such census. 
(Code 1971, § 3-25; Code 1991, § 3-41; Ord. No. 1399, § 1, 6-29-1989; Ord. No. 1622, § 1, 10-20-2003) 
Sec. 4-45. - Contents of license. 
    Every license issued pursuant to this article shall describe the premises at which intoxicating liquor may be sold and the kind of intoxicating liquor to be sold therein. 
(Code 1971, § 3-26; Code 1991, § 3-42) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions under Liquor Control Law, RSMo 311.240(3). 
Sec. 4-46. - License controls kinds of sales. 
    Any license issued pursuant to this article shall not be deemed to authorize or permit the sale of different kinds of intoxicating liquor other than that described in such license. 
(Code 1971, § 3-27; Code 1991, § 3-43) 
Sec. 4-47. - License controls place, time of operation. 
    No person, agent or employee of any person, in any capacity, shall sell intoxicating liquor in any place or at any other time than that designated in the license issued pursuant to this article. 
(Code 1971, § 3-28; Code 1991, § 3-44) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions under Liquor Control Law, RSMo 311.240(3). 
Sec. 4-48. - License nontransferable. 
    No license issued pursuant to this article shall be transferable or assignable. 
(Code 1971, § 3-29; Code 1991, § 3-45) 
State Law reference- Transferability of license under Liquor Control Law, RSMo 311.250. 
Sec. 4-49. - Separate license required for each place of business. 
    A separate license within the purview of this article shall be required for each place of business. 
(Code 1971, § 3-30; Code 1991, § 3-46) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions under Liquor Control Law, RSMo 311.240(1). 
Sec. 4-50. - Tasting license. 
(a)  Notwithstanding any other provisions of this article to the contrary, any person possessing the qualifications and meeting the requirements of this article who possesses a license to sell intoxicating liquor in the original package at retail, may apply for a special permit to conduct tastings of malt beverages, wines or intoxicating liquors on the licensed premises. A licensee under this section shall pay an additional fee as provided in section 4-40. 
(b)  Nothing in this section shall be construed to permit the licensee to sell malt beverages, wines or intoxicating liquors for on-premises consumption. 
(Code 1991, § 3-49.5; Ord. No. 1625, § 1, 2-16-2004) 
Sec. 4-51. - Limit on number of malt liquor and light wine licenses. 
    The number of licenses issued by the city to sell malt liquor containing alcohol in excess of 3.2 percent by weight and not in excess of five percent by weight and/or light wines containing not in excess of 14 percent of alcohol by weight as defined herein for sale at retail by the drink for consumption on the premises where sold, within the city, is hereby limited to one such license for each 500 population of the city, as shown by the last preceding federal census, and one license for any major fraction remaining in excess of each 500 population in the city as shown by such census. 
(Code 1991, § 3-50.5; Ord. No. 1488, § 3, 2-12-1996) 
Sec. 4-52. - Revocation of license. 
(a)  The board of aldermen may, after a hearing, revoke any license issued pursuant to this article if the licensee has not at all times kept an orderly place, or if he has violated any of the provisions of this article or for any other good cause shown after having first given such licensee not less than ten days' notice in writing of the application to revoke his license. Such notice shall contain the ground or grounds for revocation and shall command the licensee to be present at the regular or called meeting of the board of aldermen and show cause, if any, why such license should not be revoked; provided, however, that such licensee at such hearing shall have the right to be represented by counsel and produce witnesses and evidence in his behalf; provided, further, that such notice shall be served by the police chief upon the licensee by leaving a copy thereof with the licensee, or any person or employee in charge of the place of business of such licensee. 
(b)  Upon the conviction of any person licensed pursuant to this article for a violation of any of the provisions of this article, such conviction shall automatically operate to revoke the license hereunder issued to such person. 
(Code 1971, § 3-42; Code 1991, § 3-58) 
State Law reference- Revocation of license under Liquor Control Law, RSMo 311.555, 311.557, 311.600. 
Sec. 4-53. - Violation bars issuance, renewal of license. 
    No person convicted of violating any of the provisions of this article shall be issued a license or a renewal thereof for a period of one year from the date of such conviction. 
(Code 1971, § 3-43; Code 1991, § 3-59) 
Secs. 4-54-4-99. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - PREMISES AND OPERATION STANDARDS 

Sec. 4-100. - Hours of sale. 
(a)  No person who is issued a license pursuant to this chapter or any employee of such person shall sell, give away or permit the consumption of any intoxicating liquor in any quantity between the hours of 1:30 a.m. and 6:00 a.m. on weekdays and between the hours of 1:30 a.m. Sunday and 6:00 a.m. Monday, upon or about his premises. If the person has a license to sell intoxicating liquor by the drink, his premises shall be and remain closed between the hours of 1:30 a.m. and 6:00 a.m. on weekdays and between the hours of 1:30 a.m. Sunday and 6:00 a.m. Monday. 
(b)  When January 1, March 17, July 4 or December 31 falls on Sunday, and the Sundays prior to Memorial Day and Labor Day and on the Sunday on which the national championship game of the national football league is played, commonly known as "Super Bowl Sunday", any person having a license to sell intoxicating liquor by the drink may be open for business and sell intoxicating liquor or malt liquor by the drink under the provisions of his license on that day from the time and until the time that which would be lawful on another day of the week, notwithstanding the provisions of subsection (a) of this section or any other provision of law to the contrary. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to purchase or attempt to purchase intoxicating liquor within the city at any time that the sale of intoxicating liquor is prohibited by city ordinance or by state law. This provision shall not apply to any law enforcement officer in the discharge of official duty or to any person acting in conjunction with, or at the direction of, any such law enforcement officer. 
(Code 1991, § 3-48; Ord. No. 1379, § 1, 5-22-1989; Ord. No. 1445, § 2, 6-21-1993; Ord. No. 1466, § 1, 5-16-1994; Ord. No. 1475, § 1, 9-9-1994; Ord. No. 1620, § 1, 9-15-2003; Ord. No. 1646, § 3, 1-17-2005) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions under Liquor Control Law, RSMo 311.290, 311.298. 
Sec. 4-101. - Sales in original package. 
(a)  Intoxicating liquor sold at retail in the original package shall not be sold in a quantity less than one-half pint nor shall the original package be opened on the premises of the vendor. 
(b)  No intoxicating liquor purchased in the original package shall be consumed or permitted to be consumed upon any premises where intoxicating liquor is authorized to be sold. 
(c)  No license shall be issued for the sale of intoxicating liquor in the original package except to a person engaged in, and to be used in connection with, the operation of one or more of the following businesses: 
(1)  Drug store. 
(2)  Cigar store and tobacco store. 
(3)  Grocery store. 
(4)  General merchandise store. 
(5)  Confectionery store. 
(6)  Delicatessen store. 
(d)  No license shall be issued for the sale of intoxicating liquor in the original package to any person who does not have and keep in his store a stock of goods having a value, according to invoices at the time of making the application for such license and at all times thereafter, of at least $1,000.00, exclusive of fixtures and intoxicating liquor. 
(Code 1971, § 3-33; Code 1991, § 3-49) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions under Liquor Control Law, RSMo 311.200(1). 
Sec. 4-102. - Sales of malt liquor and light wines. 
    Malt liquor containing alcohol in excess of 3.2 percent by weight and not in excess of five percent by weight, as defined herein, and light wines containing not in excess of 14 percent of alcohol by weight made exclusively from grapes, berries and other fruits and vegetables, may be sold at retail by the drink for consumption on the premises where sold, when the person desiring to sell the same has been licensed therefor pursuant to this chapter; provided, however, that a licensee authorized to sell malt liquor or light wines, at retail by the drink for consumption on the premises where sold shall not be permitted to obtain a license for the sale of intoxicating liquors, other than malt liquor and/or light wines, in the original package. 
(Code 1971, § 3-34; Code 1991, § 3-50; Ord. No. 1488, § 2, 2-12-1996; Ord. No. 1646, § 4, 1-17-2005) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions under Liquor Control Law, RSMo 311.200(3). 
Sec. 4-103. - Financial interest of distillers, wholesalers, winemakers, brewers in retail sales. 
    Except as otherwise provided in RSMo 311.070, distillers, wholesalers, winemakers, brewers or their employees, officers or agents, shall not, directly or indirectly, have any financial interest in the retail business for sale of intoxicating liquor, and shall not, directly or indirectly, loan, give away or furnish equipment, money, credit or property of any kind, except ordinary commercial credit for intoxicating liquor sold to such retail dealers. Any distiller, wholesaler, winemaker or brewer who violates any provision of this section, and any retailer who cooperates in such violation, shall forfeit his license. 
(Code 1971, § 3-35; Code 1991, § 3-51) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 311.070. 
Secs. 4-104-4-134. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - MINORS 

Sec. 4-135. - Selling, supplying minors prohibited. 
    No person shall sell or supply intoxicating liquor to any person under the age of 21 years; provided, however, that this section shall not apply to the supplying of intoxicating liquor to a person under such age for medicinal purposes only, or by the parent or guardian of such person or to the administering of intoxicating liquor by a physician. 
(Code 1971, § 3-38; Code 1991, § 3-54) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 311.310. 
Sec. 4-136. - Persons 18 years of age or older may sell or handle liquor or beer, when. 
(a)  Except as provided in subsections (b) and (c) of this section, no person under the age of 21 years shall sell or assist in the sale or dispensing of intoxicating liquor. 
(b)  In any place of business licensed in accordance with RSMo 311.200 or 312.040, where at least 50 percent of the gross sales made consists of goods, merchandise, or commodities other than intoxicating liquor in the original package, persons at least 18 years of age may stock, arrange displays, accept payment for, and sack for carry out intoxicating liquor. Delivery of intoxicating liquor away from the licensed business premises cannot be performed by anyone under the age of 21 years. 
(c)  In any distillery, warehouse, wholesale distributorship, or similar place of business which stores or distributes intoxicating liquor but which does not sell intoxicating liquor or nonintoxicating beer at retail, persons at least 18 years of age may be employed and their duties may include the handling of intoxicating liquor for all purposes except consumption, sale at retail, or dispensing for consumption or sale at retail. 
(d)  Persons 18 years of age or older may, when acting in the capacity of a waiter or waitress, accept payment for or serve intoxicating liquor in places of business which sell food for consumption on the premises if at least 50 percent of all sales in those places consists of food, provided that nothing in this section shall authorize persons under 21 years of age to mix or serve across the bar intoxicating beverages. 
(Code 1971, § 3-39; Code 1991, § 3-55) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 311.300. 
Sec. 4-137. Purchase or possession by minors prohibited. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person under the age of 21 years: 
(1)  To purchase or attempt to purchase any intoxicating liquor; 
(2)  For the purpose of purchasing, to ask for or in any way receive any intoxicating liquor, except in cases authorized by law; 
(3)  To have in his possession any intoxicating liquor; 
(4)  To be visibly intoxicated as defined in RSMo 577.001; 
(5)  To have a detectable blood alcohol content of more than two hundredths of one percent or more by weight of alcohol in such person's blood. 
(b)  For purposes of prosecution under this section or any other provision of this article involving an alleged illegal sale or transfer of intoxicating liquor to a person under 21 years of age, a manufacturer-sealed container describing that there is intoxicating liquor therein need not be opened or the contents therein tested to verify that there is intoxicating liquor in such container. The alleged violator may allege that there was not intoxicating liquor in such container, but the burden of proof of such allegation is on such person, as it shall be presumed that such a sealed container describing that there is intoxicating liquor therein contains intoxicating liquor. 
(Code 1971, § 3-39.1; Code 1991, § 3-55.5; Ord. No. 1445, § 3, 6-21-1993; Ord. No. 1659, § 1, 10-17-2005) 
Chapter 6 - ANIMALS 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 6-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Adequate care means normal and prudent attention to the needs of an animal, including wholesome food, clean water, shelter and health care as necessary to maintain good health in a specific species of animal. 
    Adequate control means to reasonably restrain or govern an animal so that the animal does not injure itself, any person, any other animal, or property. 
    Animal means every living vertebrate except a human being. 
    Cat includes both male and female cats. 
    Dangerous wild animal means a lion, tiger, leopard, ocelot, jaguar, cheetah, margay, mountain lion, Canada lynx, bobcat, jaguarundi, hyena, wolf, coyote or any other deadly, dangerous or poisonous reptile. 
    Dog includes both male and female dogs. 
    Domestic waterfowl means non-native ducks, geese and swans not retained in agricultural activities. 
    Domesticated means an animal reclaimed from a wild state and adapted to life with humans. 
    Feed or feeding means the act of or furnishing of food or other sustenance. 
    Livestock means domesticated animals such as cattle, horses and hogs bred or kept for use and commercial profit. 
    Migratory waterfowl means ducks, geese and swans native to North America. 
    Owner, in addition to its ordinary interpretation, means any person who keeps or harbors an animal or professes to be owning, keeping, or harboring an animal. 
    Pet means a tame animal kept for human companionship. 
(Code 1971, §§ 4-1, 4-21; Code 1991, §§ 4-1, 4-31, 4-102; Ord. No. 1153, § 6, 12-17-1973; Ord. No. 1184, § 1, 6-2-1975; Ord. No. 1598, § 1, 5-20-2002; Ord. No. 1670, § 1, 8-21-2006) 
Sec. 6-2. - Animal control officer; summons. 
    The animal control officer is authorized and empowered to issue summons for any legal proceeding involving violations of any provision of this chapter. 
(Code 1991, § 4-10; Ord. No. 1457, § 1, 10-18-1993) 
Sec. 6-3. - Control of animals interfering with city employees. 
    It shall be unlawful for any owner or keeper of an animal to permit the animal to act in such a manner as to hinder or interfere with any city employee from discharging his official duties. 
(Code 1991, § 4-9) 
Sec. 6-4. - Interfering with impounded animals. 
    A person commits the offense of interfering with impounded animals when such person releases, or attempts to release, any animal which is impounded within the city pound or which is in the custody or control of any police officer or the animal control officer. 
(Code 1991, § 4-12; Ord. No. 1598, § 1, 5-20-2002) 
Sec. 6-5. - Disposal of certain dead animals. 
(a)  No dead horse, sheep, dog, hog, cow or horned cattle of any kind shall be left unburied in the city by the owner or keeper thereof longer than is absolutely necessary to enable such owner or keeper to remove or bury the same, and no animal shall be buried by the owner or keeper thereof within the city at any place less than 400 yards from any building occupied as a dwelling house or place of business. 
(b)  Any dead horse, sheep, dog, hog, cow or horned cattle of any kind which is buried within the city, or within one-half mile of the corporate limits thereof, shall be buried by the owner or keeper of the animal and shall be covered with earth firmly packed and filled to a level with the surrounding surface. The animal shall be buried to such a depth that no part thereof shall be nearer than four feet to the natural surface of the ground and every part of the animal shall be covered with at least four feet of earth in addition to any other materials that may be used for that purpose. 
(c)  It shall be the duty of the police chief to notify in writing the owner or keeper of any dead horse, sheep, dog, hog, cow or horned cattle of any kind that may die or be found dead within the city, or within one-half mile of such city limits, to bury the same immediately in the manner required by this section. The notice shall be served by delivering a copy thereof to the owner or keeper, or by leaving a copy at his usual place of abode with a member of his family over 12 years of age. 
(d)  If the owner or keeper of any animal of the species named in subsection (a) of this section is unknown or cannot be found within a reasonable time after the death of the animal, or discovery of its carcass, it shall be the duty of the police chief to cause the same to be buried immediately at the expense of the city. 
(e)  It shall be unlawful for the owner or keeper of any dead horse, sheep, dog, hog, cow or horned cattle of any kind to knowingly or willfully leave the same unburied anywhere in the city, or within one-half mile of the corporate limits thereof, for more than 12 hours after the death of the animal, whether or not he is notified by the police chief to bury the same; or to fail to bury such dead animal within six hours after having been notified by the police chief. 
(f)  The owner or keeper of any dead horse, sheep, dog, hog, cow or horned cattle of any kind who fails to bury the same in accordance with this section shall be liable to the city for all expenses that may be incurred by the city by reason of the failure of such owner or keeper to bury his animal as herein required, and such expense may be recovered by civil action in the name of the city before any court of competent jurisdiction. 
(Code 1971, § 4-8; Code 1991, § 4-8) 
State Law reference- Police jurisdiction, RSMo 79.380; duty of owner or keeper to dispose of dead animal, RSMo 269.020. 
Secs. 6-6-6-28. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - CARE AND CONTROL 

Sec. 6-29. - Animal abuse, neglect and abandonment. 
(a)  A person commits the offense of animal abuse when such person: 
(1)  Intentionally or purposely kills an animal in any manner not allowed by or expressly exempted from the provisions of RSMo § 578.005 to 578.023 and 273.030; 
(2)  Purposely or intentionally causes injury or suffering to an animal; or 
(3)  Having ownership or custody of an animal, knowingly fails to provide adequate care or adequate control. 
(b)  A person commits the offense of animal neglect when such person has custody or ownership or both of an animal and fails to provide adequate care or adequate control, which results in substantial harm to the animal. 
(c)  A person commits the offense of animal abandonment when such person has knowingly abandoned an animal in any place without making provisions for its adequate care. 
(d)  In addition to any other penalty imposed by this section, the municipal court may order a person found guilty of animal abuse, animal neglect or animal abandonment to pay all reasonable costs and expenses necessary for: 
(1)  The care and maintenance of abused, neglected or abandoned animals within the person's custody or ownership; 
(2)  The disposal of any dead or diseased animals within the person's custody or ownership; 
(3)  The reduction of resulting organic debris affecting the immediate area of the abuse, neglect or abandonment; and 
(4)  The avoidance or minimization of any public health risks created by the abuse, neglect or abandonment of the animals. 
(Code 1991, § 4-7; Ord. No. 1598, § 1, 5-20-2002) 
State Law reference- Animal neglect, RSMo 578.009; animal abuse, RSMo 578.012; disposition of neglected or abused animal, RSMo 578.021. 
Sec. 6-30. - Feeding wild waterfowl prohibited. 
(a)  Purpose and intent. The purpose of this section is to prevent such conduct that may attract and concentrate migratory and domestic waterfowl to public properties within the city. The presence of large numbers of waterfowl causes a public nuisance and adversely affects the city. 
(b)  Feeding and enticing prohibited. No person or persons shall feed, cause to be fed or provide food for migratory or domestic waterfowl in lands or waters publicly owned within the city. No person or persons shall foster any condition to exist or continue, which results in a congregation or congestion of migratory or domestic waterfowl. 
(c)  Penalty. Any person or persons found to be violating this section shall be subject to a fine of $50.00 for the first offense, and not less than $100.00 for the second or subsequent offenses. Each day any such violation continues shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1991, §§ 4-101, 4-103, 4-104; Ord. No. 1670, § 1, 8-21-2006) 
Secs. 6-31-6-69. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - DOGS AND CATS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Authority of city to tax, regulate, restrain and prohibit running at large of dogs, impose penalties, provide for destruction thereof, RSMo 79.400; local option dog tax, RSMo 273.040 et seq.; protection against rabies, RSMo 322.010 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 6-70. - License required; fee. 
    No person shall own or keep within the city any dog or cat over the age of four months without first obtaining a license therefor from the animal control officer. A fee as provided in the city fee schedule shall be paid for each license issued. The animal control officer shall collect license fees on June 1 of each year. Upon payment of the license fee, the animal control officer shall deliver a receipt to the person making payment showing for what purpose payment was made and for what year, together with a full description of the dog or cat for which such license fee is paid. The receipt shall serve as a license for the year named therein. 
(Code 1971, § 4-23; Code 1991, §§ 4-32-4-35; Ord. No. 1598, § 1, 5-20-2002) 
Sec. 6-71. - Vaccination required, certificate. 
    Every owner or keeper of any dog or cat over the age of four months within the city limits shall have such dog or cat vaccinated against rabies on or before June 1 of each year. The animal control officer shall not issue a dog or cat license without proof of vaccination in the form of certificate issued by the veterinarian that vaccinated the animal. 
(Code 1991, § 4-37; Ord. No. 1598, § 1, 5-20-2002) 
Sec. 6-72. - Collar required; badges attached. 
    It is the duty of the owner or keeper of any dog or cat which has been vaccinated against rabies and upon which the license fee has been paid to furnish a collar to be worn by the dog or cat on which shall be fastened a badge furnished by the veterinarian showing the rabies treatment and the year therefor and a badge furnished by the city clerk showing the license fee paid and the year therefor. The absence of any collar or badge from any dog or cat shall be prima facie evidence that the dog or cat has not been vaccinated nor the license fee paid. 
(Code 1971, § 4-29; Code 1991, § 4-38; Ord. No. 1184, § 1, 6-2-1975; Ord. No. 1408, 12-18-1989) 
Sec. 6-73. - Establishment, maintenance of pound. 
    The city shall provide a suitable place for a dog and cat pound and maintain the same in a sanitary condition. 
(Code 1971, § 4-30; Code 1991, § 4-39; Ord. No. 1153, § 3, 12-17-1973; Ord. No. 1184, § 1, 6-2-1975) 
Sec. 6-74. - Number of dogs and cats to be kept. 
    No person shall possess, keep or harbor within the city any combination of more than four dogs or cats. In addition to any penalty which may be imposed for violation of this section, the municipal court shall order the defendant to reduce the number of dogs and/or cats possessed, kept or harbored by the defendant to four. Should the defendant refuse to reduce the number of dogs or cats that defendant possesses, keeps or harbors, the municipal court shall find the defendant in contempt of court and order the immediate confiscation and impoundment of all dogs and cats possessed, kept or harbored by the defendant. In addition to the foregoing penalties, any person who violates this section shall pay all expenses, including sums for shelter, food, handling and veterinary care, which may be necessitated by the person's failure to abide by the provisions of this section. 
(Code 1991, § 4-42; Ord. No. 1598, § 1, 5-20-2002) 
Sec. 6-75. - Restraint. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to permit a dog or cat possessed, kept or harbored by him, to run at large, unless leashed, on the streets, alleys, or public places or on private premises not under control of such owner, within the city, whether a license for such dog or cat shall have been secured or not. The owner of any dog or cat who fails to keep his dog or cat under restraint shall be held liable for all damages caused by such dog or cat. For any dog or cat found running at large and which cannot be safely taken up and impounded, the animal control officer, or any police officer, is hereby authorized to use such force as may be necessary to capture such dog or cat, including the killing of such dog or cat. 
(Code 1971, § 4-38; Code 1991, § 4-43; Ord. No. 1193, § 1, 2-2-1976) 
Sec. 6-76. - Presence of dogs on public square during fair, prohibited; exception. 
    For the safety of the general public, it shall be unlawful for any person to have any dog on the public square during the period of the Lamar Free Fair. However, this section shall not apply to those dogs which are being used for health/medical reasons such as Seeing Eye dogs for the blind. Also, this section shall not apply to those dogs being used in conjunction with the Lamar Free Fair such as during animal shows and parades. 
(Code 1991, § 4-45; Ord. No. 1598, § 1, 5-20-2002) 
Secs. 6-77-6-95. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - IMPOUNDMENT 

Sec. 6-96. - Impoundment of unvaccinated, unlicensed dogs, cats; fees; ten-day hold. 
(a)  It is the duty of the police officer or animal control officer to capture and impound all dogs and cats over the age of four months found within the city which have not been properly vaccinated for rabies or which were found running at large and upon which a license has not been issued by the city. 
(b)  An owner claiming a dog or cat so impounded shall pay the animal control officer the sum as provided in the city fee schedule for the release of such dog or cat and shall pay the additional sum per day for each day or fraction thereof such dog or cat has been impounded. No dog or cat shall be released from the control of the police until the impoundment and maintenance fee has been paid and the dog or cat vaccinated for rabies and a city license procured therefor. 
(c)  All dogs and cats held in the city pound shall be fed at least once daily and the money collected through the reclaiming of dogs and cats shall be used for the purpose of defraying the expense of the impoundment and the feeding of the dogs and cats. 
(d)  In the event that any dog or cat impounded has not been reclaimed within ten days from the time it was placed in the pound, it shall be killed by a police officer or animal control officer or licensed veterinarian in a humane manner and the carcass buried. 
(e)  Any dog or cat known to have bitten any person shall be held continuously for a period of ten days from the time of the biting. Such dog or cat shall be held in the city pound, unless the owner or keeper specifically requests that such dog or cat be held by a licensed veterinarian. 
(Code 1991, § 4-40; Ord. No. 1598, § 1, 5-20-2002) 
Sec. 6-97. - Release of impounded dogs and cats. 
    No impounded dog or cat shall be released from the control of any police officer or the animal control officer until the impoundment fees imposed by this division are paid. Upon the release of a dog or cat that is not vaccinated or does not have a current license as required by this article the owner of the animal shall, within seven days of release, provide written proof to the animal control officer that the animal has been vaccinated and licensed as required by this article. 
(Code 1991, § 4-41; Ord. No. 1598, § 1, 5-20-2002) 
Secs. 6-98-6-122. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - LIVESTOCK AND DOMESTIC FOWL 

Sec. 6-123. - Keeping restricted. 
(a)  Exemptions; grandfather exemptions. This section shall not be applicable to any lawfully operated stockyard, slaughterhouse, rodeo grounds or any college or university. In addition, this section shall not be applicable to those individuals who, on May 20, 2002, were possessing, keeping or harboring livestock on property which they own or lease. This exception shall continue until ownership of the property changes, the tenant's lease is terminated, or the property is no longer used for this purpose by the person in ownership or possession as of May 20, 2002. 
(b)  Location of enclosures restricted. No person shall possess, keep or harbor within the city a cow, bull, mare, jack, horse, goat, sheep, pig, swine, hog, chicken, duck, turkey or other domestic fowl in an outdoor enclosure, outbuilding or pasture, the exterior boundary of which is within 100 feet of the dwelling house of another, or a church, school or place of business, without the prior written consent of the occupant of such dwelling house, trustees or directors of such church or school, or owner of such place of business, as the case may be. 
(c)  Maximum density. No person shall possess, keep or harbor within the city more than one cow, bull, jack, horse, goat, sheep, pig, swine, hog, chicken, turkey, or other domestic fowl, or any combination of the animals or fowl in an outdoor enclosure, outbuilding or pasture, unless such enclosure, outbuilding or pasture shall have an area of one-half acre for each of the animal and fowl, provided that this area requirement shall not apply to the keeping of suckling offspring. 
(d)  Testing and vaccination required. No person shall keep a pig, swine, or hog within the city without first having the animal tested and vaccinated for brucellosis. 
(e)  Maintenance of enclosures. Persons owning land within the city upon which livestock is kept or permitted to be kept by the landlord or otherwise, shall provide and maintain fences, corrals, tethers or similar devices to confine or restrict livestock to such property. If the animal control officer determines that such devices are lacking, inadequate or not in good repair, the animal control officer shall notify the landowner in writing and order the landowner to provide, replace, reinforce or repair such devices within ten days. Failure of the landowner to comply with the order shall constitute a violation of this section. Each day of noncompliance after the expiration of the ten days provided in the notice constitutes a distinct and separate offense. 
(f)  Exception for certain domestic fowl. Nothing in this section shall prohibit the keeping on the premises of an owner-occupied residence chickens, turkeys or other domestic fowl, excluding roosters, or any combination of the animals, not to exceed six animals, in an outdoor enclosure, outbuilding or pasture, and such enclosure, outbuilding or pasture shall have an area of not less than 30 square feet for each the animal. 
(Code 1991, §§ 4-86, 4-87; Ord. No. 1587, § 2, 5-20-2002; Ord. No. 1725, § 1, 10-19-2009) 
Sec. 6-124. - Running at large prohibited; impoundment. 
    It is unlawful for the owner or keeper of any livestock or fowl to allow the same to run at large within the city limits. If any livestock or fowl is found running at large within the city, the same shall be taken up by the animal control officer or any police officer and impounded in the city pound. 
(1)  Notice of impoundment. The police officer who impounds any livestock or fowl shall, within three days, give notice thereof to the owner, if known, in writing, stating therein the amount of compensation for feeding and keeping the animal and damages claimed, and thereupon the owner shall pay the officer taking up the animal a reasonable compensation for the taking up, keeping and feeding the animal and shall also pay all persons damaged by reason of the animal running at large, the actual damages sustained by them; provided, however, that such owner shall not be responsible for any accident on a public road or highway if he establishes the fact that the animal was outside the enclosure through no fault or negligence of the owner. If the owner is not known, or if notified and fails to make compensation for the taking up, feeding and keeping of animals taken up under the provisions of this article, the same shall be deemed strays, and shall be dealt with in the same manner as required by law with respect to such property as strays, under the stray law. 
(2)  Redemption. The owner or keeper of any livestock or fowl impounded pursuant to this article may redeem the impounded animals by paying all impoundment and boarding fees the expiration of five days from the date of impoundment. 
(3)  Sale of impounded animals. If any impounded livestock or fowl has not been claimed by the owner or keeper thereof within the time permitted under this section, the police chief shall sell the animals to the highest bidder for cash; provided, however, that the police chief shall first give ten days' notice of the time, place and terms of such sale, with a description of the property to be sold, by a written or printed handbills, posted on the gate or door of the city pound or place where such livestock or fowl is being impounded and advertised once in a newspaper of general circulation in the city not less than seven days prior to sale. 
(4)  Disposition of proceeds of sale. Any proceeds derived from any impoundment sale conducted pursuant to the provisions of this section shall be paid to the owner or keeper, if known, of the impounded livestock or fowl which has been sold after the expenses of impoundment have been deducted therefrom. If the proceeds received from the impoundment sale are not claimed by such owner or keeper within 30 days from the date of such sale, such proceeds shall be paid by the police chief into the city treasury. 
(5)  Unauthorized removal from impound prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person, without the permission of the mayor or police chief, to take away or out of the city pound any livestock or fowl impounded therein. 
(Code 1971, §§ 4-2-4-6; Code 1991, §§ 4-3-4-6; Ord. No. 1598, § 1, 5-20-2002) 
State Law reference- Authority of city to sell impounded animals, fowl, RSMo 79.400; domestic animals to be restrained from running at large, RSMo 270.010. 
Secs. 6-125-6-146. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - DANGEROUS OR VICIOUS ANIMALS 

Sec. 6-147. - Keeping dangerous wild animals, prohibited; exceptions. 
    A person commits the offense of keeping dangerous wild animals when such person possesses, keeps or harbors a dangerous wild animal within the city. This section shall not apply to dangerous wild animals possessed, kept or harbored in a properly maintained and licensed zoological park, a circus, a scientific or educational institution, a research laboratory, a veterinary hospital, or an animal refuge; provided, however, that any such dangerous wild animal is registered with the animal control officer prior to the same being brought into the city. 
(Code 1991, § 4-11; Ord. No. 1598, § 1, 5-20-2002) 
Sec. 6-148. - Dangerous or vicious domestic animals enumerated; exceptions; declaration; appeal. 
(a)  For the purpose of this article, a dangerous or vicious animal is an animal that meets any one or more of the following conditions: 
(1)  An animal which has been trained by its current owner, either personally or professionally, as a guard animal or a watch animal. 
(2)  An animal which has been trained by a previous owner, either personally or professionally, as a guard animal or a watch animal, and the current owner of the animal knows or should reasonably be expected to know that such training occurred. 
(3)  An animal against which a registered complaint has been received by the city and two pairs of city officials have investigated and found the animal to be dangerous or vicious. 
(4)  An animal against which four registered complaints from four different households have been received by the city. 
(5)  An animal that has inflicted a severe or fatal injury on a person on public or private property. The term "severe injury" means any physical injury, resulting directly from an animal's actions, which results in broken bones, lacerations or any other injury requiring professional medical closure or any other trauma requiring inpatient hospitalization. 
(6)  Any animal that has killed or severely injured a domestic animal, livestock or poultry, without provocation, while off of the owner's property. 
(7)  Any animal owned or harbored primarily or in part for the purpose of animal fighting or any animal trained for animal fighting. 
(8)  Any animal that has bitten or caused injury to a person, without provocation, on public or private property other than the property of the owner. 
(9)  Any animal which, while on the owner's property, has bitten or caused injury to, without provocation, a person other than the owner or a member of the owner's family who normally resides at the place where the animal is kept. 
(10)  Any animal which, when unprovoked, chases or approaches a person upon a street, sidewalk or any public grounds, or private property other than property of the owner, in a menacing fashion or apparent attitudes of attack, regardless of whether or not a person is injured by said animal. 
(11)  Any animal with a known propensity, tendency or disposition to attack unprovoked, to cause injury or to otherwise threaten the safety of persons or domestic animals. 
(b)  Exemptions to dangerous or vicious animal classification. 
(1)  With the exception of subsection (a)(1) of this section, no animal may be deemed dangerous or vicious if the threat, injury or damage was sustained by a person who, at the time, was committing a willful trespass or other tort upon the premises of the owner or keeper of the animal, or was teasing, tormenting, abusing or assaulting the animal, or has, in the past, been observed or reported to have teased, tormented, abused or assaulted the animal or was committing or attempting to commit a crime. 
(2)  Animals owned or used by governmental or law enforcement agencies when being used in the services of those agencies are exempt. 
(c)  Declaration of a dangerous or vicious animal. If the animal control officer or chief of police or other officer designated by the chief of police has cause to believe that an animal is dangerous or vicious, as established in subsection (a) of this section, the animal control officer or chief or designee may find and declare that the animal is dangerous or vicious and therefore subject to the terms and restrictions of this article. 
(d)  Notice of declaration of a dangerous or vicious animal. After declaring an animal dangerous or vicious, the animal control officer or chief of police or designee shall notify the animal's owner, keeper, harborer or possessor in writing of the declaration. The notice shall include a photocopy or printout of this section and a directive that the animal be removed from the city within five days. If the owner, keeper, harborer or possessor of the animal cannot be located, the animal may be immediately impounded and notice shall be posted in a conspicuous location at such person's last known address. 
(e)  Removal of animal declared dangerous or vicious. It shall be the responsibility of the owner, keeper, harborer or possessor of an animal declared dangerous or vicious under subsection (c) to cause the animal to be removed from the city within five days of said declaration, and to keep the animal out of the city subject to findings made under subsection (f) that such animal is not dangerous or vicious; failure to comply hereunder shall constitute a violation of this section. 
(f)  Hearing and appeal. If the circumstances surrounding the declaration of a dangerous or vicious animal under any of the conditions listed in subsection (a) of this section are in dispute, then the owner, keeper, harborer or possessor of the animal has the option of submitting within five working days, a written request to the municipal court clerk for a hearing and possible appeal. 
(1)  A hearing before the municipal judge shall be convened at the next regular municipal court docket not less than ten working days after receipt of a bona fide written appeal. The municipal court clerk shall notify the city prosecuting attorney and the owner, keeper, harborer or possessor of the animal of the date and time of the hearing. 
(2)  Pending the outcome of such a hearing and appeal, the animal shall be removed from the city. 
(3)  The hearing shall be informal and strict rules of evidence shall not apply. 
(4)  The municipal judge shall determine whether to declare the animal to be a dangerous or vicious animal based upon evidence and testimony presented at the time of the hearing by the owner, keeper, harborer or possessor of the animal in addition to witnesses, animal control personnel, police or any other persons possessing information pertinent to such determination. The owner, keeper, harborer or possessor of the animal, at such person's own personal expense, may be represented by counsel. 
(5)  The municipal judge shall issue a decision after the close of the hearing and notify the owner in writing of the decision. 
(6)  Any person aggrieved by the determination of the municipal judge may appeal the decision to the Circuit Court of Barton County pursuant to the provisions of RSMo ch. 536, provided, however, that any appeal must be filed within five working days of the date of the decision. 
(Code 1991, § 4-56; Ord. No. 1587, § 1, 7-27-2001; Ord. No. 1828 , § 1, 9-18-2017) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1828 , § 1, adopted Sept. 18, 2017, changed the title of § 6-148 from "Dangerous or vicious domestic animals enumerated; exceptions" to read as herein set out. 
Sec. 6-149. - Destruction of animals running at large.
