    If any fierce or dangerous animal annoys or endangers any person while running at large within the city or on the premises of any person other than the owner of the animal, it shall be lawful for a police officer or the animal control officer to kill the animal. 
(Code 1991, § 4-13; Ord. No. 1598, § 1, 5-20-2002) 
Secs. 6-150-6-153. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1828 , § 2, adopted Sept. 18, 2017, repealed §§ 6-150-6-153, which pertained to standards for keeping, transfer of ownership, restriction on offspring and presumption of dangerousness or viciousness and derived from Code 1991, §§ 4-58-4-61; and Ord. No. 1587, § 1, adopted July 27, 2001. 
Sec. 6-154. - Enforcement of article. 
    It is unlawful for the owner, keeper, harborer or possessor of a dangerous or vicious animal within the city to fail to comply with the provisions of this article. Any animal found to be the subject of a violation of this article shall be subject to immediate seizure and impoundment. In addition, failure to comply shall result in immediate removal of the animal from the city. 
(Code 1991, § 4-62; Ord. No. 1587, § 1, 7-27-2001) 
Sec. 6-155. - Penalty for violation. 
    Any person violating or permitting the violation of any provision of this article shall, upon conviction, be fined a sum not less than $250.00 and not more than $500.00. The court shall order the animal to be removed from the city. Should the defendant refuse to remove the animal from the city, the court shall find the defendant in contempt and order the immediate confiscation and impoundment of the animal. Each day that a violation of this article continues may be deemed a separate offense. In addition to the foregoing penalties, any person who violates any provision of this article shall pay all expenses, including, but not limited to, sums for shelter, food, handling, veterinary care and expert testimony, which may be necessitated by the person's failure to abide by the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1991, § 4-63; Ord. No. 1587, § 1, 7-27-2001) 
Chapter 8 - BUILDINGS AND CONSTRUCTION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Power of city to regulate the construction of buildings, RSMo 79.450(3); Underground Facility Safety and Damage Prevention Act, RSMo 319.010 et seq.; inadequate and deficient housing, RSMo 441.500 et seq.; construction materials standards, RSMo 701.010 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 8-1. - Materials of certain buildings to be fireproof. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person within the city to erect, reconstruct, remodel or maintain any building seating or accommodating more than 50 persons for any public gathering, where an admission fee is charged, unless such building is constructed of fireproof material. 
(Code 1971, § 8-40; Code 1991, § 8-47) 
State Law reference- Authority of city to require incombustible construction, RSMo 79.450(4). 
Sec. 8-2. - Flues, chimneys. 
(a)  All flues and chimneys constructed in the city shall be at least four inches in thickness, constructed of stone or brick, completely embedded in lime mortar, plastered on the inside with a smooth coat of the same, raised at least three feet above the roof by or through which it passes, and shall extend at least two feet below the ceiling. 
(b)  Holes for stove pipes shall have a sheet iron thimble, or a thimble of other fireproof material, inserted in the chimney or flue, embedded in lime mortar, and when not in use, shall have a tin or sheet iron stopper, with a flange at least one-inch wide, outside the brick or stone. 
(c)  It shall be the duty of the fire chief to inspect all flues and chimneys that he may deem dangerous to any building in the city. Upon complaint of any person that the flues or chimneys of any building are unsafe or dangerous, the fire chief shall immediately proceed to inspect such flues or chimneys, and if found to be in a dangerous condition, he shall give notice to the owner or occupant of such property and forbid their use until repaired or rebuilt, as may be directed by the fire chief. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for any person to use or cause to be used any flue or chimney that has been condemned by the fire chief, pursuant to subsection (c) of this section. 
(Code 1971, § 8-41; Code 1991, § 8-48) 
State Law reference- Authority of city to regulate construction, cleaning of chimneys, RSMo 79.450(3). 
Sec. 8-3. - Construction of barns. 
    No barn or other building for the storage of any hay or straw, whether baled or otherwise, shall be constructed within the city unless permission is first obtained therefor from the board of aldermen. No such permission shall be granted unless two-thirds of all the members elected to the board of aldermen shall vote therefor; provided, however, that no such permission shall be granted if the owner of any building or property located within 300 feet of the place where such barn or other building is proposed to be constructed shall object thereto and file such objection, in writing, with the board of aldermen prior to the granting of such permission; provided, further, that this section shall not be so construed as to prevent the construction of any barn or other such building wholly and entirely of fireproof materials. 
(Code 1971, § 8-42; Code 1991, § 8-49) 
State Law reference- Authority of city to regulate construction of buildings, RSMo 79.450(3). 
Secs. 8-4-8-18. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - CONSTRUCTION CODES 

Sec. 8-19. - Scope and applicability. 
    This article shall control all matters concerning the construction, alteration, addition, repair, removal, demolition, use, location, occupancy and maintenance of all buildings and structures and their service equipment as herein defined and shall apply to existing or proposed buildings and structures in the city; except as such matters as otherwise provided in this Code or by state law. 
(Code 1991, § 5-26; Ord. No. 1738, § 2(exh. A), 12-20-2010) 
Sec. 8-20. - International codes applicable. 
(a)  The provisions of the 2006 International Building Code shall apply to the construction, alteration, movement, enlargement, replacement, repair, equipment, use and occupancy, location, maintenance, removal and demolition of every building or structure or any appurtenances connected or attached to such buildings or structures; provided, however, that detached one- and two-family dwellings and multiple single-family dwellings (townhouses) not more than three stories above grade in height with a separate means of egress and their accessory structures shall comply with the 2006 International Residential Code. 
(b)  The provisions of the 2006 International Residential Code for one- and two-family dwellings shall apply to the construction, alteration, enlargement, replacement, repair, equipment, use and occupancy, location, removal and demolition of detached one- and two-family dwellings and townhouses not more than three stories above grade in height with a separate means of egress and their accessory structures. 
(Code 1991, § 5-27; Ord. No. 1738, § 2(exh. A), 12-20-2010) 
Sec. 8-21. - Purpose. 
    This article shall be construed to secure its expressed intent and ensure public safety, health and welfare insofar as they are affected by building construction, through structural strength, adequate egress facilities, sanitary equipment, light and ventilation and fire safety; and in general, to secure safety to life and property from all hazards incident to the design, erection, repair, removal, demolition or use and occupancy of buildings, structures or premises. 
(Code 1991, § 5-28; Ord. No. 1738, § 2(exh. A), 12-20-2010) 
Sec. 8-22. - Matter covered. 
    The provisions of this article shall apply to all buildings and their appurtenant constructions, including vaults, area and street projections, and accessory additions; and shall apply with equal force to municipal, county, state and private buildings; except where such buildings are otherwise specifically provided for by statute. 
(Code 1991, § 5-29; Ord. No. 1738, § 2(exh. A), 12-20-2010) 
Sec. 8-23. - Exemptions. 
    No building or structure shall be constructed, extended, repaired, removed or altered in violation of the provisions of this article, except for ordinary repairs as defined hereinafter, and except further that the raising or lowering or moving of a building or structure as a unit necessitated by a change in legal grade or widening of a street shall be permitted, provided the building is not otherwise altered or its use or occupancy changed. 
(Code 1991, § 5-30; Ord. No. 1738, § 2(exh. A), 12-20-2010) 
Sec. 8-24. - Zoning laws or statutes. 
    Except as may be specifically provided herein, no provisions of the existing zoning ordinance or other legal statutes pertaining to the location, use or construction of buildings shall be nullified by the provisions of this article, but in any case, the most rigid requirements shall control the construction, equipment of location of the building or structure. Whenever state statutes require the approval of special use group buildings, including among others, factories, school and multifamily dwellings, the approval of such authority shall accompany the application for a permit as may be required. 
(Code 1991, § 5-31; Ord. No. 1738, § 2(exh. A), 12-20-2010) 
Sec. 8-25. - Matters not provided. 
    Any requirement essential for structural, fire or sanitary safety of an existing or proposed building, or essential for the safety of the occupants thereof and which is not specifically covered by this article, shall be covered by the 2006 International Building Code or International Residential Code, as applicable. A copy of these publications may be obtained by writing to: International Code Council, 5203 Leesburg, Pike Suite 708, Falls Church, VA 22041-3401, or by calling (703) 931-4533. 
(Code 1991, § 5-32; Ord. No. 1738, § 2(exh. A), 12-20-2010) 
Sec. 8-26. - Ordinary repairs. 
    Ordinary repairs to buildings may be made without application or notice to the building official; but such repairs shall not include the cutting away of any wall, partition or portion thereof, the removal or cutting of any structural beam or bearing support, or the removal or change of any required means of egress, or rearrangement of parts of a structure to, alteration of, replacement or relocation of any standpipe, water supply, sewer, drainage, drain leader, gas, soil, waste, vent or similar piping, electric wiring or mechanical or other work affecting public health or general safety. 
(Code 1991, § 5-33; Ord. No. 1738, § 2(exh. A), 12-20-2010) 
Sec. 8-27. - Compliance. 
    Any repairs to buildings or structures contrary to the provisions set out in section 8-28 shall be deemed a violation and subject to the penalties prescribed for the violation of this article. 
(Code 1991, § 5-34; Ord. No. 1738, § 2(exh. A), 12-20-2010) 
Sec. 8-28. - Service equipment certificate of approval. 
    When the installation, extension, alteration or repair of an elevator, moving stairway, mechanical equipment, refrigerating, air conditioning or ventilating apparatus, plumbing, gas piping, electric wiring, heating system or any other equipment is specifically controlled by the provisions of this article or other approved rules, it shall be unlawful to use such equipment until a certificate of approval has been issued by the city. Installation of service equipment shall conform to applicable requirements of this article. 
(Code 1991, §§ 5-35, 5-36; Ord. No. 1738, § 2(exh. A), 12-20-2010) 
Sec. 8-29. - Maintenance required. 
    All buildings and structures and all parts thereof, both existing and new, shall be maintained in a safe and sanitary condition. All service equipment, means of egress, devices and safeguards which are required by a previous section of this article for the building when erected, altered or repaired, shall be maintained in good working order. 
(Code 1991, § 5-37; Ord. No. 1738, § 2(exh. A), 12-20-2010) 
Sec. 8-30. - Responsibility for maintenance. 
    The owner or his designated agent shall be responsible for the safe and sanitary maintenance of the building or structure and its exit facilities at all times. 
(Code 1991, § 5-38; Ord. No. 1738, § 2(exh. A), 12-20-2010) 
Sec. 8-31. - Alterations and repairs. 
    When an existing building is damaged by fire or other cause or if alterations and repairs are made to an extent of 50 percent or more of the physical value of the building before such damage or alteration, the entire building or structure shall be made to comply with the requirements of this article for new buildings. If the cost of such alterations or repairs is less than 50 percent of the physical value of the building, the building official shall determine to what degree the portions so altered or repaired shall be made to conform to the requirements of this article. For purposes of this section, the physical value of the building shall be based on the estimated current replacement cost or the complete replacement cost of the complete structure. 
(Code 1991, §§ 5-39, 5-40; Ord. No. 1738, § 2(exh. A), 12-20-2010) 
Sec. 8-32. - Use change. 
    It shall be unlawful to make any change in the use or occupancy of any structure which would subject it to any special provision of this article without approval of the building official and his certification that such structure meets the intent of the provisions of this article governing building construction for the proposed new use and occupancy and that such change does not result in any greater hazard to the public safety or welfare. 
(Code 1991, § 5-41; Ord. No. 1738, § 2(exh. A), 12-20-2010) 
Sec. 8-33. - Fire district. 
(a)  Defined. To control types of construction based on the inherent fire hazard of use groups of buildings, the city authority shall establish fire district limits to include all areas in which congested business, commercial and public assembly uses are housed. Such areas shall be designated as "within the fire limits" and shall be under the provisions of this article. The following is hereby declared to be the fire limits of the city: All that portion of the city embraced within the territory described and designated in this section shall constitute and be known as the fire limits of the city: All of Blocks 3, 4, 5, 11, 12, 13, 14, 15, 18, 19, 20, 21, 26, 27, 28, 29, 30, 34, 35, and 36 of the original Town of Lamar. 
(b)  Construction within fire district. All other areas not included within the fire limits shall be designated as "outside the fire limits." No building or frame construction shall be erected within or moved from outside to within the fire limits except those one- and two-family dwellings which shall conform to the intent and purpose of this article and temporary structures, including reviewing stands, construction sheds, canopies and similar temporary structures of frame construction for a certain specified period of time as approved by the building official. Roof covering of dwellings erected in the fire limits shall be asbestos, brick, concrete, metal, slate, tile, prepared asphalt or laminated felt roofing finished with asphalt, slag, gravel or similar noncombustive moisture-resistant materials or an approved combination of such materials. 
(c)  Incombustible or fire-resistant materials required. Every building erected or enlarged within the fire limits, except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, shall be enclosed on all sides with walls constructed of brick, stone, tile, concrete, concrete block or other equivalent incombustible materials and shall have the roof, tops and sides of all roof structures, including dormer windows, covered with incombustible or fire-resistant materials. All cornices shall be constructed of incombustible materials. Wooden fences shall not exceed six feet in height. Any proposed building or structure which is not specifically covered under the provisions of this article shall be determined by the building official. The building official may consult a competent authority in determining the intent and purpose of the article regarding such proposed building or structure. 
(Code 1991, §§ 5-43, 5-44, 5-45; Ord. No. 1738, § 2(exh. A), 12-20-2010) 
State Law reference- Authority of city to provide limits within which incombustible construction is required, RSMo 79.450(4). 
Sec. 8-34. - Fire stopping. 
    All classes of buildings shall be arranged to cut off all concealed draft openings, including floors, ceilings, roof and attic spaces, and shall form effectual fire barriers horizontally and vertically. 
(Code 1991, § 5-46; Ord. No. 1738, § 2(exh. A), 12-20-2010) 
Sec. 8-35. - Provisions supplementary, repealer. 
    All of the provisions and regulations of this article shall be deemed as a supplement to all other ordinances pertaining to the same subject matter. All other sections of any previous ordinance not in direct conflict with this article shall remain in full force and effect. 
(Code 1991, § 5-47; Ord. No. 1738, § 2(exh. A), 12-20-2010) 
Secs. 8-36-8-58. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - BUILDING PERMITS 

Sec. 8-59. - Application required. 
    It shall be unlawful to construct, enlarge, alter, remove or demolish, or change the occupancy of a building from one use to another requiring greater strength, exit or sanitary provisions; or to change to a prohibited use; or to install or alter any equipment for which provision is made or the installation of which is regulated by this article, without first filing an application with the building department and obtaining the required permit therefore; except that ordinary repairs as defined in this chapter that do not involve any violation of this article shall be exempt from this provision. 
(Code 1991, § 5-96; Ord. No. 1738, § 2(exh. A), 12-20-2010) 
Sec. 8-60. - By whom application made. 
    Application for a permit shall be made by the owner or lessee of the building or structure, or the agent of either, or by the licensed engineer or architect employed in connection with the proposed work. If the application is made by a person other than the owner, it shall be accompanied by a duly verified affidavit of the owner or the qualified person making the application that the proposed work is authorized by the owner and that the applicant is authorized to make such application. The full names and addresses of the owner, lessee, applicant and of the responsible officers, if the owner or lessee is a corporate body, shall be stated in the application. 
(Code 1991, § 5-97; Ord. No. 1738, § 2(exh. A), 12-20-2010) 
Sec. 8-61. - Description of work. 
    The application shall contain a general description of the proposed work, its location, the use and occupancy of all parts of the building or structure and of all portions of the site or lot not covered by the building and such additional information as may be required by the building official. 
(Code 1991, § 5-98; Ord. No. 1738, § 2(exh. A), 12-20-2010) 
Sec. 8-62. - Plans and specifications. 
    The application for the permit shall be accompanied by not less than two copies of specifications and of plans drawn to scale, with sufficient clarity and shall contain dimensions to show the nature and character of the work to be performed. When quality of materials is essential for conformity to this article, specific information shall be given to establish such quality; and in no case shall this article be cited or the term "legal" or its equivalent be used as a substitute for the specific information. The building official may waive the requirement for filing plans when the work involved is of a minor nature. 
(Code 1991, § 5-99; Ord. No. 1738, § 2(exh. A), 12-20-2010) 
Sec. 8-63. - Plot diagram. 
    There shall also be filed a plot plan showing to scale the size and location of all new construction and all existing structures on the site, distances from lot lines and the established street line, existing and proposed topography including finished floor elevation and existing elevations at lot corners and street; and it shall be drawn in accordance with an accurate boundary line survey. In the case of demolition, the plot plan shall show all construction to be demolished and the location and size of all existing buildings and constructions that are to remain on the site or plot. 
(Code 1991, § 5-100; Ord. No. 1738, § 2(exh. A), 12-20-2010) 
Sec. 8-64. - Engineering details. 
    The building official may require adequate details of structural, mechanical and electrical work including computations, stress diagrams and other essential technical data to be filed. All engineering plans and computations shall bear the signature of the engineer or architect responsible for the design. 
(Code 1991, § 5-101; Ord. No. 1738, § 2(exh. A), 12-20-2010) 
Sec. 8-65. - Application amendments. 
    Subject to the limitations of provisions of following sections, amendments to a plan, application or other records accompanying the same may be filed at any time before completion of the work for which the permit is sought or issued; and such amendments shall be deemed part of the original application and shall be filed therewith. 
(Code 1991, § 5-102; Ord. No. 1738, § 2(exh. A), 12-20-2010) 
Sec. 8-66. - Time limitation. 
    An application for a permit for any proposed work shall be deemed to have been abandoned six months after filing, unless such application has been diligently prosecuted or a permit has been issued; except that for reasonable cause, the building official may grant one or more extensions of time for additional periods not exceeding 90 days each. 
(Code 1991, § 5-103; Ord. No. 1738, § 2(exh. A), 12-20-2010) 
Sec. 8-67. - Service connections. 
    Before a building can be demolished or removed, the owner or agent shall notify all utilities having service connections within the building, such as water, electric, gas, sewer, and other connections. A permit to demolish or to remove a building shall not be issued until a release is obtained from the utility department, stating that their respective service connections and appurtenant equipment, such as meters and regulators, have been removed or sealed and plugged in a safe manner. 
(Code 1991, § 5-104; Ord. No. 1738, § 2(exh. A), 12-20-2010) 
Sec. 8-68. - Stop-work order. 
    Whenever the provisions of this article or of the plans and specifications approved thereunder are not complied with, a stop-work order shall be served on the owner or his representative and a copy thereof shall be posted at the site of construction. Such stop-work order shall not be removed except by written notice of the building official after satisfactory evidence has been supplied to him that the violation has been corrected. 
(Code 1991, § 5-105; Ord. No. 1738, § 2(exh. A), 12-20-2010) 
Sec. 8-69. - Building permit fees. 
(a)  Before receiving a building permit, the owner or the owner's agent shall pay the fees specified in the city's fee schedule which are based on total construction cost. For purposes of determining the applicable construction cost, the following values shall apply: 
Building Type Cost 
per square foot

Business (B) ..... 75.00 
Educational (E) ..... 75.00 
Factory (F-1, F-2) ..... 20.00 
High Hazard (H-1, H-2, H-3, H-4, H-5) ..... 20.00 
Institutional (I-1, I-2, I-3, I-4) ..... 75.00 
Mercantile (M) ..... 35.00 
Residential (R-1, R-2, R-3, R-4) ..... 65.00 
Storage (S-1, S-2) ..... 20.00 
Utility and Miscellaneous (U) ..... 10.00 
(b)  The fee for demolishing buildings may be waived if a "notice of condemnation" has not been issued. 
(Code 1991, § 5-106; Ord. No. 1738, § 2(exh. A), 12-20-2010) 
Sec. 8-70. - Application. 
    In applying the provisions of this article in respect to new work, existing buildings, alterations and repairs, the physical value of the work shall be determined by the building official on the basis of current costs of labor and materials. Whenever in the opinion of the building official, the estimated cost as submitted by the owner or the builder, is below reasonable estimation, he may determine the cost of the building permit by the cubic foot method. 
(Code 1991, § 5-107; Ord. No. 1738, § 2(exh. A), 12-20-2010) 
Sec. 8-71. - To whom fees paid. 
    All fees for building permits shall be paid to the city clerk, who shall issue a receipt in duplicate, giving the original copy to the owner or his agent and the carbon copy to the building official for his records. 
(Code 1991, § 5-108; Ord. No. 1738, § 2(exh. A), 12-20-2010) 
Secs. 8-72-8-100. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - STRUCTURE NUMBERING 

Sec. 8-101. - Policy. 
    There is hereby established a uniform system of numbering houses and buildings fronting on all streets, avenues and public ways in the city, and all houses and buildings shall be numbered in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1991, § 5-301; Ord. No. 1738, § 2(exh. A), 12-20-2010) 
Sec. 8-102. - Base lines. 
    First Street shall constitute the base line for numbering along all streets running north and south, and Broadway Street shall constitute the base line for numbering along all streets running east and west. 
(Code 1991, § 5-302; Ord. No. 1738, § 2(exh. A), 12-20-2010) 
Sec. 8-103. - Numbers determined-How. 
(a)  There shall be assigned 100 numbers to each block, square or space that would be one block or square, if streets each way were so extended as to intersect each other. 
(b)  Where blocks of different length occur on opposite sides of a street, the numbers on both sides shall be assigned on the basis of the shorter blocks, unless the building inspector shall otherwise determine. 
(Code 1991, § 5-303; Ord. No. 1738, § 2(exh. A), 12-20-2010) 
Sec. 8-104. - Same-Additionally. 
    All lots and houses on the south and west side of all streets shall be numbered with odd numbers, each commencing with the "hundred" assigned to that block. Where any building has more than one door serving a separate occupant, separate numbers shall be assigned. Buildings fronting on two or more streets shall have a number assigned only to the main entrance, unless other entrances serve different occupants. 
(Code 1991, § 5-304; Ord. No. 1738, § 2(exh. A), 12-20-2010) 
Sec. 8-105. - If not through street. 
    All streets not extending through to the base line shall be assigned the same relative numbers as if the said street had extended to the said base line. 
(Code 1991, § 5-305; Ord. No. 1738, § 2(exh. A), 12-20-2010) 
Sec. 8-106. - Number to be displayed. 
(a)  Each house and building shall be assigned its respective number or numbers and the owner, occupant or agent shall place or cause to be placed upon each house or building controlled by him, the number or numbers and the owner, occupant or agent shall place or cause to be placed upon each house or building controlled by him, the number or numbers assigned. 
(b)  Such number or numbers shall be placed within 20 days after notification is made upon the owner, occupant or agent. The cost of the number or numbers shall be paid for by the property owner, occupant or agent. Replacements of numbers shall be procured and paid for by the owner, occupant or agent. The numbers used shall be not less than four inches in height. 
(c)  The numbers shall be placed conspicuously above, on or at the side of the proper door of each building, or above the garage of a residence, or upon a lamppost in the front yard of a residence, so that the number can be seen plainly from the street. Whenever any building is situated more than 50 feet from the street line, the number of each such building shall be conspicuously displayed at the street line, near the walk, drive way or common entrance to such building and upon the gate post, fence, post or other appropriate place so as to be easily discernible from the sidewalk. 
(d)  Address numbers displayed using letters (e.g., "Two Hundred"), as opposed to numbers (e.g., "200"), when numbers are not otherwise displayed in compliance with this section, do not comply with the requirements of this article, except, buildings with address numbers displayed using letters and not numbers as of August 16, 2004, for as long as such address is displayed in such manner, shall be deemed to be in compliance with this section. 
(Code 1991, § 5-306; Ord. No. 1738, § 2(exh. A), 12-20-2010) 
Sec. 8-107. - Apartments. 
    Where only one number can be assigned to any house or building, the owner, occupant or agent of such house or building who shall desire distinctive numbers for the upper and lower portion of any such house or building, or for any part of such house or building, fronting on any street, such owner, occupant or agent shall use the suffix "A," "B," "C," etc., as may be required. 
(Code 1991, § 5-307; Ord. No. 1738, § 2(exh. A), 12-20-2010) 
Sec. 8-108. - Building inspector to assist, others may assist if building inspector unable. 
    It shall be the duty of the building inspector to inform any party applying therefor, of the number or numbers belonging or embraced within the limits of said lot or property as provided and assigned to any lot or building; the building inspector shall determine the number of such lot or building. Whenever the building inspector is unavailable or unable to assist or perform the duties prescribed under this article, the city clerk or any assistant city clerk shall perform the same. 
(Code 1991, § 5-308; Ord. No. 1738, § 2(exh. A), 12-20-2010) 
Sec. 8-109. - New construction. 
    Whenever any house, building or structure shall be erected or located in the city, in order to preserve continuity and uniformity it is the duty of the owner to procure the correct number or numbers as designated from the building inspector for the said property and to immediately fasten the said number or numbers so assigned upon said building as provided by this article. No building permit shall be issued for any house, building or structure until the owner has procured from the building inspector the official number of the premises. 
(Code 1991, § 5-309; Ord. No. 1738, § 2(exh. A), 12-20-2010) 
Sec. 8-110. - Notice of violation. 
    If the owner or occupant of any building required to be numbered by this article shall neglect for the period of 20 days to duly attach and maintain the proper number on such building, a city police officer shall serve upon him a notice requiring such owner or occupant to properly number the same, and if he neglects to do so for ten days after the service of such notice, such person shall be deemed to have violated this article. If notice cannot be personally delivered by a police officer, then the city clerk shall cause such notice to be made upon the owner or occupant by certified mail, return receipt requested, addressed to the last known address of said owner or occupant, and such notice shall be deemed to have been given upon depositing the same, postage prepaid, at the post office. Upon conviction thereof such person shall be fined not less than $1.00, nor more than $10.00, together with the costs of prosecution and in default of payment of such forfeiture and costs of prosecution shall be imprisoned in the county jail until such fine and costs are paid, but not to exceed 30 days for each violation. Each day that a violation continues to exist shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1991, § 5-310; Ord. No. 1738, § 2(exh. A), 12-20-2010) 
Secs. 8-111-8-133. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - DANGEROUS STRUCTURES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Authority of city to remove or abate certain buildings or structures, §§ 67.400 et seq., 79.450(4). 

Sec. 8-134. - Conditions declared nuisances. 
    The following conditions, when present in buildings or structures located within the city, have been determined to be detrimental to the health, safety and/or welfare of the residents of the city and therefore constitute a nuisance: 
(1)  Those whose interior walls or other vertical structural members list, lean or buckle to such an extent that a plumb line passing through the center of gravity of any such wall or vertical structural members falls outside of the middle third of its base. 
(2)  Those which, exclusive of the foundation, show 33 percent or more of damage or deterioration of the supporting member or members, or 50 percent of damage or deterioration of the nonsupporting enclosing or outside walls or covering. 
(3)  Those that have improperly distributed loads upon the floors, roofs or other horizontal structural members, or in which the same are overloaded or that have insufficient strength or deflections to be reasonably safe for the purpose used or intended to be used. 
(4)  Those that have been damaged by fire, wind or other causes so as to have become dangerous to life, safety or the general health and welfare of the occupants or the people of the city. 
(5)  Those that are uninhabited and are open at door, window, wall or roof. 
(6)  Those under construction upon which no substantial work shall have been performed for 120 days. 
(7)  Those in the process of demolition upon which no substantial work shall have been performed under section 8-138. 
(8)  Those containing therein substantial accumulations of trash, garbage or other materials susceptible to fire, or constituting or providing a harboring place for vermin or other obnoxious animals or insects or in any way threatening the health of the occupants thereof or the health of persons in the vicinity thereof. 
(9)  Those having inadequate facilities for egress in case of fire or panic. 
(10)  Those that have parts thereof that are so attached or deteriorated that they may fall upon public ways or upon the property of others or may injure members of the public or the occupants thereof. 
(11)  Those buildings built in violation of any safety provision of the building code, electrical code, plumbing code, mechanical code, minimum housing standards code or the fire prevention code of the city or used in violation thereof. 
(Code 1991, § 5-241; Ord. No. 1738, § 2(exh. A), 12-20-2010) 
Sec. 8-135. - Standards for enforcement. 
    The following standards shall be followed in substance by the building inspector, city administrator and board of aldermen in ordering repair, maintenance, vacation, demolition and removal or completion: 
(1)  If the dangerous building can reasonably be repaired or maintained so that it will no longer exist in violation of the terms of this article, it shall be ordered so repaired or maintained. 
(2)  If the dangerous building is in such condition as to make it dangerous to the health, safety or welfare of its occupants, it shall be ordered to be vacated pending abatement of the nuisance. 
(3)  In any case where the dangerous building cannot be reasonably repaired or maintained so that the building or structure will no longer exist in violation of the terms of this article, the building or structure shall be ordered repaired or demolished and removed. 
(4)  If the conditions constituting the public nuisance are such that the costs to repair or maintain the building or structure so that it will no longer constitute a public nuisance equal or exceed 50 percent of the value of the building or structure, it shall be ordered repaired or demolished and removed, and in the event it is not repaired or demolished and removed by the owner, then the city shall abate the nuisance by demolition and removal. 
(5)  Any building or structure constituting a public nuisance because of the conditions described in section 8-134(6) shall be ordered to be completed and if it shall not be so completed or demolished and removed by the owner, then the city shall abate the nuisance by demolition and removal. 
(6)  Any building or structure found to be a public nuisance because of the conditions described in section 8-134(7) shall be ordered demolished and removed. 
(Code 1991, § 5-242; Ord. No. 1738, § 2(exh. A), 12-20-2010) 
Sec. 8-136. - Inspections, notice of violation. 
(a)  The building inspector shall: 
(1)  Inspect any building or structure about which complaints are filed by any person alleging that the building or structure contains any of the conditions described in section 8-134. 
(2)  Inspect any building or structure reported by the fire or police department of the city when that department has reason to believe that the building or structure has any of the conditions set forth in section 8-134. 
(3)  Inspect any building or structure of the city at any time whenever there is reason to believe that the building or structure has a condition described in section 8-134. 
(b)  Where the inspection shows that a building or structure has any of the conditions in section 8-134, the building inspector shall notify the city administrator. If the city administrator concurs, the building inspector shall: 
(1)  Post a notice of violation on the building or structure at a conspicuous location, which reads substantially as follows: 
"This building has been found to be a public nuisance by the city administrator of the City of Lamar. [It also reasonably appears that this building or structure is an immediate danger to the health, safety or welfare of persons thereabout or therein.] This notice is to remain on this building or structure until it is brought into compliance with the ordinance of the City of Lamar, Missouri. It is unlawful to remove this notice until such compliance has occurred." 
The language of said notice contained in brackets is option and should only be used when applicable. 
(2)  Notify the owner, occupant, lessee, mortgagee, agent and all other persons having an interest in the building or structure as shown by the land records of the recorder of deeds for the county, at least ten days prior to a hearing before the board of aldermen, that such building or structure has been found to be a public nuisance under the provisions of this article. Said notification shall be provided to such person or persons by certified mail, return receipt requested, addressed to the last known address of such persons, or by personal service, but if notification cannot be made in such manner, then the full text of said notification shall be published in a general circulation newspaper published within the county once a week for three consecutive weeks, on the same day of each week, the last insertion of which shall be at least ten days prior to the hearing by the board of aldermen. If notification is by certified mail, it shall be deemed to have been delivered on the date of mailing. Said notification shall set forth a description of the conditions found in the building or structure so as to constitute the building or structure as a public nuisance under section 8-134, and it shall state the date of the hearing by the board of aldermen. 
(3)  Prepare a report for a hearing at the meeting of the board of aldermen, stating the address of the building or structure, the owner's name and address and the code violations. 
(Code 1991, § 5-243; Ord. No. 1738, § 2(exh. A), 12-20-2010) 
Sec. 8-137. - Hearing. 
(a)  Not less than ten days after notification is made by the building inspector pursuant to section 8-136(b)(2), the board of aldermen shall call and have a full and adequate hearing upon the matter. Any party may be represented by counsel and all parties shall have an opportunity to be heard. The board of aldermen shall determine: 
(1)  Whether the building or structure involved is a public nuisance under the terms of this article or detrimental to the health, safety or welfare of the residents or the city; and 
(2)  Whether the procedures required by this article have been substantially followed. 
(b)  If at the hearing the board of aldermen determines that a public nuisance does not exist or that the condition of the building or structure is not detrimental to the health, safety or welfare of the residents of the city, then the building inspector shall remove the notice of violation from the building or structure and notify the person or persons previously notified pursuant to section 8-136(b)(2) of the removal of said notice. 
(c)  If at the hearing the board of aldermen determines that the procedures of this article were not substantially followed, then the building inspector shall follow the procedures of section 8-136 to reinitiate the notice of violation. 
(d)  If at the hearing the board of aldermen determines that a public nuisance does exist or that the condition of the building or structure is detrimental to the health, safety or welfare of the residents of the city, and that the procedures of this article were substantially followed, then: 
(1)  The board of aldermen shall issue an order making specific findings of fact, based upon competent and substantial evidence, which shows the building or structure to be a nuisance and/or detrimental to the health, safety or welfare of the residents of the city and ordering work to be performed consistent with the provision of section 8-135, which order shall be signed by a person designated by the board of aldermen; and 
(2)  The building inspector shall issue an order of compliance as provided for in section 8-138. 
(Code 1991, § 5-244; Ord. No. 1738, § 2(exh. A), 12-20-2010) 
Sec. 8-138. - Order of compliance. 
(a)  An order of compliance shall: 
(1)  Be issued by the building inspector following a hearing by the board of aldermen after an order is made pursuant to section 8-137(d)(1); 
(2)  Be delivered to the person or persons previously notified pursuant to section 8-136(b)(2) by certified mail, return receipt requested, addressed to the last known address of such persons, or by personal service, but if the order cannot be delivered in such manner, then it shall be posted on the building or structure at a conspicuous location; delivery of said order shall be deemed to have been given as of the date of mailing, or the date of personal service, or the date of posting, as the case may be; 
(3)  State that such person or persons shall begin work consistent with the order made pursuant to section 8-137(d)(1) upon the building or structure within 30 days of delivery of the order of compliance, and shall further state that said work shall be completed within 120 days of delivery of the order of compliance; 
(4)  Have attached thereto a copy of the order made pursuant to section 8-137(d)(1). 
(b)  Completion of the work described in the order of compliance shall be completed within 120 days of its delivery. 
(c)  The building inspector shall inspect the work described in the order of compliance upon completion to determine compliance therewith and notify the person or persons to whom the order of compliance was directed of compliance status. 
(d)  Upon failure of the person or persons to whom the order of compliance was directed to comply with said order within the time specified, the city may elect to complete the work described in the order of compliance, with city employees recording the time of each employee and the equipment used. 
(e)  The total cost incurred by the city to complete the work described in the order of compliance shall be presented to the city clerk. 
(f)  In lieu of completing the work described in the order of compliance itself, the city may elect to contract for said work upon the building or structure. If this election is made, then said work shall be bid and the bids shall be presented to the board of aldermen for selection of a contractor. After the contractor completes the work, the total cost shall be presented to city clerk. 
(Code 1991, § 5-245; Ord. No. 1738, § 2(exh. A), 12-20-2010) 
Sec. 8-139. - Certification of cost of abatement, lien, payment. 
(a)  Whenever the city shall have caused the work to be done as provided by section 8-138, the city administrator shall certify the costs of the work to the city clerk who shall cause a special tax bill therefore to be issued against the lot, tract or parcel of land upon which the building or structure is located. The special tax bill from the date of its issuance shall be deemed a personal debt against the property owner, and in addition shall be a lien on the lot, tract or parcel of land until paid and shall be registered in the office of the city clerk or other official designated by the board of aldermen in a book to be kept by him for such purposes. The tax bill shall be collected by the official designated by the city for the collection of taxes. 
(b)  Within 30 days of the issuance of the tax bill and at the written request of the taxpayer delivered to the city clerk, a tax bill for the work described in the order of compliance upon a building or structure may be paid in ten equal annual installments, which installments with interest thereon to date on the unpaid balance shall be due annually on the anniversary of the date of issuance of the bill. Interest shall be paid at the maximum rate per annum allowable by law on the unpaid balance of the special tax bill or assessment computed from the date of issuance. If any annual payment of principal or interest shall not be paid within 30 days of its due date, the entire remaining balance of the tax bill shall immediately become due and payable. 
(c)  If request for ten annual payments is not made, the tax bill shall be payable in 60 days from its date of issuance with interest thereon at the maximum rate per annum allowable by law. 
(Code 1991, § 5-246; Ord. No. 1738, § 2(exh. A), 12-20-2010) 
Sec. 8-140. - Collection, insurance proceeds. 
(a)  Tax bills issued under section 8-139 shall be prima facie evidence of the validity of the bill, the doing of the work and the liability of the property for the damages stated in the bill and shall be collected if default should occur by suit brought in a court of competent jurisdiction by the city attorney on behalf of the city. Judgment in any such suit shall be special and against the property only and shall be satisfied by sale of the property or so much thereof as is necessary to satisfy the judgment and the costs of the sale. 
(b)  If there are proceeds of any insurance policy based upon a covered claim payment made for damage or loss to a building or other structure caused by or arising out of any fire, explosion, or other casualty loss, and if the covered claim payment is in excess of 50 percent of the face value of the policy covering a building or other structure, the following procedure shall apply: 
(1)  The insurer shall withhold from the covered claim payment 25 percent of the covered claim payment, and shall pay that amount to the city to deposit into an interest-bearing account. Any named mortgagee on the insurance policy shall maintain priority over any obligation under this section. If a special tax bill or assessment is issued by the city for the expenses of the work described in the order of compliance upon such building as a dangerous building, the moneys held by the city shall be applied toward payment of special tax bill or assessment. If there is an excess, it shall be paid by the city to the insured or as the terms of the policy, including any endorsements thereto, provide. 
(2)  The city shall release the proceeds and any interest which has accrued on such proceeds received under subsection (b)(1) of this section to the insured or as the terms of the policy and endorsements thereto provide within 30 days after receipt of such insurance moneys, unless the city has instituted legal proceedings under the provisions of sections 8-138 and 8-139. If the city has proceeded under the provisions of sections 8-138 and 8-139, all moneys in excess of that necessary to comply with the provisions of sections 8-138 and 8-139 for the demolition and removal, or repair, of the building or structure, less salvage value, shall be paid to the insured. 
(3)  The city may certify that, in lieu of payment of all or part of the covered claim payment under this section, it has obtained satisfactory proof that the insured has or will remove debris and repair, rebuild or otherwise make the premises safe and secure. In this event the city shall issue a certificate within 30 days after receipt of proof to permit covered claim payment to the insured without deduction. It shall be the obligation of the insured or other person making the claim to provide the insurance company with the written certificate provided for in this subsection. 
(4)  No provision of this section shall be construed to make the city a party to any insurance contract. 
(Code 1991, § 5-247; Ord. No. 1738, § 2(exh. A), 12-20-2010) 
Sec. 8-141. - Appeal from order. 
    Any owner, occupant, lessee, mortgagee, agent or other person having an interest in the building or structure may appeal from the order made under the provision of section 8-137(d)(1). The appeal shall be to the circuit court of the county as provided in RSMo ch. 536. 
(Code 1991, § 5-248; Ord. No. 1738, § 2(exh. A), 12-20-2010) 
Sec. 8-142. - Emergency measures authorized. 
    In all cases where it reasonably appears that an immediate danger to the health, safety or welfare of any person exists, the city may take emergency measures to vacate, repair, demolish or remove a building or structure which is a public nuisance under the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1991, § 5-249; Ord. No. 1738, § 2(exh. A), 12-20-2010) 
Sec. 8-143. - Liability for enforcement. 
    No officer, agent or employee of the city shall be personally liable for any damage that may occur to any persons or property as a result of any act required of the officer, agent or employee or permitted to be taken by the officer, agent or employee under the terms of this article. Any suit brought against any such officer, agent or employee of the city as a result of any such acts required or permitted shall be defended by the city until the final determination of the proceedings, and if judgment shall be obtained it shall be paid by the city. It is hereby further declared that no officer, agent or employee of the city owes any duty under the provisions of this article to any citizen or other individual but that the duties prescribed herein and imposed upon officers, agents or employees of the city are duties to be performed for the government of the city. 
(Code 1991, § 5-250; Ord. No. 1738, § 2(exh. A), 12-20-2010) 
Sec. 8-144. - Violations, penalty. 
(a)  The owner, occupant or lessee in possession of any building or structure who shall fail to comply with either the order made pursuant to section 8-137(d)(1), or the order of compliance issued by the building inspector pursuant to section 8-138, or any such person who shall fail to proceed continuously without unnecessary delay, or any person removing any posted notice or order provided for in this article, or any person violating any other provision of this article, shall be guilty of an ordinance violation and upon conviction thereof shall be punished as follows: 
(1)  An owner of the property who is not a resident of the property upon which the building or structure is located shall be punished by a fine not to exceed $2,000.00 or by imprisonment in the county jail for not more than 90 days, or by both such fine and imprisonment. 
(2)  Any other person shall be punished by a fine not to exceed $1,000.00 or by imprisonment in the county jail for not more than 90 days, or by both such fine and imprisonment. 
(b)  Each day of violation shall be deemed a separate offense. 
(Code 1991, § 5-251; Ord. No. 1738, § 2(exh. A), 12-20-2010) 
Secs. 8-145-8-171. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - CONTRACTOR LICENSING 

Sec. 8-172. - License required. 
    No person shall engage in business as a general contractor or specialty contractor without a license issued by the city. 
(Code 1991, § 5-280; Ord. No. 1738, § 2(exh. A), 12-20-2010) 
Sec. 8-173. - Definition. 
(a)  The term "contractor," as used in this article, shall mean any person, including any and all building crafts and enterprises, who shall engage in the business of building, erecting, repairing, remodeling and otherwise constructing or reconstructing houses, buildings and other structures or any part thereof. The term "contractor" shall also include specialty contractors or subcontractors who shall contract to construct or do the following: Roofing repairs or installation; painting; sewer or water construction; curb and gutter construction; pavement construction and or sealing; sheet rock installation and or finishing; insulation installation; pest inspection and/or control; flooring or other construction work of a specialized nature; or work performed by contract under the contract of a general contractor or builder. 
(b)  Any person who shall build not more than one house or one residential out-building in any one calendar year for occupancy by the person as his residence shall not be classified as a contractor under this article and shall not be required to obtain a license as such. 
(Code 1991, § 5-281; Ord. No. 1738, § 2(exh. A), 12-20-2010) 
Sec. 8-174. - Revocation of building permits and license. 
    Failure of any contractor to comply with any of the provisions of this article, misuse of this article or any other city ordinance, shall be cause for revocation of his license or the building permit issued to him. The building inspector shall give five days' notice to the contractor of the violations before revoking any license or permit. The contractor may be entitled to a hearing by the board of aldermen enumerating him to the charge against him. 
(Code 1991, § 5-282; Ord. No. 1738, § 2(exh. A), 12-20-2010) 
Sec. 8-175. - License prerequisite to issuance of building permits. 
    No building permit shall be issued by the building inspector to any contractor for the construction, erection or remodeling of any house, building or other structure or any part thereof until such contractor shall have first obtained the license and paid the license fee required in this article. 
(Code 1991, § 5-283; Ord. No. 1738, § 2(exh. A), 12-20-2010) 
Sec. 8-176. - License fee. 
    An annual license fee as provided in the city fee schedule shall be due and payable to the city on January 1 of each year or prior to engaging in any work. Contractors working without a license will be subject to a late fee in addition to the annual fee as provided in the city fee schedule. 
(Code 1991, § 5-284; Ord. No. 1738, § 2(exh. A), 12-20-2010) 
Sec. 8-177. - Term. 
    Licenses required by this article expire at the end of the calendar year for which they were issued, and they may be renewed upon payment of fees in the amount provided. Expired licenses may be renewed at any time upon payment of a penalty of $20.00 and compliance with the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1991, § 5-285; Ord. No. 1738, § 2(exh. A), 12-20-2010) 
Sec. 8-178. - Insurance. 
    Before any person is granted a license under this article, such person shall file a certificate of insurance with the city certifying general liability insurance in the amount of $100,000.00 minimum for each occurrence. Each person granted a license shall also comply with state workers' compensation laws, if, under state law, he is required to carry such insurance. 
(Code 1991, § 5-286; Ord. No. 1738, § 2(exh. A), 12-20-2010) 
Secs. 8-179-8-209. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT 

Sec. 8-210. - Department of building inspection. 
    The department of building inspection is hereby created and the executive official of the department shall be known as the building inspector or building official. 
(Code 1991, § 5-62; Ord. No. 1738, § 2(exh. A), 12-20-2010) 
Sec. 8-211. - Appointment of building inspector. 
    The building inspector shall be appointed by the mayor and he shall not be removed from office except for cause and after full opportunity has been granted him to be heard on specific and relevant charges by and before the mayor. 
(Code 1991, § 5-63; Ord. No. 1738, § 2(exh. A), 12-20-2010) 
Sec. 8-212. - Organization. 
    The building inspector shall have such number of officers, technical assistants, inspectors and other employees as shall be necessary for the administration of this article and as authorized by the mayor. 
(Code 1991, § 5-64; Ord. No. 1738, § 2(exh. A), 12-20-2010) 
Sec. 8-213. - Deputy inspector. 
    The building inspector may designate an employee as his deputy who shall exercise all the powers of the building inspector during the temporary absence of disability of the building inspector. 
(Code 1991, § 5-65; Ord. No. 1738, § 2(exh. A), 12-20-2010) 
Sec. 8-214. - Employee restrictions. 
    No official or employee connected with the department of building inspection, except one whose only connection is that of a member of the board of survey or of the board of appeals, shall be engaged directly or indirectly with the furnishing of labor, materials or appliances for the construction, alteration or maintenance of a building, or the preparation of plans or specifications therefore, unless he is the owner of the building; nor shall such officer or employee engage in any work which conflicts with his official duties or the interests of the department. 
(Code 1991, § 5-66; Ord. No. 1738, § 2(exh. A), 12-20-2010) 
Sec. 8-215. - Responsibility. 
    The building inspector, officer or employee charged with the enforcement of this article, while acting for the city, shall not thereby render himself liable personally and he is hereby relieved from all personal liability for any damage that may accrue to persons or property as a result of any act required or permitted in the discharge of his duties and under the provisions of this article he shall be defended by the legal representative of the city until the final termination of the proceedings. In no case shall the building inspector or any of his subordinates be liable for costs in any action, suit or proceeding that may be instituted in pursuance of the provisions of this article; and any officer of the building department, while acting in good faith and without malice, shall be free from liability for acts performed under any of the provisions of this article or by reason of any act or omission in the performance of his official duties in connection therewith. 
(Code 1991, § 5-67; Ord. No. 1738, § 2(exh. A), 12-20-2010) 
Sec. 8-216. - Records of business and activities. 
    An official record shall be kept of all business and activities of the building department specified in the provisions of this article and such records shall be open to public inspection at any appropriate and reasonable times. 
(Code 1991, § 5-68; Ord. No. 1738, § 2(exh. A), 12-20-2010) 
Sec. 8-217. - Powers and duties. 
    The building inspector shall enforce all of the provisions of this article and shall act on any questions relative to the mode or manner of construction and the materials to be used in the erection, addition to, alteration, repair, demolition, installation of service equipment, the location, use, occupancy and maintenance of all buildings and structures, except as may be otherwise specifically provided for by statutory requirements or as herein provided. 
(Code 1991, § 5-69; Ord. No. 1738, § 2(exh. A), 12-20-2010) 
Sec. 8-218. - Applications and permits. 
    The building inspector shall receive applications and issue permits for the erection and alteration of buildings and structures, and examine the premises for which such permits have been issued and to enforce compliance with the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1991, § 5-70; Ord. No. 1738, § 2(exh. A), 12-20-2010) 
Sec. 8-219. - Notices and orders. 
    The building inspector shall issue all necessary notices or orders to remove illegal or unsafe conditions, to require the necessary safeguards during construction, to require adequate exit facilities in existing buildings and structures and to ensure compliance with all of the requirements of this article for the safety, health and general welfare of the public. 
(Code 1991, § 5-71; Ord. No. 1738, § 2(exh. A), 12-20-2010) 
Sec. 8-220. - Inspections. 
    The building inspector shall make all the required inspections, or he may accept reports of inspection of authoritative and recognized services or individuals. All reports of such inspections shall be in writing and certified by a responsible officer of such authoritative service or by the responsible individual, or he may engage such expert opinion as he may deem necessary to report upon unusual technical issues that may arise, subject to the approval of the mayor. 
(Code 1991, § 5-72; Ord. No. 1738, § 2(exh. A), 12-20-2010) 
Sec. 8-221. - Research. 
    The building inspector shall make or cause to be made, investigations of new developments in the building industry. He shall accredit tests meeting the functional requirements of this article conducted by accredited authoritative agencies or he may accept duly authenticated reports from recognized authoritative sources of all new materials and methods of construction proposed for use which are not specifically provided in this article. The costs of all tests or other investigations required under these provisions shall be paid by the applicant. 
(Code 1991, § 5-73; Ord. No. 1738, § 2(exh. A), 12-20-2010) 
Sec. 8-222. - New rules. 
    The building inspector shall promulgate rules under the procedures provided in section 8-225, establishing the conditions for use of new materials consistent with the provisions of this article and with minimum requirements based on accepted engineering practices. 
(Code 1991, § 5-74; Ord. No. 1738, § 2(exh. A), 12-20-2010) 
Sec. 8-223. - Records of applications, permits, etc. 
    The building inspector shall keep official records of applications received, permits and certificates issued, fees collected, reports of inspections and notices and orders issued. File copies of all papers in connection with building operations shall be retained in the official records so long as the building or structure to which they relate remains in existence. 
(Code 1991, § 5-75; Ord. No. 1738, § 2(exh. A), 12-20-2010) 
Sec. 8-224. - Annual report. 
    At least annually, the building inspector shall submit to the chief appointing authority of the city, a written statement of all permits and certificates issued, orders promulgated and materials approved. 
(Code 1991, § 5-76; Ord. No. 1738, § 2(exh. A), 12-20-2010) 
Sec. 8-225. - Rulemaking authority. 
    The building inspector shall have power as may be necessary in the interest of the public safety, health and general welfare, to adopt and promulgate rules and regulations, to interpret and implement the provisions of this article and to secure the intent and purpose thereof; but, no such rules shall have the effect of waiving working stresses or of fire-resistive requirements specifically provided in this article or of violating accepted engineering practice involving public safety. 
(Code 1991, § 5-77; Ord. No. 1738, § 2(exh. A), 12-20-2010) 
Sec. 8-226. - Amendment of rules. 
    All rules adopted by the procedure herein established shall have the same effect as the provisions of this article. Such rules may be amended or repealed at any time by the same procedure herein prescribed for their adoption. 
(Code 1991, § 5-78; Ord. No. 1738, § 2(exh. A), 12-20-2010) 
Sec. 8-227. - Effective date of rules. 
    No rule or regulation shall become effective until four weeks after the intention to adopt such rules shall have been published in accordance with local statutes in an official paper or public newspaper with general circulation in the city and only after a public hearing shall have been held on the rule. 
(Code 1991, § 5-79; Ord. No. 1738, § 2(exh. A), 12-20-2010) 
Sec. 8-228. - Modifications authorized; application. 
(a)  When there are practical difficulties involved in carrying out structural or mechanical provisions of this article or of an approved rule, the building official may vary or modify such provisions upon application of the owner or his representative, provided that the spirit and intent of this article shall be observed and public welfare and safety be assured. 
(b)  The application for modification and the final decision of the building official shall be in writing and shall be officially recorded in the application for the permit in the permanent records of the department of building inspection. 
(Code 1991, §§ 5-80, 5-81; Ord. No. 1738, § 2(exh. A), 12-20-2010) 
Sec. 8-229. - Preliminary inspection. 
    Before issuing a permit, the building official shall examine or cause to be examined, all buildings, structures and sites for which an application has been filed for a permit to construct, enlarge, alter, repair, remove, demolish or change the use thereof; and he shall conduct such inspection from time to time during and on completion of the work for which he has issued a permit; and he shall maintain a record of all such examinations and inspections and of all violations of this article. 
(Code 1991, § 5-82; Ord. No. 1738, § 2(exh. A), 12-20-2010) 
Sec. 8-230. - Final inspection. 
    Upon completion of the building or structure and before issuance of the certificate of use and occupancy required in this article, a final inspection shall be made and all violations of the approved plans and permit shall be noted and the holder of the permit shall be notified of the discrepancies. 
(Code 1991, § 5-83; Ord. No. 1738, § 2(exh. A), 12-20-2010) 
Sec. 8-231. - Right of entry. 
    In the discharge of his duties, the building official or his authorized representative shall have the authority to enter, at any reasonable hour, any building, structure or premises in the city to enforce the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1991, § 5-84; Ord. No. 1738, § 2(exh. A), 12-20-2010) 
Sec. 8-232. - Official badge. 
    The building inspector may adopt a badge of office for himself and his assistants which shall be displayed for the purpose of identification. 
(Code 1991, § 5-85; Ord. No. 1738, § 2(exh. A), 12-20-2010) 
Sec. 8-233. - Cooperation of other city departments and officials. 
    The assistance and cooperation of the police, fire and health departments and all other city officials shall be available to the building inspector as required in the performance of his duties. 
(Code 1991, § 5-86; Ord. No. 1738, § 2(exh. A), 12-20-2010) 
Sec. 8-234. - Appeal to board of aldermen. 
    An owner, lessee, agent, operator or occupant aggrieved by any order issued pursuant to this article, may file an appeal to the board of aldermen within ten days from the service of such order and the board of aldermen shall set a time and place not less than five days, nor more than ten days thereafter, as to when and where such appeal may be heard by the board of aldermen. Such appeal shall stay the execution of such order until such time as it has been heard and revised, confirmed or rescinded. The board of aldermen shall at a hearing of an appeal, affirm, modify, revoke or direct that such order be withdrawn. Unless revoked or vacated, such order shall then be complied with. 
(Code 1991, § 5-216; Ord. No. 1738, § 2(exh. A), 12-20-2010) 
Sec. 8-235. - Court appeals. 
    Nothing contained in this article shall be deemed to deny the right of any person to appeal from an order from the provisions contained herein or a decision of the board of aldermen to a court of competent jurisdiction. Such appeals shall stay the execution of any order until it has been heard, reviewed, rescinded or confirmed. 
(Code 1991, § 5-217; Ord. No. 1738, § 2(exh. A), 12-20-2010) 
Sec. 8-236. - Penalties. 
    The owner or agent of any building, structure or premises where a violation of any provision or regulation of this article has been committed or shall exist, or the lessee or tenant of an entire building or premises where such violation has been committed or shall exist, or the general agent, architect, builder, contractor or any other person who commits, takes part in or assists in any such violation shall be guilty of a misdemeanor which shall be punishable by a fine of not less than $10.00, nor more than $500.00 for each and every day that such violation continues and if the violation is willful with conviction thereof, the punishment shall be a fine of not less than $100.00 for each and every day that such violation shall continue or by imprisonment for ten days for each and every day that such violation shall continue or by both fine and imprisonment in the discretion of the court. Any person who, having been served with an order to remove any violation, shall fail to comply with such order from which no appeal has been taken within ten days after such service, or shall continue to violate any provision under this article in respect named in such order, shall also be subject to a civil penalty of $250.00. 
(Code 1991, § 5-218; Ord. No. 1738, § 2(exh. A), 12-20-2010) 
Secs. 8-237-8-280. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - MINIMUM PLUMBING STANDARDS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 8-281. - Standards not covered. 
    For standards not covered by this article, the 2006 editions of the International Plumbing Code, International Mechanical Code and International Fuel Gas Code shall be used. Copies are on file in the city clerk's office. 
(Code 1991, § 18-106; Ord. No. 1740, § 2, 12-20-2010) 
Sec. 8-282. - Scope of, compliance with article. 
    Building sewer laying shall be a part of the work of plumbing under this article. All plumbing and sewer work shall conform to the accepted standards of engineering and public health authorities and practice. This article sets forth the minimum requirements for the installation of revisions as authorized by the board of aldermen, subject further to revisions by the inspector of plumbing and sewers under necessary emergency conditions, by and with the approval of the committee on utilities. 
(Code 1991, § 18-107; Ord. No. 1740, § 2, 12-20-2010) 
Sec. 8-283. - When sewer connections required. 
(a)  Every dwelling house, hotel, apartment house, factory, school house, store or other building in which any plumbing fixtures are placed shall be connected with a city sewer, where the sewer is provided adjacent to or within 100 feet of any lot or tract of land upon which the building is located. If water closets or other plumbing fixtures are installed in buildings where there is no sewer within 100 feet of the lot, suitable provisions shall be made for disposing of building sewerage by some accepted method of sewerage treatment and disposal. 
(b)  In no case will wastewater from any fixture be discharged on the surface of the ground or connected with any sewer or drain that will permit wastewater to empty on any premises or flow into any street or alley. Waste or sewer pipes leaving buildings shall be three feet under the surface of the ground, where possible. Every connection with the city sewer system shall be made at the "Y," if any, located in city sewer, excepting, however, the cases where the designated "Y" is not located within at least three feet of the designated point furnished by the city. The plumber shall make the necessary connection with the city sewer system. 
(Code 1991, § 18-108; Ord. No. 1740, § 2, 12-20-2010) 
Sec. 8-284. - Flush water closet required where sewer is available. 
    It shall be the duty of the owner of every lot or tract of land upon which there is a house or other building used or occupied by human beings and abutting on a street or alley having city water and within 100 feet of a public or lateral sewer, to install upon the premises any standard type of flush water closet and to provide sewer and water connections thereto. 
(Code 1991, § 18-109; Ord. No. 1740, § 2, 12-20-2010) 
Sec. 8-285. - Sanitary closet where sewer not available. 
    It shall be the duty of every owner of a lot or tract of land upon which a house or other building is used or occupied by humans and which abuts on a street or alley in which there is no city water or sewer, or which is located more than 100 feet from a public sewer, to provide on the premises a septic system approved by the county health department and the city building inspector. 
(Code 1991, § 18-110; Ord. No. 1740, § 2, 12-20-2010) 
Sec. 8-286. - Building sewer, drainage system to be independent of others. 
    Each building sewer and drainage system shall be separate and independent of that of any other building sewer and drainage system; provided, however, that where one building stands in the rear of another building located on an interior lot (a lot surrounded by other property and not abutting on any public street or alley), the building sewer from the front building may be extended to the rear building and the whole considered as one building sewer. 
(Code 1991, § 18-194; Ord. No. 1740, § 2, 12-20-2010) 
Sec. 8-287. - Maintenance of premises generally. 
    It shall be the duty of the occupants of each premises to maintain in a sanitary condition at all times the sewage disposal system serving the premises, and it shall be unlawful for anyone to abuse or misuse the privy or other toilet device. No wash water, garbage or kitchen slop shall be emptied into any privy or closet receptacle. It shall be unlawful for any person within the city to throw out, deposit or in any other way dispose of sewage other than as provided for in this article. 
(Code 1991, § 18-111; Ord. No. 1740, § 2, 12-20-2010) 
Sec. 8-288. - Raising, moving, etc., of structures. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to raise, move, overhaul or otherwise change, alter or tamper with any building in this city to which is attached any water connections or sewer connections until a permit has been granted therefore. The disconnection of water and sewer service shall be done by a licensed master plumber in the manner prescribed by the inspector of plumbing and sewers. 
(Code 1991, § 18-93; Ord. No. 1740, § 2, 12-20-2010) 
Sec. 8-289. - Prohibited acts. 
    It is a misdemeanor to do or cause to be done any of the following acts, except as herein provided, and any person guilty thereof shall be fined not less than $1.00 or more than $100.00 plus costs: 
(1)  Uncover the public, district, lateral or private sewer for any purpose or make any connection therewith, or uncover the public connection branches thereof, unless and until a permit has been issued therefor. 
(2)  Make or cause to be made any connection, except as provided in this article or other city ordinance. 
(3)  Throw or deposit or cause or permit to be thrown or deposited in any vessel or receptacle connected with the public sewer, any garbage, hair, ashes, fruit or vegetables, peelings or refuse, rags, cotton, cinders, suspended solids, oil, grease or other matter or thing whatsoever, except: 
a.  The usual and natural materials or substances for which it is constructed. 
b.  The garbage, fruit, vegetables or peelings first passed through an approved and recognized mechanical garbage disposal machine which has been correctly and properly connected to the sewer system and has been inspected and approved by the inspector of plumbing and sewers. 
(4)  Install or permit installation of a ball or other trap device with a seal that is dependent on a movable part. 
(Code 1991, § 18-31; Ord. No. 1740, § 2, 12-20-2010) 
Secs. 8-290-8-310. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - EXCAVATIONS 

Sec. 8-311. - Trenching and backfilling. 
    All excavations shall be open trench work unless otherwise authorized by the inspector of plumbing and sewer. The foundation in the trench shall be formed to prevent any subsequent settlement of the pipe. If the foundation is good, firm earth, the earth shall be pared or molded to give full support to the lower third of each pipe. Care must be exercised in backfilling below the centerline of the pipe in order to give it proper support. Backfilling shall be placed as specified per city policy. The plumber or other person doing any sewer or plumbing work involving excavation in any street, alley, avenue, lane, sidewalk or other public place shall cause the excavation to be filled and tamped as above provided within 48 hours after the completion, inspection and approval of the work done therein. The ditch and the surface thereof shall be restored in as good condition by the plumber or other person as it was previous to the digging, and shall be kept in the condition by the plumber or other person at his own expense until the fill becomes stabilized. 
(Code 1991, § 18-117; Ord. No. 1740, § 2, 12-20-2010) 
Sec. 8-312. - Excavations to be marked. 
    Every sewer building, plumber or person doing work under this division shall enclose any opening or excavation he may make in any of the streets, alleys, avenues, lanes or any other public places in this city, or which is adjacent to and abutting on the streets, alleys, avenues, lanes or any other public places in this city, with good and sufficient barriers not less than two feet high, and shall maintain light danger signals or other recognized and approved danger light signals thereon from sunset to sunrise, which danger light signals shall be placed as may be designated by the inspector of plumbing and sewers and at each end of the opening or excavation. The person shall be held personally liable for any and all damages to persons or property resulting from negligence in maintaining the barriers and signals, or in any manner resulting from the building and construction of the sewer, private drain, water line or other excavation whatsoever. 
(Code 1991, § 18-118; Ord. No. 1740, § 2, 12-20-2010) 
Secs. 8-313-8-332. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - PERMITS 

Sec. 8-333. - Fees. 
    Application for a permit required by this division shall be accompanied by the payment of fees, as provided in the city fee schedule. 
(Code 1991, § 18-89; Ord. No. 1740, § 2, 12-20-2010) 
Sec. 8-334. - Display; inspection procedures. 
    It shall be the duty of the person or plumber to keep all special permits on the premises where work is being done, until the time as the work is completed, when the permit must be returned to the inspector who shall make final inspection and, if accepted, he shall cancel the same. The inspector of plumbing and sewers shall inspect all plumbing within 24 hours after the permit has been returned, and he has been notified of the completion of the work, Sundays and holidays excepted. All work must be left uncovered and convenient for examination until final inspection and approval. 
(Code 1991, § 18-90; Ord. No. 1740, § 2, 12-20-2010) 
Sec. 8-335. - Permit nontransferable. 
    Any permit issued pursuant to this division shall not be transferable. 
(Code 1991, § 18-91; Ord. No. 1740, § 2, 12-20-2010) 
Secs. 8-336-8-355. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - PLUMBER LICENSE 

Sec. 8-356. - Required. 
    No person shall engage in the business of plumbing in the city unless licensed as a master plumber under the provisions of this article. No person shall engage in the business of installing, repairing or altering plumbing unless the plumbing work performed in the course of the business is under the direct supervision of a licensed master plumber. 
(Code 1991, § 18-61; Ord. No. 1740, § 2, 12-20-2010) 
Sec. 8-357. - Application. 
    Any person desiring to be licensed as a master plumber shall make written application to the city. Application shall include passage of a master plumber's examination test through the International Code Council (Exam ID #672), or an exam approved by the city.
