(Code 1991, § 18-62; Ord. No. 1740, § 2, 12-20-2010) 
Sec. 8-358. - Examination; reciprocity. 
    All applicants for a master plumber's license shall successfully pass an examination therefor given by the International Code Council; provided, however, the provisions of sections 8-356 and 8-357 shall not apply to any master plumber who holds a valid license from any city which grants reciprocal rights and privileges to any master plumber holding a license issued by the city. 
(Code 1991, § 18-64; Ord. No. 1740, § 2, 12-20-2010) 
Sec. 8-359. - Insurance certificate. 
    A person who has been issued a master plumber's license shall execute a certificate of liability insurance in the minimum amount of $100,000.00. The certificate shall be made out to the city. A master plumber's license shall not be valid unless a valid insurance certificate is on file and has not expired. 
(Code 1991, § 18-66; Ord. No. 1740, § 2, 12-20-2010) 
Sec. 8-360. - Expiration, renewal. 
    All licenses issued by the city shall expire on December 31 of each year in which issued but may be renewed upon payment of fees in the amount provided. Expired licenses may be renewed at any time upon payment of the penalty of $50.00 for master plumber. 
(Code 1991, § 18-67; Ord. No. 1740, § 2, 12-20-2010) 
Sec. 8-361. - Revocation authorized. 
    The city may revoke any license if obtained through nondisclosure, misstatement or misrepresentation of a material fact or if a penalty has been imposed upon the licensee under provisions of this article. Before a license may be revoked, the licensee shall have notice in writing enumerating the charge against him and be entitled to a hearing by the city not sooner than five days from receipt of the notice. The licensee shall be given an opportunity to present testimony, oral or written, and shall have the right of cross examination. 
(Code 1991, § 18-68; Ord. No. 1740, § 2, 12-20-2010) 
Sec. 8-362. - Conduct of hearing on revocation. 
    All testimony shall be given under oath. The city shall have the power to administer oaths, issue subpoenas, and compel the attendance of witnesses. The decision of the city shall be based upon the evidence produced at the hearing and shall be made a part of the record thereof. A person whose license may have been revoked shall not be permitted to apply within one year from date of revocation. 
(Code 1991, § 18-69; Ord. No. 1740, § 2, 12-20-2010) 
Sec. 8-363. - Misuse. 
    No person who has obtained a plumber's license shall allow his name to be used by another person, either for the purpose of obtaining permits, or for doing business or work under the license. Every person licensed shall notify the city of the address of his place of business, if any, and the name under which business is carried on, and shall give immediate notice to the city of any change of either. 
(Code 1991, § 18-70; Ord. No. 1740, § 2, 12-20-2010) 
Sec. 8-364. - Supervision of plumber's work. 
    No person shall perform any plumbing work within the city unless it is performed under the direct supervision of a licensed master plumber. 
(Code 1991, § 18-72; Ord. No. 1740, § 2, 12-20-2010) 
Sec. 8-365. - Disconnections of water, sewer service. 
    All disconnections of water and sewer service shall be done by a licensed master plumber in the manner prescribed by the inspector of plumbing and sewers. 
(Code 1991, § 18-73; Ord. No. 1740, § 2, 12-20-2010) 
Secs. 8-366-8-385. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - PLUMBING INSPECTIONS 

Sec. 8-386. - Request for inspection; enforcement of compliance. 
(a)  The master plumber or person in charge of any plumbing or sewer work shall notify the inspector of plumbing and sewers when any work is ready for inspection as follows: 
(1)  When any soil, waste and vent pipes shall be completed throughout the building, including all floor drains and the building sewer; and when alterations are made to oil or new plumbing work, before any joints in soil, waste or vent pipes shall be covered up. 
(2)  When all fixtures have been placed and all work completed in every particular. 
At the time the inspector will make his inspection, and any standard test deemed necessary, and if found to be in accordance with the requirements of this article he shall approve same in writing. 
(b)  Any person furnishing water into any water service pipe connected with any new building or structure shall first have the pipe and the plumbing fixtures in the building or structure inspected and approved, provided that temporary permits may be issued for water supply during the period of construction of new buildings or structures, the permit to expire upon completion of the new building or structure and prior to the issuance of a certificate of inspection. 
(c)  On all plumbing work other than that installed in new buildings or structures, if upon inspection by the city inspector of plumbing and sewers the plumbing work does not comply with the requirements of this article, the inspector shall immediately notify the city to shut off the water supply until the work, installations and facilities found to be unsatisfactory or inadequate have been corrected to comply with this article. 
(Code 1991, § 18-46; Ord. No. 1740, § 2, 12-20-2010) 
Sec. 8-387. - Right of access. 
    The inspector of plumbing and sewers shall at all times have access to any building while same is under construction, alteration or repair, or which is connected with the city water and/or sewer, to properly examine the same. 
(Code 1991, § 18-47; Ord. No. 1740, § 2, 12-20-2010) 
Sec. 8-388. - Correction of defective work. 
    Whenever the inspector of plumbing and sewer finds defects in any plumbing and or drainage work being done in violation of the requirements of this article or any ordinance of this city, he shall order the same taken out or corrected and made to conform thereto. The inspector shall investigate any cause of complaint entered at the office of the inspector or city clerk as to the unsanitary condition of the plumbing in or about any building, and if on the investigation the plumbing is found in an unsanitary condition the inspector shall serve written notice on the owner, agent or tenant of the premises to proceed within five days following reception of notice to have the plumbing corrected and placed in a sanitary condition. Any person notified who fails to comply with the order shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1991, § 18-48; Ord. No. 1740, § 2, 12-20-2010) 
Sec. 8-389. - Plumbing fixture inspection required before water is activated. 
    The city shall not turn on water into any water service pipe connected with any new building or structure until the pipe and the plumbing fixtures in the new building or structure have been inspected by the inspector of plumbing and sewers and approved by the inspector in writing; provided, however, that temporary permits may be issued for water supply during the period of construction of new buildings, the permit to expire upon completion of the new building prior to the issuance of a certificate of inspection. 
(Code 1991, § 18-2; Ord. No. 1740, § 2, 12-20-2010) 
Sec. 8-390. - Shutting off of water for unsatisfactory work. 
    On all plumbing work other than that installed in new buildings or structures, if upon inspection by the inspector of plumbing and sewers the plumbing work does not comply with the requirements of this article, the inspector shall immediately report to the city to shut off the water supply until the work, installations and facilities found to be unsatisfactory or inadequate have been corrected to comply with this article. Notice shall be given to the occupant of the premises affected and shall not turn on the supply until further notice from the director directing the action. 
(Code 1991, § 18-3; Ord. No. 1740, § 2, 12-20-2010) 
Chapter 10 - BUSINESSES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal taxing powers, RSMo 71.610 et seq.; municipal licenses, RSMo 94.200 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 10-1. - License required. 
    No person shall, within the city, conduct, exercise, carry on, deal in, sell, keep, own or operate any of the articles, things, places, businesses, occupations, trades, vocations or vehicles named, mentioned or described in section 10-4 unless a license is first obtained therefor from the city clerk. 
(Code 1971, § 11-1; Code 1991, § 11-1) 
Sec. 10-2. - Payment of fee prerequisite for license; issuance. 
    Any person wishing to take out a license under the provisions of this chapter shall pay to the city clerk the amount of the license fee prescribed by this chapter. Upon payment of such license fee to the city clerk, the city clerk shall issue the proper license which shall be signed by the city clerk and attested by the city seal. 
(Code 1971, § 11-2; Code 1991, § 11-2) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 94.230. 
Sec. 10-3. - Debts owed to city. 
(a)  No license or permit required by this Code or the ordinances of the city shall be issued to any applicant therefor who shall owe to the city any account or money for services rendered or materials furnished. Such services rendered or materials furnished in connection with utilities may be added to the utility bill and collected as a part of the utility bill of the city. 
(b)  It is hereby made the duty of the city clerk or other officer issuing licenses or permits required by this chapter or other ordinances of the city to determine whether any applicant for such license or permit owes any account or money for services rendered or materials furnished by the city and to refuse to issue such license or permit to any applicant owing such account or money and to further see that in the case of services rendered or materials furnished in connection with utilities furnished by the city that same be added to the utility bill and collected as a part of such utility bill. 
(Code 1991, § 11-3; Ord. No. 1192, §§ 1, 2, 12-15-1975) 
Sec. 10-4. - License fee prescribed; term, expiration of license. 
(a)  There is hereby levied a license fee on the respective occupations, trades, businesses, vocations, objects, subjects, persons and vehicles mentioned, named or described in this section, and on all persons who deal in, sell, keep, own or operate any of the articles or things mentioned, named or described in this section, and on all persons described, named or mentioned in this section, in the respective amounts and for the time stated: 
(1)  Persons residing outside the city limits and maintaining no place of business therein who sell or deliver any goods or merchandise to any person within the city by wagon, automobile, truck, or private or public conveyance of any other kind: per day, or any part thereof, or per year as so provided in the fee schedule. 
(2)  Peddlers or hawkers: a fee as provided in the city fee schedule per day, or any part thereof. 
(b)  Any license issued pursuant to this chapter for a term of one year shall expire on December 31 of the year in which it was issued. 
(c)  A person or persons licensed under this chapter shall be permitted to operate under the authority of the license between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 8:00 p.m., and not at any other time. 
(Code 1971, § 11-3; Code 1991, § 11-4; Ord. No. 1585, § 1, 7-16-2001) 
Sec. 10-5. - Collection of license fees; disposition of proceeds. 
    It is hereby made the duty of the city clerk to collect the license fees prescribed by this chapter and pay the proceeds thereof to the city treasurer and take his receipt therefor. 
(Code 1971, § 11-4; Code 1991, § 11-5) 
Sec. 10-6. - Separate license for each business location. 
    No license granted under the provisions of this chapter shall authorize the holder thereof to transact business under such license at more than one place or stand in the city at the same time. 
(Code 1971, § 11-5; Code 1991, § 11-6) 
Sec. 10-7. - Display of license. 
    All persons doing business under a license granted pursuant to this chapter shall keep such license posted in their place of business in such a manner as to expose the same to public view. 
(Code 1971, § 11-6; Code 1991, § 11-7) 
Sec. 10-8. - License not transferable. 
    No license issued pursuant to this chapter shall be transferable or assignable. 
(Code 1971, § 11-7; Code 1991, § 11-8) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 94.230. 
Sec. 10-9. - Record of licenses. 
    The city clerk shall keep a book in his office in which he shall register all licenses granted pursuant to this chapter, showing the date of commencement and expiration of each license, to whom granted, for what purpose, and the amount of such license fee paid therefor. 
(Code 1971, § 11-8; Code 1991, § 11-9) 
Sec. 10-10. - Revocation of license. 
    Any license issued pursuant to this chapter may, for cause, be revoked by the board of aldermen. 
(Code 1971, § 11-9; Code 1991, § 11-10) 
Sec. 10-11. - Persons acting as agents, solicitors for unlicensed businesses. 
(a)  Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, it shall be unlawful for any person to act as an agent or solicitor for any company, firm, corporation, individual or association of individuals unless such company, firm, corporation, individual or association of individuals has been licensed by the city to transact business or operate within the city. 
(b)  No person following for a livelihood the profession of veterinarian, architect, professional engineer, land surveyor, auctioneer or real estate broker or salesman in this state, shall be taxed or made liable to pay any city tax or license fee for the privilege of following or carrying on his profession by the city unless that person maintains a business office within the city. 
(Code 1971, § 11-10; Code 1991, § 11-11) 
Secs. 10-12-10-40. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - MOTOR VEHICLES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Authority of city to levy and collect license tax upon vehicles, RSMo 301.340. 

Sec. 10-41. - License tax required. 
    Every owner of a motor vehicle residing in the city shall pay an annual motor vehicle license tax, which shall be valid from January 1 until December 31, for each motor vehicle that they own as of January 1 of each year. 
(Code 1991, § 11-36; Ord. No. 1594, § 1, 3-18-2002) 
Sec. 10-42. - License fee. 
    The fee per year for the license required by this article shall be as provided in the city fee schedule. The fee shall be due and payable on December 31 of each year and shall be delinquent on January 1 of the following year. 
(Code 1991, § 11-37; Ord. No. 1594, § 1, 3-18-2002) 
Sec. 10-43. - Exception. 
    No resident of the city who owns a motor vehicle used exclusively outside of the city shall be required to pay any motor vehicle license tax as set forth in section 10-41 for any such motor vehicle. The fact that the motor vehicle is used exclusively outside of the city may be shown by an affidavit of the owner of such motor vehicle for the purpose of securing a state registration certificate without producing a receipt for municipal license taxes. 
(Code 1991, § 11-38; Ord. No. 1594, § 1, 3-18-2002) 
Sec. 10-44. - Exemption from article. 
    Vehicles and other contraptions operated or powered by motors and driven by minors are hereby exempt from the provisions of this article and chapter 46, pertaining to motor vehicles, when same are operated under the supervision of parents or adults on special occasions such as parades or other special events held on public streets which are blocked off for such occasion. 
(Code 1991, § 11-40; Ord. No. 1594, § 1, 3-18-2002) 
Sec. 10-45. - Collection official. 
    The official designated by the board of aldermen shall include as a charge on bills issued for personal property taxes the charge for city motor vehicle license taxes and collect the same with and in the same payment as personal property taxes. The designated official shall collect delinquent receipts of such motor vehicle license taxes, and penalties thereon, in the same manner and form as provided by law for the collection of delinquent ad valorem property taxes. 
(Code 1991, § 11-39; Ord. No. 1594, § 1, 3-18-2002) 
Secs. 10-46-10-63. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - NATURAL GAS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Licensing and regulation of gas companies, RSMo 94.270. 

Sec. 10-64. - Gross receipts license fee required; amount; payment; etc. 
(a)  Every corporation, company, association, joint stock company or association, partnership and person, their lessees, trustees or receivers appointed by any court whatsoever, owning, operating, managing, leasing or controlling a gas plant or system for the distribution and sale of natural gas by means of pipes constructed under, across or through the public streets of the city shall, in addition to all other taxes, payments or requirements now or hereafter required by law or city ordinance, pay to the city as a license fee a sum equal to five percent of the licensee's gross receipts from the sale of gas sold for domestic or commercial purposes within the corporate limits of the city. 
(b)  Domestic and commercial sales shall be considered as sales made other than on special contracts providing for standby fuel and interruption of service at any time demands of domestic and commercial consumers may so require. 
(c)  The licensee shall not later than February 1 and August 1, respectively, of each year make a report to the board of aldermen of its gross receipts for the six months' period ending at the last meter reading preceding December 31 and June 30, respectively, and at the time of making such reports shall pay into the city treasury such license fee based upon the gross receipts so reported. 
(d)  The acceptance of such fees shall not prejudice the right of the city to collect any additional fee thereafter found to be due. 
(e)  In the event the licensee pays a sum greater than is due upon its gross receipts for any period by reason of its inability to determine accurately the amount properly due, the licensee shall be entitled, following a determination of the overpayment, to deduct such overpayment and receive a credit therefor against the amount of license fee due for the next succeeding period or periods following the determination of the overpayment. 
(f)  The city, by its duly authorized representatives, shall have the right, at all reasonable times during business hours, to make such examinations and inspections of the books of such licensee as may be necessary to determine the correctness of such reports. 
(g)  The city shall have the right, at its own expense, to employ the same accountants who make the annual audit of the books, records and accounts of the business of the licensee, to audit, at the same time, the licensee's accounts and records and certify as to the correctness of any payments due and payable by the licensee to the city. 
(Code 1991, § 11-66; Ord. No. 1282, § 1, 5-18-1981) 
Sec. 10-65. - Penalty for delinquency. 
    For each and every month, or part thereof that any license fee required by this article remains unpaid after the same becomes due and payable, there shall be added to such license fee, as a penalty for such delayed payment, two percent of the amount of such license fee, or part thereof that is unpaid until the same is fully paid. 
(Code 1991, § 11-67; Ord. No. 1282, § 2, 5-18-1981) 
Sec. 10-66. - Status of license fee. 
    The fee required to be paid by this article is an occupation or license fee and shall be in lieu of any other occupation or license fee required of any person engaged in the business described in this article, but nothing herein shall be construed as exempting such person from the payment of any tax upon real or personal property nor from the payment of any other lawfully levied tax other than a license or occupation tax. 
(Code 1991, § 11-68; Ord. No. 1282, § 3, 5-18-1981) 
Sec. 10-67. - Application to franchisees. 
    Any person engaged in the business described in this article and holding a franchise granted by the city which contains within its terms provisions for the payment of an occupation and license tax, shall pay such tax as therein provided until the expiration or effective date of express repeal of such franchise. Upon such expiration or express repeal, such person shall commence computation and payment of the license fee as herein provided. 
(Code 1991, § 11-69; Ord. No. 1282, § 4, 5-18-1981) 
Secs. 10-68-10-92. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - POOL HALLS AND BILLIARD HALLS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Authority of city to license and regulate billiard and pool tables, RSMo 94.270; pool tables generally, RSMo ch. 318. 

Sec. 10-93. - Definition. 
    As used in this article, the term "pool hall" or "billiard hall" means any place where pool or billiard tables are kept for hire to the public or upon which the public is invited to play, provided that automatic coin-operated pool tables, smaller in size than regulation pool tables, are hereby separately classified. 
(Code 1971, § 19-1; Code 1991, § 20-1; Ord. No. 1154, § 1, 12-17-1973) 
Sec. 10-94. - License required; number restricted. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to operate, own or control any pool hall, billiard hall or coin-operated pool table within the city without first having obtained a license therefor from the city. One coin-operated license only shall be issued to one place of business. 
(Code 1971, § 19-2; Code 1991, § 20-2; Ord. No. 1154, § 2, 12-17-1973) 
Sec. 10-95. - Application for license. 
(a)  All applications for licenses within the scope of this article shall be made in writing to the board of aldermen. 
(b)  No license within the scope of this article shall be granted at the same meeting of the board of aldermen at which the application therefor is presented except by unanimous vote of the board; provided, however, that such application may be considered by the board of aldermen at the first meeting of the board at which the application is presented if the applicant has first served written notice upon each member of the board, at least five days before the meeting of the board at which such application is to be presented, of his intention to present such application. 
(Code 1971, § 19-3; Code 1991, § 20-3) 
Sec. 10-96. - Qualifications for license. 
(a)  No person shall be granted a license within the scope of this article unless he is of good moral character, a native born or naturalized citizen of the United States, a qualified, regular voter and taxpaying citizen of the city. 
(b)  No person shall be granted a license within the scope of this article whose license has been revoked. 
(Code 1971, § 19-4; Code 1991, § 20-4) 
Sec. 10-97. - Conduct of licensee, permittee. 
    Any licensee or permittee under this article shall keep an orderly house and premises at all times. He shall not violate any of the provisions of this article. He shall pay all taxes and fees levied by state law, together with all fines, penalties and forfeitures which may be adjudged against him under the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1971, § 19-5; Code 1991, § 20-5) 
Sec. 10-98. - Issuance of license. 
    The city clerk shall issue a license within the scope of this article to any person who complies with all of the requirements of this article to the satisfaction of the board of aldermen and who produces a receipt from the designated official confirming that the fees levied by this article have been paid. 
(Code 1971, § 19-6; Code 1991, § 20-6) 
Sec. 10-99. - License fee. 
    There is hereby levied a license fee as provided for in the fee schedule per year for each pool or billiard table or automatic coin-operated pool table within the purview of this article. Such license fee shall be paid whether or not such pool table, billiard table or coin-operated pool table is in operation during such period. 
(Code 1971, § 19-7; Code 1991, § 20-7; Ord. No. 1154, § 3, 12-17-1973) 
Sec. 10-100. - Receipt to be issued upon payment of license fee. 
    The designated official shall issue a receipt to any person who has paid the license fee levied by this article. 
(Code 1971, § 19-8; Code 1991, § 20-8) 
Sec. 10-101. - Forfeiture of license fee. 
    In the event of revocation or forfeiture of any license issued pursuant to this article, for cause or otherwise, the city shall not return any part of the license fee paid for such license. 
(Code 1971, § 19-9; Code 1991, § 20-9) 
Sec. 10-102. - Duration of license. 
    Each license issued pursuant to this article shall be for a term of one year from the date of issuance thereof, unless revoked for cause as herein provided. 
(Code 1971, § 19-10; Code 1991, § 20-10) 
Sec. 10-103. - Information contained in license. 
    Every license issued pursuant to this article shall describe the premises at which any pool hall or billiard hall is to be located and the particular kind of tables to be operated thereunder. 
(Code 1971, § 19-11; Code 1991, § 20-11) 
Sec. 10-104. - Number restricted. 
    The number of licenses issued under this article shall be one license per each 1,000 people or major part thereof, and the "major part" shall mean at least 667 persons. 
(Code 1971, § 19-12; Code 1991, § 20-12; Ord. No. 1377, § 1, 2-15-1988) 
Sec. 10-105. - Separate license required for each place of business. 
    A separate license to operate a pool hall or billiard hall within the city shall be required for each place of business within the purview of this article. 
(Code 1971, § 19-13; Code 1991, § 20-13) 
Sec. 10-106. - Operation limited to place shown in license. 
    No person who is issued a license to operate a pool hall or billiard hall within the city shall operate the same in any other place than that designated in the license. 
(Code 1971, § 19-14; Code 1991, § 20-14) 
Sec. 10-107. - License not transferable. 
    No license issued pursuant to this article shall be transferable or assignable. 
(Code 1971, § 19-15; Code 1991, § 20-15) 
Sec. 10-108. - Hours of operation-Daily. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person or entity within the corporate limits of the city to operate any billiard hall, pool hall or coin-operated pool tables between the hours of 1:30 a.m. and 6:00 a.m. on any day, except as provided in section 10-109. 
(Code 1971, § 19-16; Code 1991, § 20-16; Ord. No. 1311, § 1, 10-3-1983; Ord. No. 1439, § 1, 10-19-1992) 
Sec. 10-109. - Same-Persons or entities licensed under chapter 4. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person or entity, licensed under chapter 4 of this Code, within the corporate limits of the city to operate any billiard hall, pool hall or coin-operated pool tables on any Sunday after the hour of 1:30 a.m. 
(Code 1971, § 19-17; Code 1991, § 20-17; Ord. No. 1154, § 4, 12-17-1973; Ord. No. 1311, § 1, 10-3-1983; Ord. No. 1439, § 2, 10-19-1992) 
Sec. 10-110. - Proximity to churches, schools. 
    No license shall be issued to any person to operate a pool hall or billiard hall in any building or place located within 100 feet of any church building or school building in the city. 
(Code 1971, § 19-18; Code 1991, § 20-18; Ord. No. 1435, § 1, 7-28-1992) 
Sec. 10-111. - Minors. 
    No person who is issued a license to operate a pool hall or billiard hall within the city shall allow any minor therein unless such minor first files with the licensee the written consent of his parent or guardian authorizing the presence of such minor therein. Such written consent shall remain on file with the licensee on his premises at all times, and shall at all times be subject to inspection by the police chief or other officer of the city. Such written consent, when filed, shall be in effect for the minority of such minor unless withdrawn or revoked by the party signing or authorizing the same. 
(Code 1971, § 19-19; Code 1991, § 20-19) 
Sec. 10-112. - Intoxicated persons. 
    No person who is issued a license to operate a pool hall or billiard hall within the city shall allow any intoxicated person therein. 
(Code 1971, § 19-20; Code 1991, § 20-20) 
Sec. 10-113. - Intoxicating liquor, nonintoxicating beer. 
    No person who is issued a license to operate a pool hall or billiard hall within the city shall sell or dispense therein any intoxicating liquor or any nonintoxicating beer, as defined in section 4-1; nor shall such licensee allow any intoxicating liquor or nonalcoholic beer to be brought on such premises or consumed therein. 
(Code 1971, § 19-21; Code 1991, § 20-21) 
Sec. 10-114. - Beer in places licensed for coin-operated pool tables. 
    The provisions of section 10-113 dealing with five percent beer or nonintoxicating beer shall not apply to places of business licensed for the operation of an automatic coin-operated pool table. 
(Code 1991, § 20-22; Ord. No. 1154, § 4, 12-17-1973; Ord. No. 1311, § 1, 10-3-1983) 
Sec. 10-115. - Permitting unlawful operation. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to own, operate, lease, occupy or control any building or place and knowingly permit pool tables or billiard tables to be operated unlawfully therein. 
(Code 1971, § 19-23; Code 1991, § 20-23) 
Sec. 10-116. - Revocation of license. 
(a)  The board of aldermen may, after a hearing, revoke any license issued pursuant to this article if the licensee thereof has not at all times kept an orderly place, or if he has violated any of the provisions of this article or for any other good cause shown after having first given the licensee not less than ten days' notice in writing of the application to revoke his license. Such notice shall contain the ground or grounds for revocation and shall command the licensee to be present at the regular or called meeting of the board of aldermen and show cause, if any, why such license should not be revoked; provided, however, that such licensee at such hearing shall have the right to be represented by counsel and produce witnesses and evidence in his behalf; provided, further, that such notice shall be served by the police chief upon such licensee by leaving a copy thereof with him or any person or employee in charge of the place of business of such licensee. 
(b)  Upon the conviction of any person licensed pursuant to this article for a violation of any provision of this article, such conviction shall automatically operate to revoke the license hereunder issued to such person. 
(Code 1971, § 19-24; Code 1991, § 20-24) 
Sec. 10-117. - Violation bars issuance, renewal of license. 
    No person convicted of violating any of the provisions of this article shall be issued a license to operate a pool hall or billiard hall within the city or renewal thereof thereafter. 
(Code 1971, § 19-25; Code 1991, § 20-25) 
Sec. 10-118. - Certification of conviction. 
    Upon the conviction of any person for violating any of the provisions of this article, it shall be the duty of the police judge to certify such conviction to the board of aldermen. 
(Code 1971, § 19-26; Code 1991, § 20-26) 
Secs. 10-119-10-138. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - COMMERCIAL TREE MAINTENANCE ENTITIES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 10-139. - Trees defined. 
    As used in this article, the term "trees" shall mean all ornamental, shade, fruit, nut or other species of trees, or any portions thereof, over the height of ten feet growing or standing, either alive or dead, in the corporate limits of the city. 
(Code 1971, § 23-13; Code 1991, § 25-21) 
Sec. 10-140. - Work performance generally. 
    All holders of a license issued pursuant to this article, while operating in the city, shall perform their duties in a workmanlike manner, using such methods and work practices that will pose the least danger of injury to persons. 
(Code 1971, § 23-14; Code 1991, § 25-22) 
Sec. 10-141. - Removal of debris. 
    All tree trunks, branches, limbs, roots whenever dug out, chips, and other debris from trees shall be removed by the holder of the license issued pursuant to this article from the premises of the owner thereof to a designated location in the city, or some other location outside the city, immediately after such trees are pruned, treated, repaired, trimmed, cut down or removed as the contract with such owner so provides. 
(Code 1971, § 23-15; Code 1991, § 25-23) 
Secs. 10-142-10-160. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 10-161. - Required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to prune, dust, spray, treat, repair, trim, fumigate, cut down or remove any tree, within the corporate limits of the city, not located upon his own property without first obtaining a license therefor from the city. 
(Code 1971, § 23-22; Code 1991, § 25-41) 
Sec. 10-162. - Application. 
    All applications for a license required by this division shall be made in writing on an application form furnished by the city at the office of the city clerk. 
(Code 1971, § 23-23; Code 1991, § 25-42) 
Sec. 10-163. - Insurance required. 
    All applications for a license required by this division shall be accompanied by a copy of the applicant's public liability and property damage insurance policy, in an amount of bodily injury liability of not less than $100,000.00 sustained by each person, $300,000.00 for bodily injury for any one accident, and for property damage of not less than $100,000.00, with a deductible property damage liability endorsement of not more than $500.00. Such policy shall remain in force during the licensed period, and shall remain on file in the office of the city clerk during the period the license herein required is in effect and until released by the city. 
(Code 1971, § 23-24; Code 1991, § 25-43; Ord. No. 1623, § 1, 10-20-2003) 
Sec. 10-164. - Duration. 
    Any license issued pursuant to this division shall be in force for one year from the date of issuance, unless revoked or forfeited for cause as herein provided. 
(Code 1971, § 23-25; Code 1991, § 25-44) 
Sec. 10-165. - Fee designated. 
    The license fee for the license required under this division shall be as provided in the city fee schedule. 
(Code 1971, § 23-26; Code 1991, § 25-45; Ord. No. 1661, § 1, 10-17-2005) 
Sec. 10-166. - Nontransferable. 
    Any license issued pursuant to this division shall not be transferable or assignable. 
(Code 1971, § 23-27; Code 1991, § 25-46) 
Sec. 10-167. - Revocation by board; notice; hearing. 
    The board of aldermen may, upon a hearing, revoke any license issued pursuant to this division if the licensee has not at all times performed his work in accordance with the provisions of this article, or for any other good cause shown, first having given such licensee not less than five days' notice in writing of the application to revoke his license prior to the date of hearing. Such notice shall contain all grounds for such revocation and shall command the licensee to be present at the regular or called meeting of the board of aldermen and show good cause as to why such license should not be revoked. Such licensee shall have the right to be represented by counsel at such meeting and may produce evidence in his behalf at such hearing. Such notice of hearing shall be served by the police chief and may be served upon the licensee by leaving a copy thereof with the licensee or any person or employee in charge of the work of the licensee in the city. 
(Code 1971, § 23-28; Code 1991, § 25-47) 
Sec. 10-168. - Forfeiture of fee upon revocation. 
    In case any license issued pursuant to this division is revoked or forfeited, the city shall not refund any part of the license fee paid for such license. 
(Code 1971, § 23-29; Code 1991, § 25-48) 
Sec. 10-169. - Forfeiture of license upon lapse of insurance. 
    In the event the insurance policy required by this division lapses for any cause during the period the license required by this division is in force, the license of such licensee shall automatically be forfeited. 
(Code 1971, § 23-30; Code 1991, § 25-49) 
Sec. 10-170. - Automatically revoked upon conviction. 
    Any license issued pursuant to this division shall automatically be revoked upon the conviction of the holder thereof for any violation of this article. 
(Code 1971, § 23-31; Code 1991, § 25-50) 
Sec. 10-171. - Issuance, renewal to violators. 
    No person who has been convicted of violating any of the provisions of this article shall be issued a license within the scope of this division, or a renewal thereof, for a period of one year from the date of such conviction. 
(Code 1971, § 23-32; Code 1991, § 25-51) 
Sec. 10-172. - Certification of conviction. 
    Upon conviction of any person under the provisions of this article, it shall be the duty of the municipal judge to certify such conviction to the board of aldermen. 
(Code 1971, § 23-33; Code 1991, § 25-52) 
Secs. 10-173-10-190. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - PEDDLERS, HAWKERS, ETC. 

Sec. 10-191. - Peddling from parked vehicles. 
    No person shall park any vehicle on any public way or public property in the city for the purpose of selling, or offering for sale, any goods, produce, or merchandise or for the purpose of soliciting business without the approval of the board of aldermen. 
( Ord. No. 1812 , § 1(11-1), 9-19-2016) 
Sec. 10-192. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this article is to protect, maintain and enhance the public health, safety, and general welfare by regulating peddling, itinerant traders, traveling salesperson, and other door-to-door salesperson, generally known as peddlers. This article is not intended to interfere with legitimate business activities of peddlers as the same are herein defined, whether the same be local or interstate. These provisions are intended only to, as nearly as possible, ferret out the illegitimate or confidence operators and to regulate and control all those who would use their unique presence on property within the city, either in person or by means of a telephone contact, or their unique proximity to its residents, for purposes of harassment, nuisance, theft, or other unlawful activities. To achieve this end, this article requires peddlers seek licenses, have background checks, and peddle under certain limitations. It is not the intent of this article to infringe free speech rights or require licensing for persons going door-to-door for political campaigns, religious proselytizing, or other free speech reasons. 
( Ord. No. 1812 , § 1(11-2), 9-19-2016) 
Sec. 10-193. - Definitions. 
    As used in this article, the following words have the meaning indicated except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Canvasser means a person who attempts to make personal contact with a resident at his/her residence, without prior specific invitation or appointment from the resident, for the primary purpose of attempting to enlist support for or against a particular religion, philosophy, ideology, political party, issue or candidate, even if incidental to such purpose the canvasser accepts the donation of money for or against such cause. 
    Peddler, hawker, etc., means a person who attempts to make personal contact with a resident at such person's residence, without prior specific invitation or appointment from the resident, for the primary purpose of attempting to sell a good or service. The word "peddler" or "hawker" shall include "door-to-door salespersons", "itinerant traders, vendors or merchants", "traveling salespersons", "vendor", "huckster", "concessionaire", and shall include route salespersons selling randomly to customers, but not route salespersons supplying only prior customer orders. A "peddler" does not include a "solicitor." 
    Solicitor means a person who attempts to make personal contact with a resident at his/her residence, without prior specific invitation or appointment from the resident, for the primary purpose of (1) attempting to obtain a donation to a particular patriotic, philanthropic, social service, welfare, benevolent, educational, civic, fraternal, charitable, political or religious purpose, even if incidental to such purpose there is the sale of some good or service, or (2) distributing a handbill or flyer advertising a commercial event, activity, good or service that is offered to the resident for purchase at a location away from the residence or at a time different from the time of visit. 
( Ord. No. 1812 , § 1(11-3), 9-19-2016) 
Sec. 10-194. - License required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any peddler, solicitor, itinerant merchant, and vendor as defined in section 10-193 of this article to engage in such business within the corporate limits of the city, without first obtaining a license therefore. Each employee of a business or corporation engaging in peddling shall have a separate license. A license must be applied for at least five days prior to the date when the activity to be carried on is to commence. 
( Ord. No. 1812 , § 1(11-4), 9-19-2016) 
Sec. 10-195. - Exemptions. 
    The license requirement of section 10-194 shall not apply to: 
(1)  Sales by farmers and gardeners of the produce of their farms, gardens and greenhouses, including fruit, vegetables and flowers, or to the sale, distribution and delivery of milk, teas, coffees, spices, groceries, meats and bakery goods, to sales on approval, to conditional sales of merchandise, or to the taking of orders for merchandise for future delivery when full payment is not required at the time of solicitation; 
(2)  To individuals or groups who are duly authorized to act for and on behalf of, any recognized charitable, civic or religious organization; 
(3)  Peddlers going to a house or place of business at the express invitation of the owner or occupant of such house or place of business; 
(4)  Persons engaged in a business or activity which the state or federal government has exclusive authority to regulate; 
(5)  Persons distributing newspapers, pamphlets, handbills or other written or printed matter distributed for the purpose of disseminating news, information or religious materials; 
(6)  Persons residing in the city who hold garage or yard sales; and 
(7)  Governmental entities. 
( Ord. No. 1812 , § 1(11-5), 9-19-2016) 
Sec. 10-196. - Prohibitions. 
    No person, including those exempted in section 10-195 hereof, shall: 
(1)  Remain upon private property after having been asked to leave by the owner or occupant thereof. Any itinerant vendor, mobile street vendor or peddler who enters upon property owned, leased or controlled by another and willfully refuses to leave said property after having been notified by such owner or possessor of said property, or his agent, to leave such property shall be guilty of an ordinance violation. 
(2)  Engage in any conduct in violation of any law of the State of Missouri or any ordinance of the city. 
(3)  Sell or offer for sale any goods, wares, merchandise, food, produce or other items upon any public street, sidewalk, alley or other public right-of-way. 
(4)  Call on prospective customers between the hours of 7:30 p.m. and 10:00 a.m., unless by previous arrangement with such customer. 
(5)  Engage in any activity of solicitation, selling, requesting donations, distribution of literature of any type, or offering of any service upon any public street or at any street intersection. 
( Ord. No. 1812 , § 1(11-6), 9-19-2016) 
Sec. 10-197. - Required information. 
    Applicants for a license under this article shall make a sworn application to the city upon forms to be furnished by the city clerk's office. A criminal record check shall be completed by the police department. Each applicant shall provide the minimum following information: 
(1)  Full name and all information contained on the driver's license of the applicant and each agent or employee working under the license; 
(2)  Permanent home address and present local address of the applicant; 
(3)  Name and home office address of the applicant's employer; 
(4)  If the applicant owns or uses a motor vehicle in connection with his business, a description of such motor vehicle and the license number of same; 
(5)  A brief description of the merchandise or services to be sold; 
(6)  A statement as to whether or not the applicant has been convicted of any felony and the disposition of same; 
(7)  A site plan to be drawn by the applicant, not to scale, which need only show the location to be used by the itinerant vendor and to be made the basis of the license; 
(8)  Proposed duration of the temporary sales operation; 
(9)  Written permission of the owner of the land or building where the sales are to take place (itinerant vendor only); 
(10)  A copy of the applicant's State of Missouri Sales Tax Permit; and 
(11)  A copy of a certificate of insurance, for vehicular, property, casualty, or liability as may be reasonable and customary for the nature of the proposed operation consistent with the Revised Statutes of Missouri. 
( Ord. No. 1812 , § 1(11-7), 9-19-2016) 
Sec. 10-198. - Investigation; issuance, and denial. 
(a)  The city clerk shall initiate the investigation of the truth and accuracy of the information contained in the application as soon as possible. 
(b)  The city clerk shall deny a license if a timely investigation reveals that: 
(1)  Failure of the applicant to truthfully provide any of the information requested by the city as a part of the application or the failure to sign the application, or the failure to pay the required fee at the time of application. 
(2)  The conviction of the applicant within the past five years from the date of application for any violation or any federal or state statute or regulation, or of any local ordinance, which adversely reflects on the person's ability to conduct the business for which the license is being sought in an honest and legal manner. These violations shall include but not be limited to burglary, theft, larceny, swindling, fraud, unlawful business practices, and any form of actual or threatened physical harm against another person or violations involving a sex offense, trafficking in controlled substances, or any violent acts against persons or property; 
(3)  An investigation reveals that the applicant falsified information on the application; 
(4)  The location and time of the activities described in the application would endanger the safety and welfare of the applicant or its customers; 
(5)  The applicant is a person against whom a judgment based upon, or conviction for, fraud, deceit or misrepresentation has been entered within the five years immediately preceding the date of application; 
(6)  There is no proof as to the authority of the applicant to serve as an agent to the principal; or 
(7)  The applicant owes to the city any account or money for services rendered or materials furnished, or who is then delinquent in the payment of fines and/or court costs owed to the municipal court. 
(c)  The city clerk's disapproval and the reasons for disapproval shall be noted on the application, and the applicant shall be notified that his application is disapproved and that no license will be issued. Notice shall be mailed to the applicant at the address shown on the application form, or at the applicant's last known address. 
( Ord. No. 1812 , § 1(11-8), 9-19-2016) 
Sec. 10-199. - Violations, enforcement or revocation of license. 
(a)  The licenses issued pursuant to this article may be revoked immediately by the city clerk for any of the following causes: 
(1)  Any fraud, misrepresentation or false statement contained in the application for license; 
(2)  Any fraud, misrepresentation or false statement made in connection with the selling of goods, wares or merchandise; 
(3)  Any violation of this article; 
(4)  Conviction of the licensee of any felony or of a misdemeanor involving moral turpitude; or 
(5)  Conducting the business licensed under this article in an unlawful manner or in such a manner as to constitute a breach of the peace or to constitute a menace to the health, safety or general welfare of the public; or any other conduct that is prohibited by local, state or federal laws or regulations. 
(b)  The license of an itinerant vendor shall be suspended until such time as may be heard publicly and reinstated by the board of aldermen. 
(c)  Notice of hearing for revocation of a license shall be given in writing, setting forth specifically the grounds of the complaint and the time and place of the hearing. Such notice shall be mailed, postage prepaid, to the licensee, at his last known address, at least five days prior to the date set for the hearing. 
    Any person who violates or fails to comply with the provisions of any section of this article shall be guilty of an ordinance violation. 
( Ord. No. 1812 , § 1(11-9), 9-19-2016) 
Sec. 10-200. - Appeals. 
    Any person aggrieved by the decision of the city clerk in regard to the denial of application for license as provided for in section 10-198 of this article or in connection with the revocation of a license as provided for in section 10-199 of this article, shall have the right to appeal to the board of aldermen. Such appeal shall be taken by filing with the city clerk within 14 days after notice of the decision by the city clerk has been mailed to such person's last address, a written statement setting forth the grounds for the appeal. The city clerk shall set the time and place for a hearing on such appeal and notice of such hearing shall be given to such person in the same manner as provided in section 10-199 of this article for notice of hearing on revocation. The order of the board of aldermen on such appeal shall be final. Upon the denial or revocation of a license, the city clerk shall notify in writing the applicant or licensee of the reason for such denial or revocation. The applicant or licensee shall have a right of appeal to the board of aldermen upon the denial or revocation of the license. 
( Ord. No. 1812 , § 1(11-10), 9-19-2016) 
Sec. 10-201. - Fees. 
    Each and every person seeking a license under the provisions herein shall pay an application fee of $50.00. The license fee shall be paid by the person desiring the license and payable at the time of application. This fee shall be charged to help defray the cost of investigation and administration incident to the license. This fee shall not be pro-rated or refunded to the applicant regardless of whether a license is issued or not. The fee for the issuance of each license shall be: 
(1)  For a peddler acting on behalf of a merchant licensed or not otherwise licensed to do business within the city, a fee of $10.00 per day. 
(2)  For a solicitor (including a commercial solicitor advertising an event, activity, good or service for purchase at a location away from the residence) or canvasser requesting a license, no fee. 
(3)  For a canvasser (even if incidental to such purpose the canvasser accepts the donation of money for or against such cause), no fee. 
( Ord. No. 1812 , § 1(11-11), 9-19-2016) 
Sec. 10-202. - Duration. 
    Each itinerant vendor's or peddler's license issued under the authority of this article shall be valid for the period of anticipated use of the applicant, but not to exceed 90 days from the date it is issued, or until revoked under the provisions of this article. 
( Ord. No. 1812 , § 1(11-12), 9-19-2016) 
Sec. 10-203. - Customers' rights; cancellation. 
    All peddlers or solicitors shall provide to the consumer, in writing, the right to cancel a solicitation transaction made in person or by telephone until midnight of the third business day after the day on which the customer signs an agreement or offer to purchase any goods, wares, merchandise, food, photographs, publications or services. For the purpose of telephone solicitation, the date of transaction means the day the consumer receives the goods, wares, merchandise, food, photographs, publications or services purchased in a solicitation transaction. If the consumer chooses to cancel the solicitation transaction, notification by mail shall be considered given at the time mailed, as evidenced by the postmark, notification by telegram shall be considered given at the time filed for transmission and notification by any other writing shall be considered given at the time delivered to the merchant's designated place of business. It shall be unlawful for any peddler, solicitor or company represented to refuse to allow the customer to cancel the solicitation transaction. 
( Ord. No. 1812 , § 1(11-13), 9-19-2016) 
Sec. 10-204. - License display. 
    Every peddler or itinerant vendor as defined in this article who has secured a license under the authority of this article shall keep a copy of any license upon his person at all times and shall display the same upon the request of any city official, customer, police officer or owner or occupant upon whose property the itinerant vendor or peddler has gone for business purposes. 
( Ord. No. 1812 , § 1(11-14), 9-19-2016) 
Sec. 10-205. - Transferability, assignability or use by another. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person other than the person to whom the license was issued to display or otherwise use any itinerant vendor's or peddler's license. The licenses issued under the authority of this article shall not be transferable or assignable. 
( Ord. No. 1812 , § 1(11-15), 9-19-2016) 
Sec. 10-206. - Surety. 
    Before any license, as provided by this article, shall be issued for engaging in the businesses as defined in section 10-193 of this article in the city, such applicant shall file with the city clerk a bond running to the city, in the sum of $1,000.00 executed by the applicant, as principal, and a surety bond upon which service of process may be made in the State of Missouri; said bond to be approved by the city attorney, conditioned that the said applicant shall comply with all of the provisions of the ordinances of the city, and the statutes of the State of Missouri, regulating and concerning the sale of goods, wares and merchandise, and will pay all judgments rendered against said applicant for any violation of said ordinances or statutes, or any of them, together with all judgments and costs that may be recovered against him by any person or persons for damage growing out of any misrepresentation or deception practiced on any person transacting such business with said applicant, whether said misrepresentations or deceptions were made or practiced by the owners or by their servants, agents, or employees, either at the time of making the sale or through any advertisement of any character whatsoever, printed or circulated with reference to the goods, wares and merchandise sold or any part thereof, and guaranteeing to any citizen of the city that property purchased will be delivered according to the representations of the said applicant. Action on the bond may be brought in the name of the city to the use of the aggrieved person. Such bond must be approved by the city attorney, both as to form, and as the responsibility of the sureties thereon. 
( Ord. No. 1812 , § 1(11-16), 9-19-2016) 
Sec. 10-207. - Posting. 
    It shall be unlawful for any peddler or solicitor to enter upon any private premises when the same is posted with a sign stating "No Peddlers Allowed," "No Solicitation Allowed" or other words to that effect. 
( Ord. No. 1812 , § 1(11-17), 9-19-2016) 
Secs. 10-208-10-220. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - SIDEWALK CAFÉS 

Sec. 10-221. - Sidewalk café permit. 
(a)  Permit authorized. Unless otherwise authorized under the Code of Ordinances, no person shall place tables or chairs or any other device for the sale or consumption of food or beverage upon any public sidewalk or footway without first obtaining an annual sidewalk café permit. The city clerk is authorized to issue annual sidewalk café permits for a permit year beginning on January 1 and ending on December 31 of the same year, for the limited purpose of temporarily placing tables and chairs for customers in connection with the sale and consumption of food and beverages in or upon any public sidewalk or footway only if all of the following conditions are met: 
(1)  A sidewalk café permit can only be issued for areas in the city zoned for business and for sidewalks that will allow a clear unobstructed passage not less than four feet in width following the placement of the tables and chairs and pedestrian barriers. 
(2)  A sidewalk café permit issued under this section may not be assigned. 
(3)  The sidewalk café permit shall specify the location of the permit area by address. 
(4)  The applicant for a sidewalk café permit meets all of the other permit requirements contained in the Code of Ordinances. 
(b)  Status of permit. A sidewalk café permit is a privilege and not a right, and the city shall at all times have the right to restrict the scope, time and manner of the placement of tables and chairs on the sidewalk at any time and for any reason by ordinance or policy enacted by the board of aldermen. 
(c)  Application for sidewalk café permits. 
(1)  All applications for a sidewalk café permit shall be filed with the city clerk in a form approved by the city clerk. 
(2)  As a condition for the issuance of a sidewalk café permit, the applicant shall furnish to the city clerk an indemnity agreement in the form approved by the city clerk binding the applicant to defend, indemnify, and hold harmless the city and any of its agencies, officials, officers, or employees from and against all claims, damages, liability, losses, costs, and expenses, including reasonable attorneys' fees, arising out of or resulting from any acts or omissions in connection with the operations of the applicant caused in whole or in part by the applicant, its employees, agents, or subcontractors, customers or caused by others for whom the applicant is liable, regardless of whether caused in part by any act or omission of city, its agencies, officials, officers, or employees. 
(3)  As a condition for the issuance of a sidewalk café permit, the applicant shall furnish the city a certificate of insurance from a company approved by the city clerk evidencing that the applicant has a comprehensive general liability and property damage policy meeting the following conditions: 
a.  Liability insurance with a combined single-limit policy of not less than $1,000,000.00. 
b.  The city shall be added as an additional insured to such policy by separate endorsement. 
c.  The policy shall contain a separate endorsement requiring the insurance company to notify the city in writing of any change in or cancellation of the policy at least ten days prior thereto. 
The applicant's failure to obtain or maintain the required insurance in effect for the duration of the permit shall immediately render the permit void. Notwithstanding the foregoing, the applicant shall remain obligated to indemnify and hold harmless the city and any of its agencies, officials, officers, or employees to the full extent required by the indemnity agreement required by this section. 
(4)  As a condition for the issuance of a sidewalk café permit, the applicant shall pay a fee of $10.00 per year. The amount due shall not be prorated for any partial year. 
(d)  Conduct of sidewalk café permit holder. A person or entity holding a sidewalk café permit (permittee) shall comply with all of the following conditions in connection with the placement of tables, chairs, umbrellas and pedestrian barriers on a sidewalk: 
(1)  Sidewalk café permits shall be conspicuously displayed at all times at the business for the permit area and shall be available for inspection by the building inspector, other city employees, and the public. 
(2)  Only tables, chairs, umbrellas and pedestrian barriers shall be permitted in the public right-of-way. 
(3)  No street or alley shall be blocked by tables, chairs and pedestrian barriers placed pursuant to a sidewalk café permit issued under this section. 
(4)  Permitted materials for outdoor dining furniture (tables, chairs, umbrellas and pedestrian barriers) are limited to iron (cast or wrought), steel (expanded or wire), aluminum (cast or extruded) metal alloy or wood. Resin is prohibited. 
(5)  Outdoor dining may be separated from the right-of-way by a minimum 30 inch tall pedestrian barrier (railing, fence or planters). Pedestrian barriers must be sturdy and stable, and must have sufficient weight so that they cannot tip or be blown over. Pedestrian barriers shall not be anchored to the sidewalk and shall be maintained so as not to stain or discolor the sidewalk. 
(6)  Advertising on umbrellas is permitted provided the product being advertised is sold by the restaurant. 
(7)  Outdoor heaters may be used if reviewed and approved by the fire chief; use of outdoor heaters is subject to any conditions prescribed by the fire chief. 
(8)  The permittee shall comply with all applicable laws, including the Americans with Disabilities Act. 
(9)  Tables, chairs and umbrellas shall be securely placed so that they will not endanger the public, or fall or protrude into any street or alley. 
(10)  Tables, chairs and umbrellas shall not be placed in a manner that creates or causes a nuisance, a fire hazard, or interferes with ingress to or from any building. 
(11)  Only tables, chairs and umbrellas for customer use may be placed and allowed to remain within the permit area. The permit area may not be used for the storage of other items. 
(12)  Tables, chairs, umbrellas and pedestrian barriers shall only be placed in front of the business holding a sidewalk café permit and shall not extend to sidewalks abutting and adjacent to other properties. Notwithstanding the foregoing, the tables and chairs may be placed in front of a property immediately abutting and immediately adjacent to the business holding the sidewalk café permit if the owner of record of the affected property consents in writing in a form approved by the city clerk and the same is thereafter approved by the board of aldermen; a property shall not be deemed to be immediately abutting and immediately adjacent if separated from the business holding the sidewalk café permit by a street or alley. 
(13)  Tables, chairs, umbrellas and pedestrian barriers shall not be placed in the street. 
(14)  Tables, chairs, umbrellas and pedestrian barriers shall be placed no less than four feet back from the front of the curb of the abutting street. 
(15)  Permittees shall be responsible for keeping all applicable permit areas to be neat, clean and free of trash and other debris. 
(e)  The provisions and terms of section 10-196 of the Code of Ordinances shall not apply to this section. 
( Ord. No. 1829 , § 1, 10-16-2017) 
Editor's note- Applications for a sidewalk café permit as referenced above has not been set out, but may be located at the city office. 
Chapter 12 - COURT[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal courts, RSMo ch. 479. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 12-1. - Established. 
    There is hereby established in this city a municipal court, to be known as the "Lamar Municipal Court, a Division of the 28th Judicial Circuit Court of the State of Missouri." This court is a continuation of the police court of the city as previously established, and is termed herein "the municipal court." 
(Code 1991, § 13-1; Ord. No. 1233, § 2(26.010), 11-6-1978) 
Sec. 12-2. - Jurisdiction. 
    The jurisdiction of the municipal court shall extend to all cases involving alleged violations of the ordinances of the city. 
(Code 1991, § 13-2; Ord. No. 1233, § 2(26.020), 11-6-1978) 
Sec. 12-3. - Superintending authority. 
    The municipal court of the city shall be subject to the rules of the circuit court of which it is a part, and to the rules of the state supreme court. The municipal court shall be subject to the general administrative authority of the presiding judge of the circuit court, and the judge and court personnel of the municipal court shall obey his directives. 
(Code 1991, § 13-3; Ord. No. 1233, § 2(26.070), 11-6-1978) 
Sec. 12-4. - Traffic violations bureau. 
    Should the municipal judge determine that there shall be a traffic violations bureau, the city shall provide all expenses incident to the operation of the bureau. 
(Code 1991, § 13-4; Ord. No. 1233, § 2(26.110), 11-6-1978) 
Sec. 12-5. - Issuance and execution of warrants. 
    All warrants issued by a municipal judge shall be directed to the chief of police, or any other police officer of the city or to the sheriff of the county. The warrant shall be executed by the chief of police, police officer or sheriff any place within the limits of the county and not elsewhere unless the warrants are endorsed in the manner provided for warrants in criminal cases, and, when so endorsed, shall be served in other counties, as provided for in warrants in criminal cases. 
(Code 1991, § 13-5; Ord. No. 1233, § 2(26.120), 11-6-1978) 
Sec. 12-6. - Arrests without warrants. 
    Any person may be arrested without a warrant by the chief of police or other police officer of the city if such person commits an offense in the officer's presence or the officer has probable cause to believe that a crime has been committed by the person subsequently arrested. 
(Code 1991, § 13-6; Ord. No. 1233, § 2(26.130), 11-6-1978) 
Sec. 12-7. - Jury trials. 
    Any person charged with a violation of a municipal ordinance of this city shall be entitled to a trial by jury, as in prosecutions for misdemeanors before an associate circuit judge. Whenever a defendant accused of a violation of a municipal ordinance demands trial by jury, the municipal court shall certify the case to the presiding judge of the circuit court for reassignment, as provided in RSMo 517.081. 
(Code 1991, § 13-7; Ord. No. 1233, § 2(26.140), 11-6-1978) 
Sec. 12-8. - Duties of the city's prosecuting attorney. 
    It shall be the duty of an attorney designated by the city to prosecute the violations of the city's ordinances before the municipal judge or before any circuit judge hearing violations of the city's ordinances. The salary or fees of the attorney and his necessary expenses incurred in such prosecutions shall be paid by the city. The compensation of such attorney shall not be contingent upon the result in any case. 
(Code 1991, § 13-8; Ord. No. 1233, § 2(26.150), 11-6-1978) 
Sec. 12-9. - Summoning of witnesses. 
    It shall be the duty of the municipal judge to summon all persons whose testimony may be deemed essential as witnesses at the trial, and to enforce their attendance by attachment, if necessary. The fees of witnesses shall be the same as those fixed for witnesses in trials before associate circuit judges and shall be taxed as other costs in the case. When a trial shall be continued by a municipal judge it shall not be necessary to summon any witnesses who may be present at the continuance; but the municipal judge shall orally notify such witnesses as either party may require to attend before him on the day set for trial to testify in the case, and enter the names of such witnesses on his docket, which oral notice shall be valid as a summons. 
(Code 1991, § 13-9; Ord. No. 1233, § 2(26.160), 11-6-1978) 
Sec. 12-10. - Transfer of complaint to associate circuit judge. 
    If, in the progress of any trial before a municipal judge, it shall appear to the judge that the accused ought to be put upon trial for an offense against the criminal laws of the state and not cognizable before him as municipal judge, he shall immediately stop all further proceedings before him as municipal judge and cause the complaint to be made before some associate circuit judge within the county. 
(Code 1991, § 13-10; Ord. No. 1233, § 2(26.170), 11-6-1978) 
Sec. 12-11. - Jailing of defendants. 
    If in the opinion of the municipal judge, the city has no suitable and safe place of confinement, the municipal judge may commit the defendant to the county jail, and it shall be the duty of the sheriff, if space for the prisoner is available in the county jail, upon receipt of a warrant of commitment from the judge to receive and safely keep such prisoner until discharged by due process of law. The city shall pay the board of such prisoner at the same rate as may now or hereafter be allowed to such sheriff for the keeping of such prisoner in his custody. The same shall be taxed as cost. 
(Code 1991, § 13-11; Ord. No. 1233, § 2(26.180), 11-6-1978) 
Sec. 12-12. - Parole and probation. 
    Any judge hearing violations of municipal ordinances may, when in his judgment it may seem advisable, grant a parole or probation to any person who shall plead guilty or who shall be convicted after a trial before the judge. 
(Code 1991, § 13-12; Ord. No. 1233, § 2(26.190), 11-6-1978) 
Sec. 12-13. - Right of appeal. 
(a)  Option A, where judge is a nonlawyer. The defendant shall have a right to a trial de novo before a circuit judge or an associate circuit judge. Such application for a trial de novo shall be filed within ten days after the judgment and shall be in the form as provided by supreme court rules. 
(b)  Option B, where judge is lawyer. In all cases tried before the municipal court, except where there has been a plea of guilty or where the case has been tried with a jury, the defendant shall have the right of trial de novo, before a circuit judge or on assignment before an associate circuit judge. An application for a trial de novo shall be filed within ten days after judgment and shall be filed in such form and perfected in such manner as provided by supreme court rules. 
(Code 1991, § 13-13; Ord. No. 1233, § 2(26.200), 11-6-1978) 
Sec. 12-14. - Appeal from jury verdicts. 
    In all cases in which a jury trial has been demanded, a record of the proceedings shall be made, and appeals may be had upon that record to the appropriate appellant court. 
(Code 1991, § 13-14; Ord. No. 1233, § 2(26.210), 11-6-1978) 
Sec. 12-15. - Breach of recognizance. 
    In the case of a breach of any recognizance entered into before a municipal judge or an associate circuit judge hearing a municipal ordinance violation case, the same shall be deemed forfeited and the judge shall cause the same to be prosecuted against the principal and surety, or either of them, in the name of the city as plaintiff. Such action shall be prosecuted before a circuit judge or associate circuit judge, and in the event of cases caused to be prosecuted by a municipal judge, such shall be on the transcript of the proceedings before the municipal judge. All moneys recovered in such actions shall be paid over to the municipal treasury to the general revenue fund of the city. 
(Code 1991, § 13-15; Ord. No. 1233, § 2(26.220), 11-6-1978) 
Sec. 12-16. - Clerk of municipal court. 
    The mayor shall appoint a clerk of the municipal court. The duties of said clerk shall be as follows: 
(1)  To collect such fines for violations of such offenses as may be authorized by the mayor, with the approval of the board of aldermen, and the court costs thereof. 
(2)  To take oaths and affirmations. 
(3)  To accept signed complaints, and allow the same to be signed and sworn to or affirmed before him. 
(4)  Sign and issue subpoenas requiring the attendance of witnesses and sign and issue subpoenas duces tecum. 
(5)  Accept the appearance, waiver of trial and plea of guilty and payment of fine and costs in traffic violations bureau cases or as directed by the municipal judge; generally act as violation clerk of the traffic violations bureau. 
(6)  Maintain, properly certified by the city clerk, a complete copy of the ordinances of the city of the municipality which shall constitute prima facie evidence of such ordinance before the court. Further, to maintain a similar certified copy on file with the clerk serving the circuit court of this county. 
(7)  Promptly pay into the city treasury the full amount of all fines collected by him during the preceding month. He shall take duplicate receipts for all such moneys paid in, one of which he shall file with the city clerk. 
(8)  Perform all other duties as provided for by ordinance, by rules of practice and procedure adopted by the municipal judge and by the Missouri Rules of Practice and Procedure in Municipal and Traffic Courts and by statute. 
(Code 1971, § 18-33; Code 1991, § 13-16; Ord. No. 1233, § 2(26.250), 11-6-1978) 
Sec. 12-17. - Court costs. 
    In addition to any fine that may be imposed by the municipal judge there shall be assessed as costs in all cases the following: 
(1)  Any person found guilty of a moving violation in the city shall have to pay court costs of $22.50 ($7.50 for the state and $15.00 for the city, which includes $3.00 for officer training as described in subsections (7) and (8) of this section). 
(2)  Costs for the issuance of an arrest warrant in the amount of $50.00 per warrant issued. 
(3)  Other costs, such as for the issuance of a commitment or a summons, as provided before the associate circuit judge in criminal prosecutions. 
(4)  Actual costs assessed against the city by the county sheriff for apprehension or confinement in the county jail. 
(5)  Mileage, in the same amount as provided to the sheriff in criminal violations, for each mile and fraction thereof the officer must travel (both directions) in order to serve any warrant or commitment or order of this court. 
(6)  Persons found guilty of charges containing more than one count may be required to pay an additional $10.50 cost for each count in excess of one count. 
(7)  The sum of $2.00 for the training of peace officers. This fee shall be transmitted monthly to the treasurer of the city. 
(8)  The sum of $1.00, which shall be deposited with the treasurer of the state in the peace officer standards and training commission fund, to be used statewide for training of peace officers. 
(Code 1991, § 13-17; Ord. No. 1233, § 2(26.260), 11-6-1978; Ord. No. 1407, 11-20-1989; Ord. No. 1501, §§ 1-3, 12-16-1996; Ord. No. 1607, § 1, 11-18-2002) 
State Law reference- Court costs, RSMo 479.260. 
Sec. 12-18. - Assessment against prosecuting witness. 
    The costs of any action may be assessed against the prosecuting witness and judgment be rendered against him that he pay the same and stand committed until paid in any case where it appears to the satisfaction of the municipal judge that the prosecution was commenced without probable cause and from malicious motives. 
(Code 1991, § 13-18; Ord. No. 1233, § 2(26.270), 11-6-1978) 
Sec. 12-19. - Installment payment of fine. 
    When a fine is assessed for violating an ordinance, it should be within the discretion of the judge assessing the fine to provide for the payment of a fine on an installment basis under such terms and conditions as he may deem appropriate. 
(Code 1991, § 13-19; Ord. No. 1233, § 2(26.280), 11-6-1978) 
Sec. 12-20. - Default in payment of fine-Imprisonment. 
(a)  When an offender sentenced to pay a fine defaults in the payment of the fine or in any installment, the municipal court, upon motion of the prosecuting attorney or upon its own motion, may require him to show cause why he should not be imprisoned for nonpayment. The court may issue a warrant of arrest or a summons for his appearance. 
(b)  Following an order to show cause under subsection (a) of this section, unless the offender shows that his default was not attributable to an intentional refusal to obey the sentence of the court, or not attributable to a failure on his part to make a good faith effort to obtain the necessary funds for payment, the court may order the defendant imprisoned for a term not to exceed 30 days for the conviction of a misdemeanor or infraction. The court may provide in its order that payment or satisfaction of the fine at any time will entitle the offender to his release from such imprisonment or, after entering the order, may at any time reduce the sentence for good cause shown, including payment or satisfaction of the fine. 
(Code 1991, § 13-20; Ord. No. 1376, §§ 1, 2, 1-18-1988) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 560.031. 
Sec. 12-21. - Same-Allowance of extra time. 
    If it appears that the default in the payment of a fine is excusable under the standards set forth in section 12-20, the court may enter an order allowing the offender additional time for payment, reducing the amount of the fine or of each installment, or revoking the fine or the unpaid portion in whole or in part. 
(Code 1991, § 13-21; Ord. No. 1376, § 3, 1-18-1988) 
Sec. 12-22. - Same-Collection. 
    Upon default in the payment of a fine or any installment thereof, the fine may be collected by any means authorized for the enforcement of money judgments. 
(Code 1991, § 13-22; Ord. No. 1376, § 4, 1-18-1988) 
Secs. 12-23-12-47. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - JUDGE 

Sec. 12-48. - Selection. 
    The judge of the city's municipal court shall be known as a municipal judge of the 28th Judicial Circuit Court. He shall be appointed to his position by the mayor, subject to the confirmation of the board of aldermen, for a term as specified herein. 
(Code 1991, § 13-46; Ord. No. 1233, § 2(26.030), 11-6-1978) 
Sec. 12-49. - Term of office. 
    The municipal judge shall hold his office for a period of two years and shall take office biannually from the second Tuesday in April of odd-numbered years. If for any reason a municipal judge vacates his office, his successor shall complete that term of office, even if the same is for less than two years. 
(Code 1991, § 13-47; Ord. No. 1233, § 2(26.040), 11-6-1978) 
Sec. 12-50. - Vacation of office. 
    The municipal judge shall vacate his office under the following circumstances: 
(1)  Upon removal from office by the state commission on the retirement, removal and discipline of judges, as provided in Missouri Supreme Court Rule 12; 
(2)  Upon attaining his 75th birthday; 
(3)  Option A, if not a lawyer, should he fail, within six months of his selection, to satisfactorily complete a course of instruction for municipal judge as prescribed by the state supreme court; or 
(4)  Option B, if a lawyer, if he should lose his license to practice law within the state. 
(Code 1991, § 13-48; Ord. No. 1233, § 2(26.050), 11-6-1978) 
Sec. 12-51. - Qualifications for office. 
    The municipal judge shall possess the following qualifications before he shall take office: 
(1)  He need not be a licensed attorney, qualified to practice law within the state. 
(2)  He need not reside within the city. 
(3)  He must be a resident of the state. 
(4)  He must be between the ages of 21 and 75 years. 
(5)  He may not hold any other office within the city government. 
(6)  If not a licensed attorney, he must, within six months after his selection to the position, satisfactorily complete a course of instruction for municipal judges as prescribed by the state supreme court. 
(7)  The municipal judge shall be considered holding a part-time position, and as such may accept (within the requirements of the Code of Judicial Conduct, Missouri Supreme Court Rule 2) other employment. 
(Code 1991, § 13-49; Ord. No. 1233, § 2(26.060), 11-6-1978) 
Sec. 12-52. - Monthly case list; payment of collected fines to treasurer.
