The board of aldermen shall cause plans and specifications for all projects, together with an estimate of the total cost for the projects, including construction, construction contingency and fees and other expenses, and an estimate of the portion of the total cost to be assessed against each property to be benefitted by the project, to be prepared by the designated city official or other proper officer, and filed with the clerk, subject to the inspection of the public, and shall cause notice thereof to be published in some newspaper printed in the county for two consecutive insertions in a weekly paper, and for seven consecutive insertions in a daily paper. 
(c)  Public hearing to be held on request of three or more citizens. A public hearing shall be held on the request of three or more citizens. At hearing citizens may express their assent or objection to the project. 
(d)  Construction contingency and expenses; interest. Special tax bills may include a reasonable construction contingency and an amount not to exceed 20 percent of the total cost of the improvement to be used for payment of fees and other expenses, and tax bills may bear interest not to exceed the rate on ten-year United States Treasury notes as established at the most recent auction. 
(e)  Due date. All tax bills shall become due and payable 60 days after the date of issue thereof, except in the case of tax bills payable in installments. 
(f)  Term of lien on property. Every special tax bill shall be a lien against the lot or tract or parcel of land described in said special tax bill for a period of ten years after date of issue, unless sooner paid, except in the case of special tax bills payable in installments, the lien of which shall not expire until one year after the date of maturity of the last installment, and except in any case where it becomes necessary to bring a suit to enforce the lien of any special tax bill, the lien of which shall continue until the expiration of the litigation. 
(Code 1991, § 22-109; Ord. No. 1515, 9-15-1997) 
Secs. 40-3-40-22. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - STREETS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 40-23. - Street names. 
(a)  The streets of the city shall be known and designated as follows: 
(1)  The street running north and south on the west side of the public square is hereby named Gulf Street and the streets proceeding west from Gulf Street are hereby named Cherry Street, Walnut Street, Maple Street and Oak Street. 
(2)  The street running north and south on the east side of the public square is hereby named Broadway and the streets running north and south proceeding east from Broadway are hereby named Poplar Street, Mill Street, Grand Avenue, Truman Avenue, Parry Street, Lexington Avenue, Jackson Avenue, Jefferson Avenue, Hagny Street, Allen Street and Howard Street. 
(3)  The streets running east and west, north of First Street in an unplatted tract commonly known as Mayo Addition shall be named as follows: 
a.  The first street north of First Street shall be named Arbor Drive. 
b.  The second street north of First Street shall be named Bluebell Drive. 
c.  The third street north of First Street shall be named Camellia Drive. 
d.  The fourth street north of First Street shall be named Dogwood Drive. 
(4)  The streets in Mayo Addition running north and south shall correspond to the nearest street running north and south, south of First Street, except that the last street to the east is hereby named Bartlett Drive, and except that the last street to the west is hereby named Mayo Street. 
(5)  The street lying along the half section line of Section 24, Township 32, Range 31 and the half section line of Section 19, Township 32, Range 30 is hereby named First Street and streets, except as hereinafter noted, running east and west proceeding south shall be numbered numerically, Second Street, Third Street and so on. 
(6)  The street running west from Broadway to Maple Street and immediately south of First Street is hereby named First Terrace. 
(7)  The first street east of Jackson Avenue in College Hill Addition, running north and south is hereby named College Street, the second, Heagon Street and the third, Francis Street. 
(8)  The streets in Lakeview Addition running east and west shall be named to correspond with the presently existing streets in the city commencing at the north and the first street to the north shall be named 16th Street, the next street 17th Street, the next 18th Street, the next 18th Terrace and the last 19th Street. The street running north and south, north from 19th Street to 16th Street and immediately east of Hagny is hereby named Lakeview Drive. 
(9)  The one existing street in Northridge Acres Addition is hereby named Northridge Drive. 
(10)  The streets running east and west from Truman Street and immediately north of Third Street are hereby named Second Terrace. 
(11)  The street running east from Poplar Street to Truman Street and immediately south of Third Street is hereby named Third Terrace. 
(12)  The street running east from Jefferson Street to a dead end and immediately south of Sixth Street is hereby named Sixth Terrace. 
(13)  The street running east from Howard Street to Wheeler Drive and immediately north of Eighth Street is hereby named Memorial Drive. 
(14)  The street running east from College Street to Heagon Street and immediately south of 16th Street is hereby named 16th Terrace. 
(b)  In the establishment of any new additions, streets therein shall be named, if possible, to correspond with any existing street with which it connects or with which it corresponds. 
(Code 1971, § 20-1; Code 1991, § 22-1; Ord. No. 1626, § 1, 4-19-2004; Ord. No. 1654, §§ 1-8, 7-18-2005) 
Sec. 40-24. - Street grade. 
(a)  Established by survey. The grades of the streets shall be established by topographic survey to the nearest 1/100 of a foot referenced to city datum as provided in this section. Plans shall be prepared for street construction and benchmarks established along the construction route at a rate of one per block by looping and closing the level circuit from the nearest established benchmark. Benchmarks shall be located outside the construction area and the elevations shown on plans. Elevations of the street shall include the centerline, gutter or ditch flow line and top of curb, if any, at a minimum of 100-foot intervals. 
(b)  Location and elevation of benchmark. The city datum is based on a U.S. Coast and Geodetic Survey brass cap disk benchmark stamped "Z 106 1934" and located nine feet northwest of the northwest corner of the post office located at 11th Street and Gulf Street. The elevation of the disk is 958.09 feet above sea level. 
(Code 1991, §§ 22-151, 22-156) 
State Law reference- Street grading damages, RSMo 88.080 et seq.; authority of city regarding grade of streets, RSMo 88.670(1), (2). 
Sec. 40-25. - Burning of trash, refuse in streets prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to burn any trash, brush, leaves or refuse in any of the streets in the city. 
(Code 1971, § 20-3; Code 1991, § 22-3) 
Secs. 40-26-40-53. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - EXCAVATIONS AND GAS LINE INSTALLATION 

Sec. 40-54. - Permit required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to cut into or excavate in or through any of the public streets within the corporate limits of the city for the installation, replacement, extension or repair of any water, sewer, gas, or other underground conduits or lines without first obtaining from the city clerk, or other proper city official, an excavation permit therefor and notification of Missouri One Call. 
(Code 1971, § 20-33; Code 1991, § 22-61) 
Sec. 40-55. - Excavation permit. 
(a)  Required; security deposit. Upon proper application by any person for an excavation permit to make an excavation in any street and upon a deposit by him in the amount provided in the city fee schedule, the city clerk, or other proper city official, shall issue such excavation permit subject to the conditions of other provisions of this Code pertaining to such work. 
(b)  Backfilling and tamping. Any excavation shall be filled and tamped by means of a hydraulic tamper by the agents or employees of the city, or by other approved means by agents or employees acceptable to the city, who shall patch or repair the surface of such excavation with material of a like kind that the street was surfaced with initially. 
(c)  Inspection; assessment of costs. Upon the completion of such work, after a charge has been made by the city for the actual cost of the city per hour for material and labor for refilling and tamping such excavation and a reasonable charge for the resurfacing of such excavation, based upon the reasonable cost thereof, has been made by the city, any excess of such deposit shall be returned to the person making such deposit. If the cost of such work done by the city should exceed the $50.00 deposit, the city shall bill the person to whom such permit was issued, who shall immediately pay to the city the additional amount due. 
(Code 1971, § 20-34; Code 1991, § 22-62) 
Sec. 40-56. - Water, sewer connections. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to cut into or excavate through any street in the city for the purpose of repairing, replacing or extending any water connection when the water main is located at either side of the street. In such event, the licensed plumber, after obtaining the proper permit, shall make an excavation at the side of such street and another excavation at the other side of such street where the connection is to be made with the water main or water line and the pipes shall then be pushed under such street by means of a pipe pusher; provided, however, that if an unusual circumstance exists where the use of a pipe pusher is impractical or impossible, the licensed plumber may cut into or excavate through the street if sufficient facts are shown to the satisfaction of the street commissioner. 
(b)  In the event that a connection is to be made with a water line or sewer located under any street in the city, it shall be lawful for any licensed plumber, after obtaining the proper permit, to make a cut or excavate into or through such street. 
(Code 1971, § 20-36; Code 1991, § 22-63) 
Sec. 40-57. - Notice to city upon completion of work. 
    It shall be the duty of the person granted a permit to make an excavation to immediately notify the city when the work is completed and the excavation is ready to be refilled and tamped. 
(Code 1971, § 20-37; Code 1991, § 22-64) 
Sec. 40-58. - Gas line installation standards. 
(a)  Permit required. Any person desiring to cut into or excavate through any street in the city for the purpose of laying, repairing, replacing, extending or connecting any gas line shall first obtain an excavation permit from the city clerk as provided in this division. 
(b)  Installation when existing gas line is under the street. If a connection is to be made with a gas line under any street in the city, any licensed gas supplier, after obtaining the proper permit, may make a cut or excavate into or through such street. 
(c)  Installation when existing gas line is located beside the street. If a present gas service line is located at either side of the street, rather than under the street, it is unlawful for the gas supplier to cut into or excavate through the street for the purpose of laying, repairing, replacing or extending any gas service lines. In such event, the gas supplier, after obtaining the proper permit, shall make an excavation at the side of the street and another excavation at another side of such street where the connection is to be made with the gas line, and the pipes shall then be pushed under the street by means of a pipe pusher; provided, however, that if an unusual circumstance exists where the use of a pipe pusher is impractical or impossible, the licensed gas supplier may cut into or excavate through the street if sufficient facts are shown to the satisfaction of the street commissioner. 
(d)  Materials. Any installation, extension, repair or replacement of any gas line within the confines of any street shall be made with material required by the gas company. 
(e)  Depth. Gas lines installed shall be buried at a depth of not less than 30 inches. 
(Code 1971, §§ 20-44-20-49; Code 1991, §§ 22-76-22-79) 
Secs. 40-59-40-89. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - IMPROVEMENTS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Authority of city regarding street improvements, RSMo 88.667 et seq. 

Subdivision I. - In General 

Sec. 40-90. - Estimation of cost. 
    When the board of aldermen shall deem it necessary to pave, macadamize, gutter, curb (when such is set out in the street beyond the sidewalk) or otherwise improve any street or highway, or any part thereof, within the limits of the city, or to improve the squares and areas formed by the crossing or meeting of such streets or highways, or parts thereof, or connections therewith, the board shall first instruct the designated city official, or other proper officer, to make an estimate of the cost of the improvements proposed to be made, who shall at once proceed to make such estimate and submit the same, with plans and specifications of the work and improvements proposed to be done, to the board of aldermen, as soon thereafter as practicable; provided, however, that no such estimate shall be required for making any local or special repairs. 
(Code 1971, § 20-60; Code 1991, § 22-101) 
Sec. 40-91. - Notice; protest. 
    When the designated city official has returned the plans and specifications and estimate of the cost to the board of aldermen, as provided in section 40-90, the board shall, before proceeding further with such improvements, by resolution, declare such work or improvements necessary to be done and cause such resolution to be published for seven consecutive insertions in a daily paper or two consecutive insertions in a weekly paper, published in the city. 
(Code 1971, § 20-61; Code 1991, § 22-102) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 88.700. 
Sec. 40-92. - Advertisement for bids. 
(a)  The board of aldermen shall, by an order made of record, direct the city clerk to advertise for bids for doing the proposed work or making the proposed improvements, by advertisement for not less than one week in some newspaper published in the city. The notice shall state: 
(1)  That the city clerk shall receive all such bids; 
(2)  That such improvements to be made or work to be done shall be in accordance with the plans and specifications filed therefor by the designated city official, or other officer designated by the board of aldermen with the city clerk; 
(3)  That the board of aldermen will receive no bid exceeding the estimate of the designated city official or other proper officer designated by the board of aldermen; 
(4)  That the board reserves the right to reject any and all bids; 
(5)  The date when such bids will be opened and the contract awarded; and 
(6)  That the contract for such work or improvements will be let to the lowest and best bidder. 
(b)  If after advertising no bid is received which the board of aldermen can lawfully accept, they may direct the city clerk to again advertise for bids as in the first instance. 
(Code 1971, § 20-62; Code 1991, § 22-103) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 88.700. 
Sec. 40-93. - Bond. 
    At the first regular meeting of the board of aldermen after the board shall have accepted any bid for work or improvements within the purview of this division, the successful bidder shall file with the city clerk a bond, payable to the city with two or more good and sufficient sureties, in such sum as the board of aldermen may direct, conditioned for the faithful performance of the contract, which contract shall be made and entered into as provided in this division. 
(Code 1971, § 20-63; Code 1991, § 22-104) 
Sec. 40-94. - Contract. 
    Upon the approval of the bond required by this division, by the board of aldermen, the mayor shall, on behalf of the city, enter into a contract with the successful bidder. Such contract shall be an agreement upon the part of such bidder to faithfully perform such work or make such improvements within the scope of this division in a skillful and workmanlike manner, within the time specified therein, according to the plans and specifications filed by the designated city official, or other proper officer, of the materials designated, and to do and perform all other things in the manner and according to the terms and provisions of such contract. 
(Code 1971, § 20-64; Code 1991, § 22-105) 
Sec. 40-95. - Inspections. 
    All work under the contract entered into under the provisions of this division shall be carried on under the supervision of the designated city official, or other proper officer designated by the board of aldermen, who shall personally inspect the work as it progresses, and see that the same is done in accordance with the plans, specifications and contract governing the same. Each part thereof must be approved before that portion of the work next to follow is commenced. 
(Code 1971, § 20-65; Code 1991, § 22-106) 
Sec. 40-96. - Minor improvements. 
(a)  If the board of aldermen deems it necessary to pave, macadamize, gutter, curb, grade or otherwise improve the roadways of any street or avenue for a distance of not more than 1,200 feet in length, so as to connect at both ends with paving, macadamizing, guttering, curbing, grading or other improvements, either on the same street or avenue or other streets or avenues, or on the same street or avenue and another street or avenue, the board of aldermen shall declare such work necessary to be done and shall cause the same proceedings to be had as hereinabove provided for, except that no protest may be filed. 
(b)  The resolution passed and published, as provided for in section 40-91, shall state the fact that anyone desiring to do so may appear before the board of aldermen at a time stated therein and be heard on the question of the necessity of the work sought to be done. If anyone does so appear, he shall be heard, and the board of aldermen shall, by resolution, state the result of such hearing to be a reaffirmance of the necessity for the doing of such work or the contrary, as the board of aldermen may then decide. If no one appears, or if the board of aldermen reaffirms the necessity of the doing of such work and improvement, then it shall proceed with such work and improvement as herein provided for when no sufficient protest against such improvement is filed within the time limit therefor. 
(Code 1971, § 20-66; Code 1991, § 22-107) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 88.707. 
Sec. 40-97. - Limited street improvement costs; special tax bills. 
(a)  The board of aldermen shall have power, by ordinance, in all cases where the cost does not exceed $2.00 per front foot per annum upon the property abutting upon any street, avenue, alley or public place to be improved, to cause the streets, avenues, alleys and public places of the city, or any part thereof, to be sprinkled, oiled, repaired, surfaced and resurfaced. The cost of such work shall be provided for and defrayed by a special tax to be assessed in favor of the city or contractor on the adjoining property fronting or bordering on the streets, avenues, alleys and public places where such sprinkling, oiling, repairing, surfacing and resurfacing is proposed to be done, in proportion that the linear feet of each lot fronting or bordering on the street, avenue, alley and public place to be sprinkled, oiled, repaired, surfaced and resurfaced bears to the total number of linear feet of all the property chargeable with the special tax in the territory embraced by the contract under which the sprinkling, oiling, repairing, surfacing and resurfacing is to be done. Property owners adjoining improvements shall agree to their cost share. 
(b)  Such work may be done by the city and an accurate account of the cost thereof kept by the city or may be contracted for annually by the board of aldermen at such time and under such terms as shall be provided by ordinance. 
(Code 1971, § 20-67; Code 1991, § 22-108) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 88.811. 
Secs. 40-98-40-122. - Reserved. 
Subdivision II. - Assessments[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Authority of city to levy special assessment, RSMo 88.680. 

Sec. 40-123. - Designation. 
    All assessments made for paving, macadamizing, curbing, guttering, excavating and grading all streets or highways, or connections therewith, and repairing the same, shall be known as special assessments for improvements and shall be levied and collected as a special tax and a special tax bill shall issue therefor, as herein provided. 
(Code 1971, § 20-72; Code 1991, § 22-121) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 88.812. 
Sec. 40-124. - Register. 
    The city clerk shall enter an abstract of all special tax bills within the purview of this division in a book to be kept for that purpose, known and designated as the "register of special assessments for improvements," wherein shall be shown the date and number of the tax bill, the name of the owner and description of the property, the date of the approval of the ordinance levying such special assessment, the amount of the tax, when due, and when and by whom paid. 
(Code 1971, § 20-73; Code 1991, § 22-122) 
Secs. 40-125-40-158. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - SIDEWALKS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 40-159-40-254. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - REPAIR AND MAINTENANCE 

Sec. 40-255. - Maintenance by property owner. 
    All sidewalks in the city shall at all times be kept in good repair by the owner of the property fronting or abutting thereon. 
(Code 1971, § 20-144; Code 1991, § 22-231) 
Sec. 40-256. - Inspection. 
    It shall be the duty of the city inspector to inspect all sidewalks in the city and, when he observes, or is notified by any person that any sidewalk, or portion thereof, is out of repair, he shall immediately inspect the same. 
(Code 1971, § 20-145; Code 1991, § 22-232) 
Sec. 40-257. - Notice to property owner; repair by city. 
    If the city inspector finds any sidewalk, or portion thereof, out of repair, he shall give written or printed notice to the owner, occupant or agent of the lot or piece of ground fronting or abutting on such walk, or portion thereof, to repair such walk, or portion thereof, within one week from the date of serving such notice. If such owner, occupant or agent shall not, within the time designated, repair such walk, or portion thereof, then the city inspector shall make such repairs. If the lot or piece of ground fronting or abutting on such sidewalk shall be vacant or unoccupied and the owner and agent unknown or nonresidents of the city, then the city inspector may make such repairs without notice. 
(Code 1971, § 20-146; Code 1991, § 22-233) 
Sec. 40-258. - Records; reports. 
    The city inspector shall keep an accurate account of the cost of all repairs made pursuant to this division, and shall report the same to the board of aldermen for assessment. 
(Code 1971, § 20-147; Code 1991, § 22-234) 
Chapter 42 - SUBDIVISIONS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Subdivision regulations, RSMo 89.410; plats, RSMo ch. 445. 

Sec. 42-1. - Acceptance generally. 
    Before any addition to the city, or subdivision within the city, shall be accepted by the city, the board of aldermen shall, by ordinance, establish the same and declare it to be a part of the city. 
(Code 1971, § 21-1; Code 1991, § 23-1) 
State Law reference- Acceptance of plat, RSMo 445.030. 
Sec. 42-2. - Two plats required; recording, filing. 
    No addition to the city nor any subdivision within the city shall be regarded as a plat of the city until two full and complete plats of such addition or subdivision shall be made out, one of which shall be recorded in the office of the recorder of deeds of the county and the other shall be filed in the office of the city clerk. 
(Code 1971, § 21-2; Code 1991, § 23-2) 
Sec. 42-3. - Streets. 
(a)  The plats required by this chapter shall show that all streets of the city, which if prolonged in straight lines, would occupy any portion of the land in the proposed addition or subdivision, have been laid out the full width and entirely through the length and breadth of such addition or subdivision. 
(b)  The plats required by this chapter shall show that all of the streets in the proposed addition or subdivision have been dedicated to the public use forever. 
(c)  The plat shall not be approved by the city until grading and drainage plans and utility plans have been submitted and approved by the city. 
(d)  The streets in the proposed addition shall be so laid out as to correspond with the prolongations of existing streets, as far as practicable and not inconsistent with the provisions of subsection (c) of this section. 
(Code 1971, § 21-3; Code 1991, § 23-3) 
Sec. 42-4. - Construction of chapter. 
    Nothing in this chapter shall be construed to bind the city to recognize any addition to the city, or subdivision within the city, heretofore made by any person not in conformity with the specifications of this chapter, or as authority for any person to grade, macadamize or repair any street or sidewalk therein. 
(Code 1971, § 21-4; Code 1991, § 23-4) 
Chapter 44 - TAXATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal taxation, RSMo 94.190 et seq.; taxation and revenue, RSMo ch. 135 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 44-1. - Establishment of rate of annual tax levy. 
    Upon receipt each year by the mayor, from the clerk of the county court, of a certified abstract from his assessment books of all property within the city subject to taxation by the state and the assessed value thereof as agreed upon by the board of equalization, the mayor shall immediately transmit the same to the board of aldermen; and the board of aldermen shall, within a reasonable time thereafter, ascertain the amount of money to be raised thereon for general and other purposes and proceed by ordinance to establish the rate of tax levy for the year. 
(Code 1971, § 22-2; Code 1991, § 24-2) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 94.190(3). 
Sec. 44-2. - Board to provide for levy, collection of taxes. 
    The board of aldermen shall, from time to time, provide by ordinance for the levy and collection of all taxes, licenses and other duties not herein enumerated, and for neglect or refusal to pay the same, shall fix such penalties as are now or may hereafter be authorized by law or ordinance. 
(Code 1971, § 22-3; Code 1991, § 24-3) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 94.200. 
Sec. 44-3. - Board not to exempt any person from tax. 
    The mayor and board of aldermen shall have no power to release any person from the payment of any tax, or exempt any person from any burden imposed by law. 
(Code 1971, § 22-4; Code 1991, § 24-4) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 94.240. 
Sec. 44-4. - City clerk to make tax books. 
    When the board of aldermen shall have fixed the rate of taxation for any given year, the city clerk shall make out appropriate and accurate tax books, and shall therein set out in suitable columns, opposite the name of each person and the item of taxable property, as returned by the assessor and board of equalization, the amount of taxes, whether general or special, due thereon. 
(Code 1971, § 22-5; Code 1991, § 24-5) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 94.290. 
Sec. 44-5. - City clerk to pay into treasury all funds collected. 
    It shall be the duty of the city clerk to pay into the treasury monthly all moneys received by him from all sources, which may be levied by law or ordinance, also all licenses of every description authorized by law to be collected, and all moneys belonging to the city which may come into his hands; and he shall receive credit therefor. 
(Code 1971, §§ 22-6, 22-22; Code 1991, § 24-6) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 94.330. 
Sec. 44-6. - Ex officio tax attorney designated; compensation for collection of delinquent taxes. 
    The city attorney shall be the ex officio tax attorney of the city. As full compensation for the ex officio tax attorney's services in bringing suit on all delinquent tax bills or the compromise thereof, he shall receive a reasonable fee, to be paid by the defendant or defendants in such suit. 
(Code 1971, §§ 22-1, 22-26; Code 1991, §§ 24-1, 24-38) 
Sec. 44-7. - Compensation of collector. 
    The designated collector for the city shall be the county treasurer who shall be allowed as compensation for the collection of all current taxes the sum of three percent of all such taxes collected. 
(Code 1991, §§ 24-11, 24-40; Ord. No. 1303, § 1, 5-2-1983) 
Secs. 44-8-44-32. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - SPECIFIC TAXES 

Sec. 44-33. - Merchant ad valorem tax. 
    All merchants of this city shall pay an ad valorem tax, equal to the tax levied by the board of aldermen upon real estate, upon the amount of goods, wares and merchandise which their sworn statement filed on the first Monday of May in each year with the county assessor shows them to possess. 
(Code 1971, § 22-7; Code 1991, § 24-7) 
State Law reference- Merchants' tax, RSMo 150.010 et seq. 
Sec. 44-34. - Sales tax. 
(a)  Pursuant to the authority granted by and subject to the provisions of RSMo 94.500 to 94.570, a tax for general revenue purposes is hereby imposed upon all sellers for the privilege of engaging in the business of selling tangible personal property or rendering taxable services at retail to the extent and in the manner provided in RSMo 144.010 to 144.510, and the rules and regulations of the state director of revenue issued pursuant thereto. The rate of the tax shall be one percent on the receipts from the sale at retail of all tangible personal property or taxable services at retail within the city, if such property and services are subject to taxation by the state under the provisions of RSMo 144.010 to 144.510. The tax shall become effective as provided in RSMo 94.510(4), and shall be collected pursuant to the provisions of RSMo 94.500 to 94.570. 
(b)  In addition, there are hereby imposed: 
(1)  A one-half cent sales tax for construction, reconstruction, repair and maintenance of city roads and bridges within the city and for the construction, reconstruction, repair and maintenance of airports owned and operated by the city and for the acquisition of lands and rights-of-way for streets, roads, bridges and airports; and 
(2)  A one-half cent sales tax for the purpose of funding capital improvements which may be funded by issuing bonds. 
(Code 1991, §§ 24-8, 24-9; Ord. No. 1263, § 1, 7-21-1980; Ord. No. 1366, § 1, 9-3-1987; Ord. No. 1367, § 1, 9-3-1987) 
State Law reference- City Sales Tax Act, RSMo 94.500 et seq. 
Secs. 44-35-44-56. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - ENFORCEMENT AND COLLECTION 

Sec. 44-57. - Enforcement of payment. 
    The enforcement of all city taxes authorized by this Code shall be made in the same manner and under the same rules and regulations as is provided by law for the collection and enforcement of the payment of state and county taxes, including the seizure and sale of goods and chattels after such taxes shall become delinquent; provided, however, that all suits for the collection of city taxes shall be brought in the name of the state at the relation and to the use of the designated city official. 
(Code 1971, § 22-8; Code 1991, § 24-10) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 94.310. 
Sec. 44-58. - Date of delinquency; lien on real property. 
    Upon January 1 of each year, all unpaid city taxes shall become delinquent, and the taxes upon real property are hereby made a lien thereon against all persons in favor of the city. 
(Code 1971, § 22-19; Code 1991, § 24-31) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 94.300. 
Sec. 44-59. - Duty of attorney to file suit; compromise. 
    It shall be the duty of the ex officio tax attorney to bring suits on all delinquent tax bills and to prosecute the same to a final determination. He shall have the power and authority to compromise any suit for the collection of delinquent taxes when in his judgment it will be in the interest of the city. 
(Code 1971, § 22-25; Code 1991, § 24-37) 
Sec. 44-60. - Interest penalty. 
    A penalty of one percent shall be added to all city taxes remaining due and unpaid on January 1 of each year; and upon the first day of each month thereafter upon which city taxes shall remain due and unpaid, an additional penalty of one percent shall be added thereto. 
(Code 1971, § 22-27; Code 1991, § 24-39) 
Chapter 46 - TRAFFIC AND VEHICLES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Model traffic ordinance, RSMo ch. 300; registration and licensing of motor vehicles, RSMo ch. 301; drivers' and chauffeurs' licenses, RSMo ch. 302; motor vehicle financial responsibility, RSMo ch. 303; traffic regulations, RSMo ch. 304; municipal traffic regulations, RSMo 304.120; general penalty for violation of traffic regulation statutes, RSMo 304.570; vehicle equipment, RSMo ch. 307. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 46-1. - Model traffic ordinance adopted. 
    RSMo ch. 300, consisting of RSMo 300.010 through 300.600, commonly known as the state model traffic ordinance is hereby adopted as and for the traffic ordinance of the city, with like effect as if recited at length herein, with the exception of the following sections which are not so adopted and which are specifically deleted: RSMo 300.015 to 300.070 inclusive, 300.110, 300.115, 300.120, 300.320 and 300.415. 
(Code 1971, § 12-1; Code 1991, § 12-1; Ord. No. 1613, § 1, 4-14-2003; Ord. No. 1821 , § 1, 6-19-2017) 
State Law reference- Authority of city to adopt model traffic ordinance by reference, RSMo 300.600. 
Sec. 46-2. - Amendment to model traffic ordinance. 
    Wherever the term "city traffic engineer" is used in the model traffic ordinance adopted by this chapter, the term "city administrator" shall be substituted therefor. 
(Code 1971, § 12-2; Code 1991, § 12-2) 
Sec. 46-3. - Violations of model traffic ordinance. 
    Unless another penalty is expressly provided by law, every person convicted of a violation of any provision of the model traffic ordinance adopted by this chapter shall be punished as provided in section 1-9. 
(Code 1971, § 12-3; Code 1991, § 12-3) 
Sec. 46-4. - One-way streets and alleys. 
    Upon those streets and parts of streets and in those alleys described and designated by ordinance, vehicular traffic shall move only in the indicated direction when signs indicating the direction of traffic are erected and maintained at every intersection where movement in the opposite direction is prohibited. 
(1)  Sixth Street from the east edge of Maple Street to the west edge of Gulf Street is declared as a public street running one way from west to east. 
(2)  Seventh Street from the west edge of Gulf Street to the east edge of Maple Street is declared as a public street running one way from east to west. 
(3)  Lamar City Park. Streets located within the Lamar City Park that are posted or marked as one-way streets are hereby declared as public streets running one way in the directions indicated by applicable signs and/or markings. 
(4)  Alleyway north of city hall, specifically described as south of Lot 2, Block 29, and north of Lot 1, Block 34, in the original town of Lamar, Barton County, Missouri, is hereby declared as a public alleyway running one way from east to west. 
(5)  Walnut Street from the north edge of Seventh Street to the south edge of Sixth Street running one way from south to north. 
(Code 1991, § 12-4; Ord. No. 1266, § 1, 8-18-1980; Ord. No. 1790, § 1, 6-22-2015; Ord. No. 1797, § 1, 11-16-2015; Ord. No. 1805, § 1, 5-16-2016) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 300.245. 
Sec. 46-5. - Motor vehicles, trailers to be registered with department of revenue. 
(a)  No person shall operate any motor vehicle or trailer upon any street or highway within the city unless such motor vehicle or trailer is currently registered with the department of revenue in accordance with RSMo 301.020. 
(b)  Any person violating the provisions of this section shall be fined not less than $5.00 nor more than $200.00 for any such conviction. 
(Ord. No. 1801, § 1, 3-21-2016) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 301.020. 
Sec. 46-6. - License plates; display; tabs to be used. 
(a)  No person shall operate any motor vehicle or trailer upon any street or highway within the city unless such motor vehicle or trailer has properly displayed a valid license plate or temporary permit issued to the lawful owner of the vehicle by the department of revenue of the state, except that any person who is a nonresident of the state may operate any motor vehicle or trailer upon any street or highway of the city, provided the motor vehicle or trailer has been duly registered for the current year in the state, county or other place of which the owner is a resident, and provided that at all times such motor vehicle or trailer is being operated or parked upon the streets or highways of this city the valid license plate or temporary permit is properly displayed on such vehicle or trailer. License plates shall be securely fastened to such motor vehicles or trailers in accordance with the laws of the state of issuance. 
(b)  License plate tabs shall be affixed to license plates in accordance with the laws of the state of issuance. 
(c)  Any person violating the provisions of this section shall be fined not less than $5.00 nor more than $200.00 for any such conviction. 
(Ord. No. 1801, § 2, 3-21-2016) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 301.130. 
Sec. 46-7. - Displaying motor vehicle or trailer plates of another; failure to transfer plates within 30 days. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for a person to operate any motor vehicle or trailer upon any street or highway within the city with license plates affixed thereto which are assigned to another motor vehicle or trailer, unless such license plates are affixed to a newly acquired motor vehicle consistent with and as specifically authorized by RSMo 301.140. 
(b)  Any person violating the provisions of this section shall be fined not less than $5.00 nor more than $200.00 for any such conviction. 
(Ord. No. 1801, § 3, 3-21-2016) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions. RSMo 301.140. 
Sec. 46-8. - Temporary instruction permits; intermediate driver's licenses. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for a person to operate, or to permit another person to operate, any motor vehicle upon any street or highway within the city in violation of RSMo 302.130, pertaining to temporary instruction permits, or RSMo 302.178, pertaining to intermediate driver's licenses. 
(b)  Any person violating the provisions of this section shall be sentenced to pay a fine not to exceed $200.00 for any such conviction. 
(Ord. No. 1801, § 4, 3-21-2016) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 302.178. 
Sec. 46-9. - Unlicensed person operating motor vehicle prohibited. 
(a)  No person shall authorize or knowingly permit a motor vehicle owned by such person or under such person's control to be driven upon any street or highway within the city by any person who is not authorized to drive or in violation of any of the provisions of RSMo 302.010-302.260. 
(b)  Any person violating the provisions of this section shall be sentenced to pay a fine which, combined with court costs, shall not exceed $300.00 for any such conviction. 
(Ord. No. 1801, § 5, 3-21-2016) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 302.260. 
Sec. 46-10. - Motorists to exercise highest degree of care. 
    Every person operating a motor vehicle on the roads and highways of this state shall drive the vehicle in a careful and prudent manner and at a rate of speed so as not to endanger the property of another or the life or limb of any person and shall exercise the highest degree of care. 
( Ord. No. 1821 , § 2, 6-19-2017) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 304.012. 
Sec. 46-11. - Distance at which vehicle must follow, penalty. 
    The driver of a vehicle shall not follow another vehicle more closely than is reasonably safe and prudent, having due regard for the speed of such vehicle and the traffic upon and the condition of the roadway. Vehicles being driven upon any roadway outside of a business or residence district in a caravan or motorcade, whether or not towing other vehicles, shall be so operated, except in a funeral procession or in a duly authorized parade, so as to allow sufficient space between each such vehicle or combination of vehicles as to enable any other vehicle to overtake or pass such vehicles in safety. 
( Ord. No. 1821 , § 3, 6-19-2017) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 304.017. 
Sec. 46-12. - Leaving the scene of an accident-Penalties. 
(a)  A person commits the offense of leaving the scene of an accident when: 
(1)  Being the operator of a vehicle involved in an accident resulting in damage to property of another person; and 
(2)  Having knowledge of such accident he or she leaves the place of the damage or accident without stopping and giving the following information to the other party or to a law enforcement officer, or if no law enforcement officer is in the vicinity, then to the nearest law enforcement agency: 
a.  His or her name; 
b.  His or her residence, including city and street number; 
c.  The registration or license number for his or her vehicle; and 
d.  His or her operator's license number, if any. 
(b)  For the purposes of this section, all law enforcement officers shall have jurisdiction, when invited by a person whose property has been damaged, to enter the premises of any privately owned property for the purpose of investigating an accident and performing all necessary duties regarding such accident. 
(c)  Any person violating the provisions of this section shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished by a fine not exceeding $500.00, or by imprisonment not exceeding 90 days, or by both such fine and imprisonment. 
(d)  This section shall not apply if: 
(1)  Physical injury was caused to another person; or 
(2)  Damage in excess of $1,000.00 was caused to the property of another person; or 
(3)  The person violating this section has previously been found guilty of any offense in violation of this section; or committed in another jurisdiction which, if committed in this state, would be a violation of RSMo 577.060. 
( Ord. No. 1821 , § 4, 6-19-2017) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 577.060. 
Sec. 46-13. - Operation of motor vehicle without proper license prohibited, penalty-Motorcycles-Special license-Protective headgear, failure to wear, fine. 
(a)  Unless otherwise provided for by law, it shall be unlawful for any person, except those expressly exempted by RSMo 302.080 to: 
(1)  Operate any vehicle upon any road or highway in this city unless the person has a valid license; 
(2)  Operate a motorcycle or motortricycle upon any road or highway of this city unless such person has a valid license that shows the person has successfully passed an examination for the operation of a motorcycle or motortricycle as prescribed by the director; 
(3)  Authorize or knowingly permit a motorcycle or motortricycle owned by such person or under such person's control to be driven upon any road or highway in this city by any person whose license does not indicate that the person has passed the examination for the operation of a motorcycle or motortricycle or has been issued an instruction permit therefor; 
(4)  Operate a motor vehicle with an instruction permit or license issued to another person. 
(b)  Every person operating or riding as a passenger on any motorcycle or motortricycle, as defined in RSMo 301.010, upon any road or highway of this city shall wear protective headgear at all times the vehicle is in motion. The protective headgear shall meet reasonable standards and specifications established by the director. 
(c)  Definitions. As used in this section, the following terms mean: 
    Director means the Missouri Director of Revenue acting directly or through the director's authorized officers and agents. 
    License means a license issued by a state to a person which authorizes a person to operate a motor vehicle. 
    Motor vehicle means any self-propelled vehicle not operated exclusively upon tracks except motorized bicycles, as defined in RSMo 307.180. 
    Motorcycle means a motor vehicle operated on two wheels; however, this definition shall not include motorized bicycles as defined in RSMo 301.010. 
    Motortricycle means a motor vehicle operated on three wheels, including a motorcycle operated with any conveyance, temporary or otherwise, requiring the use of a third wheel. 
    Vehicle means any mechanical device on wheels, designed primarily for use, or used on highways, except motorized bicycles, vehicles propelled or drawn by horses or human power, or vehicles used exclusively on fixed rails or tracks, or cotton trailers or motorized wheelchairs operated by handicapped persons. 
(d)  Penalties. 
(1)  Unless another penalty is expressly provided by law or ordinance, every person convicted of a violation of any provision of this section shall be punished as provided in section 1-9. 
(2)  A person found guilty of failure to wear protective headgear as required by section (b) of this section shall be punished by a fine not to exceed $25.00. 
(3)  Notwithstanding all other provisions of law and court rules to the contrary, no court costs shall be imposed upon any person due to violation of any provision of this section. 
( Ord. No. 1821 , § 6, 6-19-2017) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 302.020. 
Sec. 46-14. - Duty to maintain financial responsibility, residents and nonresidents, misdemeanor penalty for failure to maintain-Exception, methods-Court to notify department of revenue, additional punishment, right of appeal. 
(a)  No owner of a motor vehicle registered in this state, or required to be registered in this state, shall operate, register or maintain registration of a motor vehicle, or permit another person to operate such vehicle within this city, unless the owner maintains the financial responsibility which conforms to the requirements of the laws of this state. No nonresident shall operate or permit another person to operate in this city a motor vehicle registered to such nonresident unless the non-resident maintains the financial responsibility which conforms to the requirements of the laws of the nonresident's state of residence. Furthermore, no person shall operate a motor vehicle owned by another with the knowledge that the owner has not maintained financial responsibility unless such person has financial responsibility which covers the person's operation of the other's vehicle; however, no owner or nonresident shall be in violation of this subsection if he or she fails to maintain financial responsibility on a motor vehicle which is inoperable or being stored and not in operation. 
(b)  A motor vehicle owner shall maintain the owner's financial responsibility in a manner provided for in RSMo 303.160 or with a motor vehicle liability policy which conforms to the requirements of the laws of this state. A nonresident motor vehicle owner shall maintain the owner's financial responsibility which conforms to the requirements of the laws of the nonresident's state of residence. 
(c)  An insurance identification card shall be carried in the insured motor vehicle at all times. The operator of an insured motor vehicle shall exhibit the insurance identification card on the demand of any police officer, peace officer, commercial vehicle enforcement officer or commercial vehicle inspector who lawfully stops such operator or investigates an accident while that officer or inspector is engaged in the performance of the officer's or inspector's duties. If the operator fails to exhibit an insurance identification card, the officer or inspector shall issue a citation to the operator for a violation of this section. A motor vehicle liability insurance policy, a motor vehicle liability insurance binder, receipt, or a photocopy or an image displayed on a mobile electronic device which contains the policy information required in RSMo 303.024(2), shall be satisfactory evidence of insurance in lieu of an insurance identification card. The display of an image of the insurance card on a mobile electronic device shall not serve as consent for such officer, inspector, or other person to access other contents of the mobile electronic device in any manner other than to verify the image of the insurance card. As used in this section, the term "mobile electronic device" means any small handheld computing or communications device that has a display screen with a touch input or a miniature keyboard. Whenever a person presents a mobile electronic device as proof of financial responsibility to any peace officer, commercial vehicle enforcement officer, or commercial vehicle inspector pursuant to this section, that person shall assume all liability for any damage to the mobile electronic device, except for damage willfully or maliciously caused by a police officer, peace officer, commercial vehicle enforcement officer, or commercial vehicle inspector. 
(d)  No person shall be found guilty of violating this section if the operator demonstrates to the court that he or she met the financial responsibility requirements of this section at the time the peace officer, commercial vehicle enforcement officer or commercial vehicle inspector wrote the citation. 
(e)  As used in this section the following words and phrases shall mean: 
    Chauffeur means a person who is employed for the principal purpose of operating a motor vehicle or any person who drives a motor vehicle while in use as a public or common carrier of persons or property for hire. 
    Director means director of revenue of the State of Missouri, acting directly or through his authorized officers and agents. 
    License means an operator's or driver's license, temporary instruction permit, chauffeur's or registered operator's license issued under the laws of this state. 
    Motor vehicle means a self-propelled vehicle which is designed for use upon a highway, except trailers designed for use with such vehicles, traction engines, road rollers, farm tractors, tractor cranes, power shovels, well drillers and motorized bicycles, as defined in RSMo 307.180, and every vehicle which is propelled by electric power obtained from overhead wires but not operated upon rails. 
    Nonresident means a person not a resident of the State of Missouri. 
    Nonresident's operating privilege means the privilege conferred upon a nonresident by the laws of this state pertaining to the operation by him of a motor vehicle, or the use of a motor vehicle owned by him in this state. 
    Operator means a person who is in actual physical control of a motor vehicle. 
    Owner means a person who holds the legal title to a motor vehicle; or in the event a motor vehicle is the subject of an agreement for the conditional sale or lease thereof with the right of purchase upon performance of the conditions stated in the agreement and with an immediate right of possession vested in the conditional vendee or lessee, or in the event a mortgagor of a motor vehicle is entitled to possession thereof, then such conditional vendee or lessee or mortgagor. 
    Proof of financial responsibility means proof of ability to respond in damages for liability, on account of accidents occurring subsequent to the effective date of said proof, arising out of the ownership, maintenance or use of a motor vehicle, in the amount of $25,000.00 because of bodily injury to or death of one person in any one accident, and, subject to said limit for one person, in the amount of $50,000.00 because of bodily injury to or death of two or more persons in any one accident, and in the amount of $10,000.00 because of injury to or destruction of property of others in any one accident. 
    Registration means registration certificate or certificates and registration plates issued under the laws of this state pertaining to the registration of motor vehicles. 
    State means any state, territory or possession of the United States, the District of Columbia, or any province of the Dominion of Canada. 
    Street or highway means the entire width between property lines of every way or place of whatever nature when any part thereof is open to the use of the public, as a matter of right, for purposes of vehicular traffic. 
    This state means the State of Missouri. 
( Ord. No. 1821 , § 7, 6-19-2017) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo ch. 303. 
Sec. 46-15. - Driving while license or driving privilege is cancelled, suspended or revoked. 
    It shall be unlawful for a person to operate a motor vehicle upon any road or highway within this city if such person's license or driving privilege has been cancelled, suspended, or revoked under the laws of the State of Missouri or any other state and acts with criminal negligence with respect to knowledge of the fact that such person's driving privilege has been cancelled, suspended, or revoked. 
( Ord. No. 1821 , § 8, 6-19-2017) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 302.321. 
Sec. 46-16. - Child restraints-Definitions-Transporting children under sixteen years of age, restraint systems-Penalty-Exceptions. 
(a)  As used in this section, the following terms shall mean: 
    Child booster seat means a seating system which meets the Federal Motor Vehicle Safety Standards set forth in 49 C.F.R. 571.213, as amended, that is designed to elevate a child to properly sit in a federally approved safety belt system; 
    Child passenger restraint system means a seating system which meets the Federal Motor Vehicle Safety Standards set forth in 49 C.F.R. 571.213, as amended, and which is either permanently affixed to a motor vehicle or is affixed to such vehicle by a safety belt or a universal attachment system; 
    Driver means a person who is in actual physical control of a motor vehicle. 
(b)  Every driver transporting a child under the age of 16 years shall be responsible, when transporting such child in a motor vehicle operated by that driver on the streets or highways of this city, for providing for the protection of such child as follows: 
(1)  Children less than four years of age, regardless of weight, shall be secured in a child passenger restraint system appropriate for that child; 
(2)  Children weighing less than 40 pounds, regardless of age, shall be secured in a child passenger restraint system appropriate for that child; 
(3)  Children at least four years of age but less than eight years of age, who also weigh at least 40 pounds but less than 80 pounds, and who are also less than four feet, nine inches tall, shall be secured in a child passenger restraint system or booster seat appropriate for that child; 
(4)  Children at least 80 pounds or children more than four feet, nine inches in height shall be secured by a vehicle safety belt or booster seat appropriate for that child; 
(5)  A child who otherwise would be required to be secured in a booster seat may be transported in the back seat of a motor vehicle while wearing only a lap belt if the back seat of the motor vehicle is not equipped with a combination lap and shoulder belt for booster seat installation; 
(6)  When transporting children in the immediate family when there are more children than there are seating positions in the enclosed area of a motor vehicle, the children who are not able to be restrained by a child safety restraint device appropriate for the child shall sit in the area behind the front seat of the motor vehicle unless the motor vehicle is designed only for a front seat area. The driver transporting children referred to in this subsection is not in violation of this section. 
    This subsection shall only apply to the use of a child passenger restraint system or vehicle safety belt for children less than 16 years of age being transported in a motor vehicle. 
(c)  Any driver who violates subsection (b)(1), (2), or (3) of this section, upon conviction, shall be punished by a fine of not more than $50.00 and court costs. Any driver who violates subsection (b)(4) of of this section shall be subject to a fine of $10.00 and no court costs shall be imposed. If a driver receives a citation for violating subsection (b)(1), (2), or (3) of this section, the charges shall be dismissed or withdrawn if the driver, prior to or at his or her hearing, provides evidence of acquisition of a child passenger restraint system or child booster seat which is satisfactory to the court or the city prosecutor. 
(d)  The provisions of this section shall not apply to any public carrier for hire. The provisions of this section shall not apply to students four years of age or older who are passengers on a school bus designed for carrying 11 passengers or more and which is manufactured or equipped pursuant to Missouri Minimum Standards for School Buses as school buses are defined in RSMo 301.010. 
( Ord. No. 1821 , § 9, 6-19-2017) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 307.179. 
Sec. 46-17. - Excessive noise. 
    No vehicle shall be driven in such manner or condition that excessive and unnecessary noises shall be made by its machinery, motor, muffler, signaling device, other parts or by any improperly loaded cargo. 
( Ord. No. 1821 , § 10, 6-19-2017) 
Secs. 46-18, 46-19. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - EQUIPMENT 

Sec. 46-20. - When lights required. 
(a)  No person shall drive, move, park or be in custody of any vehicle or combination of vehicles upon any street or highway within the city during the times when lighted lamps are required unless such vehicle or combination of vehicles displays lighted lamps and illuminating devices as required under RSMo ch. 307. No person shall use on any vehicle any approved electric lamp or similar device unless the light source of such lamp or device complies with the conditions of approval as to focus and rated candlepower under RSMo ch. 307. 
(b)  Any person violating the provisions of this section as it relates to violations of the usage of lighted lamps required due to weather conditions or fog shall be sentenced to pay a fine of $10.00 for any such conviction and no court costs shall be assessed. 
(c)  Any person violating the provisions of this section other than as it relates to violations of the usage of lighted lamps required due to weather conditions or fog shall be sentenced to pay a fine not to exceed $200.00 for any such conviction. 
(Ord. No. 1801, § 17, 3-21-2016) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 307.040. 
Sec. 46-21. - Dimming of lights. 
(a)  Every person driving a motor vehicle equipped with multiple-beam road lighting equipment, during the times when lighted lamps are required, shall use a distribution of light, or composite beam, directed high enough and of sufficient intensity to reveal persons and vehicles at a safe distance in advance of the vehicle, subject to the following requirements and limitations: Whenever the driver of a vehicle approaches an oncoming vehicle within 500 feet, or is within 300 feet to the rear of another vehicle traveling in the same direction, the driver shall use a distribution of light or composite beam so aimed that the glaring rays are not projected into the eyes of the other driver, and in no case shall the high-intensity portion which is projected to the left of the prolongation of the extreme left side of the vehicle be aimed higher than the center of the lamp from which it comes at a distance of 25 feet ahead, and in no case higher than a level of 42 inches above the level upon which the vehicle stands at a distance of 75 feet ahead. 
(b)  Any person violating the provisions of this section shall be sentenced to pay a fine not to exceed $200.00 for any such conviction. 
(Ord. No. 1801, § 18, 3-21-2016) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 307.070. 
Sec. 46-22. - Taillamps and reflectors required. 
(a)  Every motor vehicle and every motor-drawn vehicle shall be equipped with at least two rear lamps, not less than 15 inches or more than 72 inches above the ground upon which the vehicle stands, which when lighted will exhibit a red light plainly visible from a distance of 500 feet to the rear. Either such rear lamp or a separate lamp shall be so constructed and placed as to illuminate with a white light the rear registration marker and render it clearly legible from a distance of 50 feet to the rear. When the rear registration marker is illuminated by an electric lamp other than the required rear lamps, all such lamps shall be turned on or off only by the same control switch at all times. 
(b)  Every motorcycle registered in this state, when operated on a highway, shall also carry at the rear, either as part of the rear lamp or separately, at least one approved red reflector, which shall be of such size and characteristics and so maintained as to be visible during the times when lighted lamps are required from all distances within 300 feet to 50 feet from such vehicle when directly in front of a motor vehicle displaying lawful undimmed headlamps. A motorcycle may be equipped with a means of varying the brightness of the vehicle's brake light for a duration of not more than five seconds upon application of the vehicle's brakes. 
(c)  Every new passenger car, new commercial motor vehicle, motor-drawn vehicle and omnibus with a capacity of more than six passengers registered in this state after January 1, 1966, when operated on a highway, shall also carry at the rear at least two approved red reflectors, at least one at each side, so designed, mounted on the vehicle and maintained as to be visible during the times when lighted lamps are required from all distances within 500 to 50 feet from such vehicle when directly in front of a motor vehicle displaying lawful undimmed headlamps. Every such reflector shall meet the requirements of RSMo ch. 307, and shall be mounted upon the vehicle at a height not to exceed 60 inches nor less than 15 inches above the surface upon which the vehicle stands. 
(d)  Any person violating the provisions of this section shall be sentenced to pay a fine not to exceed $200.00 for any such conviction. 
(Ord. No. 1801, § 19, 3-21-2016) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 307.075. 
Sec. 46-23. - Backup lamps lighted when vehicle in forward motion. 
(a)  No backup lamp on a motor vehicle shall be continuously lighted when such motor vehicle is in forward motion. 
(b)  Any person violating the provisions of this section shall be sentenced to pay a fine not to exceed $200.00 for any such conviction. 
(Ord. No. 1801, § 20, 3-21-2016) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 307.085. 
Sec. 46-24. - Failure to display red flag or lamp on projection extending five feet from vehicle. 
(a)  All vehicles carrying poles or other objects which project more than five feet from the rear of such vehicle shall, during the period when lights are required by RSMo ch. 307, carry a red light at or near the rear end of the pole or other object so projecting. At other times a red flag or cloth, not less than 16 inches square, shall be displayed at the end of such projection. 
(b)  Any person violating the provisions of this section shall be sentenced to pay a fine not to exceed $200.00 for any such conviction. 
(Ord. No. 1801, § 21, 3-21-2016) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 307.170. 
Sec. 46-25. - Properly equipped bumpers required. 
(a)  Every motor vehicle operated upon any street or highway within the city shall be equipped with front and rear bumpers in strict compliance with the provisions and terms of RSMo 307.172(2). 
(b)  Any person violating the provisions of this section shall be sentenced to pay a fine which, combined with court costs, shall not exceed $300.00 for any such conviction. 
(Ord. No. 1801, § 22, 3-21-2016) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 307.172. 
Sec. 46-26. - Vision-reducing material applied to windshield or windows. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for a person to operate a motor vehicle upon any street or highway within the city with vision-reducing material applied to the windshield or windows of said vehicle unless done in strict compliance with the provisions and terms of RSMo 307.173. 
(b)  Any person violating the provisions of this section shall be sentenced to pay a fine which, combined with court costs, shall not exceed $300.00 for any such conviction. 
(Ord. No. 1801, § 23, 3-21-2016) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 307.173. 
Sec. 46-27. - Seat belts required; exceptions. 
(a)  As used in this section, the term "passenger car" means every motor vehicle designed for carrying ten persons or fewer and used for the transportation of persons; except that the term "passenger car" shall not include motorcycles, motorized bicycles, motor tricycles, and trucks with a licensed gross weight of 12,000 pounds or more. 
(b)  Each driver, except persons employed by the United States Postal Service while performing duties for that federal agency which require the operator to service postal boxes from their vehicles, or which require frequent entry into and exit from their vehicles, and front seat passenger of a passenger car manufactured after January 1, 1968, operated upon any street or highway within the city, and persons less than 18 years of age operating or riding in a truck, as defined in RSMo 301.010, upon any street or highway within the city shall wear a properly adjusted and fastened safety belt that meets federal National Highway, Transportation and Safety Act requirements. No person shall be stopped, inspected, or detained solely to determine compliance with this subsection. The provisions of this section shall not be applicable to persons who have a medical reason for failing to have a seat belt fastened about their body, nor shall the provisions of this section be applicable to persons while operating or riding a motor vehicle being used in agricultural work-related activities. Noncompliance with this subsection shall not constitute probable cause for violation of any other provision of law. The provisions of this subsection shall not apply to the transporting of children under 16 years of age, as provided in state law. 
(c)  Each driver of a motor vehicle transporting a child less than 16 years of age shall secure the child in a properly adjusted and fastened restraint under state law. 
(d)  If there are more persons than there are seat belts in the enclosed area of a motor vehicle, then the passengers who are unable to wear seat belts shall sit in the area behind the front seat of the motor vehicle unless the motor vehicle is designed only for a front-seated area. The passenger or passengers occupying a seat location referred to in this subsection is not in violation of this section. This subsection shall not apply to passengers who are accompanying a driver of a motor vehicle who is licensed under RSMo 302.178. 
(e)  Except as otherwise provided for in state law, each person who violates the provisions of subsection (b) of this section shall be sentenced to pay a fine of $10.00 for any such conviction and no court costs shall be assessed. 
(Ord. No. 1801, § 24, 3-21-2016) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 307.178. 
Sec. 46-28. - Lights and reflectors, when required-Standards to be met. 
    Every bicycle and motorized bicycle when in use on a street or highway during the period from one-half hour after sunset to one-half hour before sunrise shall be equipped with the following: 
(1)  A front-facing lamp on the front or carried by the rider which shall emit a white light visible at night under normal atmospheric conditions on a straight, level, unlighted roadway at 500 feet; 
(2)  A rear-facing red reflector, at least two square inches in reflective surface area, or a rear-facing red lamp, on the rear which shall be visible at night under normal atmospheric conditions on a straight, level, unlighted roadway when viewed by a vehicle driver under the lower beams of vehicle headlights at 600 feet; 
(3)  Reflective material and/or lights on any part of the bicyclist's pedals, crank arms, shoes or lower leg, visible from the front and the rear at night under normal atmospheric conditions on a straight, level, unlighted roadway when viewed by a vehicle driver under the lawful lower beams of vehicle headlights at 200 feet; and 
(4)  Reflective material and/or lights visible on each side of the bicycle or bicyclist and visible at night under normal atmospheric conditions on a straight, level, unlighted roadway when viewed by a vehicle driver under the lawful lower beams of vehicle headlights at 300 feet. The provisions of this subdivision shall not apply to motorized bicycles which comply with National Highway Traffic and Safety Administration regulations relating to reflectors on motorized bicycles. 
( Ord. No. 1821 , § 11, 6-19-2017) 
Secs. 46-29-46-34. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - OPERATION OF VEHICLES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Traffic regulations, RSMo 304.010 et seq. 

Sec. 46-35. - Special traffic regulations for public square. 
(a)  There shall be two traffic patterns for the movement of traffic around the public square. One pattern shall move in a counterclockwise direction around the outside of the square and the other pattern shall move in a clockwise direction around the inside of the square. 
(b)  Motor vehicles moving within a traffic pattern shall have the right-of-way, and those motor vehicles entering, intending to enter, or crossing a traffic pattern shall yield the right-of-way to vehicles moving within a traffic pattern. 
(c)  An operator of a motor vehicle may make a U-turn by first driving forward and coming to a complete stop within a parking space located between the two traffic patterns. The operator shall yield the right-of-way to vehicles moving in a traffic pattern. All other U-turns are prohibited. 
(d)  Motor vehicles parked or standing in center parking spaces located between traffic patterns shall always move forward to enter a traffic pattern. The backing of motor vehicles from center parking spaces is prohibited. 
(Code 1991, § 12-77) 
Sec. 46-36. - Other motor vehicle violations. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to ride on a moving motor vehicle other than in or on areas intended for seating of passengers. 
(b)  No person shall ride a skateboard, scooter, roller skates, coaster, toy vehicle, or similar device which is attached to and propelled by a moving motor vehicle. 
(c)  It shall also be unlawful to operate a motor vehicle under the conditions set forth in subsections (a) and (b) of this section. 
(d)  No person shall ride or operate a skateboard, scooter (whether self-propelled or propelled by a gas or electric engine), roller skates, coaster, toy vehicle, or similar device on the public streets of the city. This subsection shall also apply to the operation of mini-motorcycles except when being driven by a licensed operator. 
(Code 1991, § 12-78; Ord. No. 1634, § 1, 6-21-2004) 
Sec. 46-37. - Driving on private property to avoid traffic-control devices. 
    No person shall drive a motor vehicle through or on any private property adjacent to any street intersection to avoid a traffic-control device. 
(Code 1991, § 12-81; Ord. No. 1536, § 3, 1-18-1999) 
Sec. 46-38. - Operating where prohibited, semi-tractor trailer units. 
    The operator of a semi-tractor trailer unit shall not operate such vehicle on any of the following streets in the city: 
(1)  On 13th Street between Francis Street and Heagon Street. 
(2)  On Oak Street north of 9th Street. 
(Code 1991, § 12-82; Ord. No. 1539, § 1, 4-19-1999) 
Sec. 46-39. - Driving on right half of roadway. 
(a)  Upon all streets or highways within the city of sufficient width, a vehicle shall be driven upon the right half of the roadway, except as follows: 
(1)  When overtaking and passing another vehicle proceeding in the same direction pursuant to the rules governing such movement; 
(2)  When placing a vehicle in position for and when such vehicle is lawfully making a left turn in compliance with the provisions of RSMo 304.014-304.025, or RSMo 300.215 of the Model Traffic Ordinance; 
(3)  When the right half of a roadway is closed to traffic while under construction or repair; 
(4)  Upon a roadway designated by ordinance as a one-way street and marked or signed for one-way traffic. 
(b)  Any person violating the provisions of this section where an accident or injury was involved shall be sentenced under the general sentencing provisions as provided in section 1-9. 
(c)  Any person violating the provisions of this section where no accident or injury was involved shall be sentenced to pay a fine which, combined with court costs, shall not exceed $300.00 for any such conviction. 
(Ord. No. 1801, § 6, 3-21-2016) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 304.015. 
Sec. 46-40. - Hand and mechanical signals. 
(a)  No person shall stop or suddenly decrease the speed of or turn a vehicle from a direct course or move right or left upon a roadway unless and until such movement can be made with reasonable safety and then only after the giving of an appropriate signal in the manner provided herein. 
(1)  An operator or driver when stopping, or when checking the speed of the operator's vehicle, if the movement of other vehicles may reasonably be affected by such checking of speed, shall extend such operator's arm at an angle below horizontal so that the same may be seen in the rear of the vehicle; 
(2)  An operator or driver intending to turn the operator's vehicle to the right shall extend such operator's arm at an angle above horizontal so that the same may be seen in front of and in the rear of the vehicle, and shall slow down and approach the intersecting roadway as near as practicable to the right side of the roadway along which such operator is proceeding before turning; 
(3)  An operator or driver intending to turn the operator's vehicle to the left shall extend such operator's arm in a horizontal position so that the same may be seen in the rear of the vehicle, and shall slow down and approach the intersecting highway so that the left side of the vehicle shall be as near as practicable to the centerline of the roadway along which the operator is proceeding before turning; 
(4)  The signals herein required shall be given either by means of the hand and arm or by a signal light or signal device in good mechanical condition of a type approved by the state highway patrol; however, when a vehicle is so constructed or loaded that a hand and arm signal would not be visible both to the front and rear of such vehicle then such signals shall be given by such light or device. A vehicle shall be considered as so constructed or loaded that a hand and arm signal would not be visible both to the front and rear when the distance from the center of the top of the steering post to the left outside limit of the body, cab or load exceeds 24 inches, or when the distance from the center of the top of the steering post to the rear limit of the body or load thereon exceeds 14 feet, which limit of 14 feet shall apply to single vehicles or combinations of vehicles. The provisions of this subdivision shall not apply to any trailer which does not interfere with a clear view of the hand signals of the operator or of the signaling device upon the vehicle pulling such trailer. 
(b)  Any person violating the provisions of this section shall be sentenced to pay a fine which, combined with court costs, shall not exceed $300.00 for any such conviction. 
(Ord. No. 1801, § 7, 3-21-2016) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo 304.019. 
Sec. 46-41. - Emergency vehicle defined; use of lights and sirens; other drivers to yield right-of-way; procedure regarding stationary vehicles. 
(a)  Upon the immediate approach of an emergency vehicle giving audible signal by siren or while having at least one lighted lamp exhibiting red light visible under normal atmospheric conditions from a distance of 500 feet to the front of such vehicle or a flashing blue light authorized by RSMo 307.175, the driver of every other vehicle shall yield the right-of-way and shall immediately drive to a position parallel to, and as far as possible to the right of, the traveled portion of the roadway and thereupon stop and remain in such position until such emergency vehicle has passed, except when otherwise directed by a police or traffic officer. 
(b)  Upon approaching a stationary emergency vehicle displaying lighted red or red and blue lights, or a stationary vehicle owned by the state highways and transportation commission and operated by an authorized employee of the state department of transportation displaying lighted amber or amber and white lights, the driver of every motor vehicle shall proceed with due caution and reduce the speed of the vehicle, maintaining a safe speed for road conditions. 
(c)  An emergency vehicle is a vehicle of any of the following types: 
(1)  A vehicle operated by the state highway patrol, the state water patrol, a conservation agent, or a state park ranger, those vehicles operated by enforcement personnel of the state highways and transportation commission, police or fire department, sheriff, constable or deputy sheriff, federal law enforcement officer authorized to carry firearms and to make arrests for violations of the laws of the United States, traffic officer or coroner or by a privately owned emergency vehicle company; 
(2)  A vehicle operated as an ambulance or operated commercially for the purpose of transporting emergency medical supplies or organs; 
(3)  Any vehicle qualifying as an emergency vehicle pursuant to RSMo 307.175; 
(4)  Any wrecker, or tow truck or a vehicle owned and operated by a public utility or public service corporation while performing emergency service; 
(5)  Any vehicle transporting equipment designed to extricate human beings from the wreckage of a motor vehicle; 
(6)  Any vehicle designated to perform emergency functions for a civil defense or emergency management agency established pursuant to the provisions of RSMo ch. 44; 
(7)  Any vehicle operated by an authorized employee of the department of corrections who, as part of the employee's official duties, is responding to a riot, disturbance, hostage incident, escape or other critical situation where there is the threat of serious physical injury or death, responding to mutual aid call from another criminal justice agency, or accompanying an ambulance which is transporting an offender to a medical facility; 
(8)  Any vehicle designated to perform hazardous substance emergency functions established pursuant to the provisions of RSMo 260.500 and 260.550; or
